[[Bridey Elliott]] (sister) }} '''Abby Elliott''' (born June 16, 1987) is an American [[actress]] and [[comedian]] who was a cast member on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' for four seasons (from 2008 to 2012) and co-starred on the [[Bravo (U.S. TV network)|Bravo]] series ''[[Odd Mom Out]]''. She is the daughter of actor/comedian [[Chris Elliott]]. ==Life and career== Elliott was born in [[New York City]], the elder of two children. She is the daughter of Paula Niedert, a talent coordinator, and actor/comedian [[Chris Elliott]]. Her grandfather is radio comedian [[Bob Elliott (comedian)|Bob Elliott]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/29/magazine/29Elliott-t.html?_r=1&ref=todayspaper&pagewanted=all|title=A Professionally Funny Family|last=Zuckerman|first=Ed|work=The New York Times|date=November 11, 2009|accessdate=January 7, 2011}} Her younger sister is actress [[Bridey Elliott|Bridey Elliott;]] they were both raised in [[Wilton, Connecticut]].{{cite web|url=http://wilton.dailyvoice.com/neighbors/happy-birthday-wilton-s-abigail-abby-elliott|title=Happy Birthday To Wilton’s Abigail 'Abby' Elliott|date=June 16, 2014|publisher=wilton.dailyvoice.com|accessdate=March 7, 2015}} She attended high school at [[Immaculate High School]] in [[Danbury, Connecticut]], where she acted in school plays and musicals. After graduating from Immaculate High School in 2005, she attended [[Marymount Manhattan College]] in New York City but dropped out during the first semester.{{cite news|last= Nellie|first=Andreeva|title='SNL' taps Abby Elliott, Michaela Watkins |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/snl-taps-abby-elliott-michaela-122861 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=November 12, 2008}} In 2006, Elliott appeared with supporting roles for the [[Television pilot|pilots]] ''You've Reached the Elliotts'' and ''Chrissy: Plain & Simple'', both sitcoms that star her father, Chris Elliott. While at UCBT, she frequently performed with [[The Midnight Show]] sketch troupe. She has also occasionally performed comedy with her sister Bridey. Before joining the cast of ''SNL'', Elliott had also done guest voices roles on ''[[King of the Hill]]'' and ''[[Minoriteam]]''.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2008/scene/news/elliott-watkins-join-snl-cast-1117995768/|title=Elliott, Watkins join ‘SNL’ cast|last=Littleton|first=Cynthia|date=November 12, 2008|publisher=variety.com|accessdate=March 7, 2015}} She has also been featured in a number of ''[[Late Night with Jimmy Fallon]]'' sketches such as "Jersey Floor" and "Studio 6-Bee".{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jimmy-fallon-jersey-shore-186198|title=Tina Fey, Amy Poehler, Jimmy Fallon Mock NBC in 'Jersey Shore' Spoof (Video)|last=Power|first=Lindsay|date=May 6, 2011|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=March 7, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2010/02/02/glee-jimmy-fallon-studio-6-bee|title=Jimmy Fallon parodies 'Glee': Living on a prayer for cue cards|last=Barrett|first=Annie|date=February 2, 2010|publisher=ew.com|accessdate=March 7, 2015}} Elliott made her film debut with a small role in ''[[No Strings Attached (film)|No Strings Attached]]'', and has since had supporting roles in the films ''[[High Road (film)|High Road]]'' and ''[[Fun Size]]''.{{cite web|title=Exclusive: Abby Elliott on Her New Movie, A Role on 'How I Met Your Mother,' and Leaving 'SNL'|url=http://www.elle.com/news/culture/abby-elliott-interview-fun-size-saturday-night-live|accessdate=October 12, 2012|work=Elle}}{{cite news|url=http://www.irishnews.com/features/not-so-fun-size-comedy-1202690 |title=Not so Fun Size comedy |work=[[The Irish News]] |date=November 2, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140107212700/http://www.irishnews.com/features/not-so-fun-size-comedy-1202690 |archivedate=January 7, 2014 }} Since leaving ''SNL'' in 2012, Elliott has made guest appearances on television programs such as ''[[2 Broke Girls]]'', ''[[How I Met Your Mother]]'', ''[[Happy Endings (TV series)|Happy Endings]]'', and ''[[Inside Amy Schumer]]''.{{cite web|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2012/12/14/happy-endings-abby-elliott/|title=Happy Endings -- Abby Elliott to guest star - Inside TV - EW.com|work=EW.com|accessdate=December 15, 2014}} From 2015 to 2017, she co-starred on the [[Bravo (U.S. TV network)|Bravo]] series ''[[Odd Mom Out]]''. ===''Saturday Night Live''=== Elliott joined the cast of ''SNL'' midway through the [[Saturday Night Live (season 34)|2008–2009 season]] (Season 34), in November 2008, following the departure of [[Amy Poehler]]. She is the third generation of her family to have been featured on ''SNL'' (the second to be hired as a cast member, and her tenure on the show was longer than both her father and grandfather). Her father, Chris Elliott, was an ''SNL'' cast member during the [[Saturday Night Live (season 20)|1994–1995 season]] (Season 20) and her grandfather, Bob Elliott, was one half of the popular comedy duo [[Bob & Ray]]. Bob Elliott co-starred on a Christmas episode in the [[Saturday Night Live (season 4)|1978–1979 season]] (Season 4). After four seasons on ''SNL'', Elliott was let go from the show prior to its [[Saturday Night Live (season 38)|38th season]]. ====Celebrity impressions on ''SNL''==== *[[Zooey Deschanel]] *[[Angelina Jolie]] *[[Anna Faris]] *[[Khloé Kardashian]] *[[Meryl Streep]] *[[Rachel Maddow]] *[[Rosie Pope]] *[[Katy Perry]] *[[Brittany Murphy]] *[[Sarah McLachlan]] *[[Ke$ha]] *[[Christina Aguilera]] *[[Anne Hathaway]] *[[Joan Cusack]] *[[Sally Field]] *[[Leah Remini]] *[[Nancy Grace]] *[[k.d. lang]] *[[Kate Middleton]] *[[Shaun White]] ====Recurring characters on ''SNL''==== *Shirley, one of the singing sisters on ''[[The Lawrence Welk Show]]''. *One of the French girls in "Les Jeunes de Paris". *Fur Coat Rhonda, one of the comedians in "The Original Kings of Catchphrase Comedy". *Paula, one of Gilly's classmates that always tattles on her. ==Personal life== In 2010, Elliott dated fellow ''Saturday Night Live'' cast member [[Fred Armisen]].{{cite news|last1=Oh|first1=Eunice|last2=Triggs|first2=Charlotte|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20414197,00.html |title=Fred Armisen and Abby Elliott's Relationship in 'Early Stages'|newspaper=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=August 19, 2010}} They ended their relationship in September 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20532202,00.html|title=Fred Armisen and Abby Elliott Split|last=Triggs|first=Charlotte|date=September 27, 2011|publisher=people.com|accessdate=March 7, 2015}} Elliott married television writer Bill Kennedy on September 3, 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.theknot.com/news/abby-elliott-shares-beautiful-proposal-story-there-were-flowers-everywhere-3757|title=Abby Elliott Shares "Beautiful" Proposal Story|date=January 26, 2016|publisher=}} ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Film ! '''Allen Meadows''' is an [[United States|American]] [[wine critic]] and publisher of the Burghound.com quarterly newsletter and website.<ref name=jrpw>{{Cite web |last= Robinson |first= Jancis, jancisrobinson.com |url= http://www.jancisrobinson.com/articles/directorypubs |title= publications and websites |date= February 7, 2006 |access-date= 2008-07-30 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080913202450/http://www.jancisrobinson.com/articles/directorypubs |archive-date= 2008-09-13 |dead-url= yes |df= }}</ref> He was a financial executive and private wine collector until a profile published in ''[[Wine Spectator]]'' in 1997 led him to decide to follow his passion for wine. By 2000, Meadows had left his role of CFO at a publicly traded insurance company<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=http://illdrinktothatpod.com/post/64751848241/episode-123-tuesday-october-22-2013-allen|title=Episode 123: Allen Meadows|date=|website=illdrinktothatpod.com|publisher=Levi Dalton|last1=Meadows|first1=Allen|accessdate=22 February 2017}}</ref> and launched the Burghound.com site, which offers subscribers newsletters with reviews of [[Burgundy wine]] and [[California wine|California]] and [[Oregon wine|Oregon]] [[Pinot noir]] wines.<ref name=msft>{{cite web|last= Steinberger |first= Mike, ''Financial Times'' |title= New voice on the grapevine |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/92d94ba6-24e4-11d8-81c6-08209b00dd01,id=030808004410.html |date=August 8, 2003 }}</ref> Meadows also regularly speaks on Burgundy and other wine subjects. Burghound.com also organizes wine events such as the Asia Symphony of Wine and Flavours - Burghound in Asia, which is held in [[Singapore]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.yoursingapore.com/content/traveller/en/browse/apps/eventdetails.856.html |title=YourSingapore.com - Asia Symphony of Wine and Flavours – Burghound in Asia |access-date=2011-03-31 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110225001046/http://www.yoursingapore.com/content/traveller/en/browse/apps/eventdetails.856.html |archive-date=2011-02-25 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
Within a relatively short time following its launch, and despite a relatively high cost of subscription, the service came to be viewed by many as "the definitive word on matters Burgundian",<ref name=nys>{{cite web|last= Kramer |first= Matt, ''New York Sun'' |title= Wine for Right Now |url= http://www.nysun.com/food-drink/wine-for-right-now/46039/ |date= January 3, 2007 }}</ref> and Meadows "a leading Burgundy critic".<ref name=eanytp>{{cite web|last= Asimov |first= Eric, ''The New York Times'': The Pour |title= Ancient Messages, Hidden in a Dusty Bottle From Long Ago |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/03/dining/03pour.html |date= January 3, 2007 }}</ref>
Among the reasons cited for the success of Burghound.com are that Meadows already held a strong online discussion-group reputation, and that [[Robert M. Parker, Jr.|Robert Parker]] had ceased to cover Burgundy for ''[[The Wine Advocate]]'' in 1996, and delegated coverage of the region to Pierre Rovani with limited success, providing an opening for Meadows.<ref name=wofw-ws>{{cite web|last=Steinberger |first=Mike, ''The World of Fine Wine'' |title=Everyone a Critic. The Future of Wine Writing |url=http://www.finewinemag.com/docs/SteinbergerWineWriting.pdf |date=March 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519182406/http://www.finewinemag.com/docs/SteinbergerWineWriting.pdf |archivedate=2011-05-19 }}</ref> As Parker already had strained relations with the Burgundy wine community, wine critics of global coverage such as [[Stephen Tanzer]] and [[Clive Coates]] were perceived to dominate the field.<ref name=msft/> It has been suggested that the Burghound coverage of the 2005 vintage of Burgundy did as much to Meadows' reputation as 1982 [[Bordeaux (wine)|Bordeaux]] did for Robert Parker.<ref name=wofw-ws/>
In 2010, Meadows and his wife Erica released a book by way of self-publishing, titled ''The Pearl of the Côte'' on the subject of the history and vineyards of [[Vosne-Romanée wine|Vosne-Romanée]], while opting not to list the book on channels such as [[Amazon.com]].<ref>Robinson, Jancis, ''Financial Times'' (July 23, 2010). [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/579b5f12-95e8-11df-bbb4-00144feab49a.html DIY wine books]</ref><ref>Asimov, Eric, ''The New York Times'' (October 4, 2010). [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/06/dining/06pour.html?src=twt&twt=nytimesbooks Six New Books for Wine and Spirits Lovers]</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox writer | image = | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1961|7|27}} | birth_place = [[Awgu]], Enugu State, Nigeria | death_date = | death_place = | resting_place = | occupation = Professor of criminology | language = English | nationality = Nigerian | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = PhD in Criminology | alma_mater = [[University of Edinburgh]] | period = | genre = Criminology | subject = | movement = | notableworks = ''Black women and the criminal justice system'' (1997),
''Counter-Colonial Criminology: A Critique of Imperialist Reason'' (2003) | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | portaldisp = }} '''Biko Agozino''' (born 27 July 1961) is a [[Nigerian people|Nigerian]] criminologist best known for his 1997 book ''Black Women and the Criminal Justice System''. == Early life and education == Agozino was born on 27 July 1961 in [[Awgu]], Enugu State, Nigeria. He attended the [[University of Calabar]] where he gained a BSc in Sociology, the [[University of Cambridge]] where he gained a Master of Philosophy in Criminology, and the [[University of Edinburgh]] where he earned a PhD in Criminology. == Career == Agozino has been editor of the ''Interdisciplinary Research Series in Ethnic, Gender and Class Relations'' series of books from [[Ashgate Publishing]]. His 1997 ''Black Women and the Criminal Justice System: Towards the Decolonisation of Victimisation'' was the first of these. By 2008 over two dozen books had been published in the series.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4bsCAuOtjgcC&pg=PR9 |page=vii |title=Policing and crime control in post-apartheid South Africa |author=Anne-Marie Singh |publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd. |year=2008 |ISBN=0-7546-4457-X}} He was appointed editor-in-chief of the ''[[African Journal of Criminology and Justice Studies]]'' and a member of the [[editorial board]] of ''Jenda: A Journal of West African Women's Studies and Culture''. Agozino is a founding member of the international governing council of the [[Lagos]]-based think tank the ''[[Centre for Democracy and Development]]''. In 2007, Agozino was appointed criminology unit coordinator and professor in sociology at the [[University of the West Indies]], St Augustine, Trinidad and Tobago.{{cite web |url=http://sta.uwi.edu/fss/criminology/bagozino.asp |publisher=University of the West Indies |title=Professor Biko Agozino |accessdate=26 June 2011}} ==Work== Agozino's work explores the past and present impact of colonisation on the way in which racial and ethnic minorities are treated by justice systems worldwide.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5GHHmigraB0C&pg=PR11 |page=xi |title=Race, ethnicity, crime, and justice: an international dilemma |author=[[Shaun L. Gabbidon]] |publisher=SAGE |year=2009 |ISBN=1-4129-4988-2}} His work develops a postcolonial perspective in African criminology.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FivwDxt24goC&pg=PA251 |page=251 |title=What Is Criminology? |author=[[Mary Bosworth]], Carolyn Hoyle |publisher=Oxford University Press US |year=2011 |ISBN=0-19-957182-1}} Agozino challenges the criminology discipline to "decolonize" its theories and methods and to undo the harm that has been done.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mPEXNfEn-kYC&pg=PA129 |page=129 |title=Criminology: the key concepts |author=Martin O'Brien, Majid Yar |publisher=Taylor & Francis |year=2008 |ISBN=0-415-42794-0}} In his introduction to Gabbidon's 2007 ''W.E.B. Du Bois on crime and justice'', Agozino notes that "excessive punitiveness" in the criminal justice systems of the US, UK, South Africa and Russia has been increasing rather than reducing the problem of crime. He also noted the hypocrisy of British and American leaders in calling [[Nelson Mandela]] a terrorist as he was struggling with the terrorist [[apartheid]] regime in South Africa.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=l_UYl-3_NJsC&pg=PR10 |page=x |title=W.E.B. Du Bois on crime and justice: laying the foundations of sociological criminology |author=Shaun L. Gabbidon |publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd. |year=2007 |ISBN=0-7546-4956-3}} His work is theoretical in nature, discussing the development of criminology in western countries and their impact on non-western societies, particularly former colonies. It has rejuvenated the colonial perspective on race and crime.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lJBiJTKt5n8C&pg=PA189 |page=189 |title=Criminological Perspectives on Race and Crime |author=Shaun L. Gabbidon |publisher=Taylor & Francis |year=2010 |ISBN=0-415-87424-6}} In his 1997 ''Black women and the criminal justice system'' Agozino notes the roles of race and ethnicity in negotiation of power within prison, where coloured people are greatly under-represented among prison officers and over-represented among inmates. He does not discuss the importance, at least in England, of the factors of class and geography.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RyBF1WXXmckC&pg=PA146 |page=146 |title=Women in prison: gender and social control |author=Barbara H. Zaitzow, Jim Thomas |publisher=Lynne Rienner Publishers |year=2003 |ISBN=1-58826-228-6}} His book also discusses fixed political positions on types of crime. He notes that when US Surgeon General [[Jocelyn Elders]] said the government should seriously look into the experience of countries that had decriminalised drug addiction she was dismissed from her job by President [[Bill Clinton]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aKur_wfD5NEC&pg=PA240 |page=240 |title=Good punishment?: Christian moral practice and U.S. imprisonment |author=James Samuel Logan |publisher=Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing |year=2008 |ISBN=0-8028-6324-8}} A review of Agozino's 2003 book ''Counter-Colonial Criminology: A Critique of Imperialist Reason'' concluded: ".., this is a book that deserves to be on all criminological reading lists, and it would be at home in any African centred studies course. It offers a generous amount of scholarly inquiry into an area that has paid scant attention to African and other “people of color’s” perspectives in the criminological discourse. It is therefore groundbreaking and a must read".{{cite journal |url=http://www.africa.ufl.edu/asq/v8/v8i3a5.pdf |title=Counter-Colonial Criminology: A Critique of Imperialist Reason. Biko Agozino. London: Pluto, 2003. 281 pp. |author=Mark Christian |journal=African Studies Quarterly |volume=8 |issue=3 |date=Spring 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929132747/http://www.africa.ufl.edu/asq/v8/v8i3a5.pdf |archivedate=29 September 2011 |df=dmy }} Another review of this book talked about the "complexity and creativity of this angry yet optimistic work". A third review said "Henceforth, criminology will no longer concentrate in the study of crime and criminals, but will also include the study of justice".{{cite journal |url=http://www.umes.edu/cms300uploadedfiles/ajcjs/acjavol1no1onyeozili2.pdf |title=Counter-Colonial Criminology: A Critique of Imperialist Reason by Biko Agozino. London: Pluto Press, 2003. |author=Emmanuel C. Onyeozili |authorlink=Emmanuel Onyeozili |journal=[[African Journal of Criminology and Justice Studies]] |publisher=[[University of Maryland Eastern Shore]] |date=Spring 2005 |accessdate=27 June 2011}} ==Bibliography== *{{cite book |title=Black women and the criminal justice system: towards the decolonisation of victimisation |author=Biko Agozino |publisher=Ashgate |year=1997 [[Image:Mokrani.jpg|thumb|Cheikh Mokrani]] [[Sheikh]] '''Mohamed El- Mokrani''' ({{lang-ar|الشيخ محمد المقراني}}{{ltr}}; 1815–1871) was one of the principal leaders of the popular uprising at the end of 19th century following the French conquest in [[Bordj Bou Arréridj|Bordj Bou Arreridj, Algeria]] in 1830.
== Reasons for Revolt ==
The revolt was triggered by extension of civil colonization authority to previously self-governing tribal [[Berber people|Berber]] confederation and the abrogation of commitments made by the military government, but it clearly had its basis in more long-standing grievances. Since the [[Crimean War]] (1854–56), the demand for grain had pushed up the price of Algerian wheat to European levels. Storage silos were emptied when the world market's impact was felt in Algeria, and Muslim farmers sold their grain reserves — including seed grain — to French speculators. When serious drought struck [[Algeria]] and grain crops failed in 1866 and for several years following, Muslim areas faced starvation, and with famine also came [[infectious disease|pestilence]]. It was estimated that 20% of the Muslim population of [[Constantine, Algeria|Constantine]] died over a three-year period. In 1871 the civil authorities repudiated guarantees made to tribal chieftains by the previous military government for loans to replenish their seed supply. This act alienated even pro-French Muslim leaders, while it undercut their ability to control their people. It was against this background of misery and hopelessness that the stricken [[Kabyles]] rose in revolt.
== Revolt of Cheikh Mokrani == {{main|Mokrani Revolt}} Mohand at-AMokrane was the son of Ahmed AMokrane one of the governors (Bachagha) of the area of [[Medjana]] located in the highlands of [[Kabylie]], who was also the cheikh of [[Rahmania]] order. After the death of Ahmed -AMokrane, the French authorities appointed Mohand in his place. However following dissension with the French administration, he resigned from his position in March 1871. This conflict happened as a result of the colonial authorities disregarding at-aMokrane, creating a French-populated commune of Bordj Bou Arréridj and appointing a French officer as its head. The great many discontented flocked to the banners of the Cheikh aggrieved by the ravages of famine, increasing racial oppression by the French and Christianization policy pursued by the [[Catholic]] church.
In March 1871 Mohamed El-Mokrani revolted against French by carrying out his army until Bordj- Bou -Arréridj with the assistance of his brother [[oumezrag]] and his cousin El Hadj Bouzid, and Sheikh mohand ameziane AHaddad of saddouk oufella great schollar theoligien of the zaouia tarahmanit which joined this uprising with his tribe. Using his position and influence on Rahmania brotherhood sheikh mohand-aMokrane was able to overcome the dissension in his camp and retake Bordj-Bou-Arreridj.
The members of the brotherhood Rahamania, disciples of the Sheik Ahaddad(El Haddad) played an eminent part in success of the insurrection of El Mokrani(amokrane), in particular after Sheikh Ahaddad(El Haddad) had proclaimed the [[war]] against the French on April 8, 1871. The insurrection acquired a total character through the increase in the number of combatants who rejoined it and his extension to the west, north and the East where considerable stations of the colonial army were encircled in several areas.
After having carried several battles Mohand Amokrane(Mohamed El-Mokrani) was martyred on May 5, 1871 at Taouraga. His tomb is located in kollaa n'at-Abbas (Bgayet)([[Béjaïa]]). Under the command of his brother Oumzrag (Boumezreg), the uprising continued until January 20, 1872, date of his arrest and deportation to New Caledonia, an island in the Pacific.
== Consequences of the Revolt ==
After the arrest of Sheik-el-Haddad, the jihad continued under [[Bouamama]]. There were also other small insurrectionary movements at Blessed-Menaceur, which forces besieged Cherchel, Zurich, Vesoul-Benian and Hammam-Rirha; this movement was also crushed. From July to September 1872, French forces had still to completely subdued [[Kabylie]]. Bou-Mezrag took refuge at Maadid, and later managed to escape the French finding allies among the [[Tuareg people|Tuareg]] tribes of the South. The general Delacroix, with a small expeditionary force, continued to pursue the rebels until beyond Ouargla. BouMezrag Mokrani, which had remained six days without drinking nor to eat, was finally captured removed.
The insurrection, which had begun on March 16, 1871 in Medjana was finished on January 20, 1872 by the arrest of Bou-Mezrag. Although a third only of Algeria had taken part in the movement, there had been about 200.000 combatants under the rebel flag.
Exile of the brother of El-Mokrani and the whole family to the [[New Caledonia]] occurred shortly afterwards. Together with them 212 persons, called [[Kabyles du Pacifique]], who participated in the revolt were tried and deported by French authorities to labor camps on the island of New Caledonia. Mokrani's descendants still live on the island.
{{Authority control}}

[[File:Constancedrexel.djvu|thumb|250px|right|Constance Drexel (1925)]] '''Constance Drexel''' (ca. November 24, 1884 or ca. November 28, 1894 (possible; disputed) – August 28, 1956), a naturalized [[United States citizen]],<ref name=calling>John Carver Edwards, ''Berlin Calling: American Broadcasters in Service to the Third Reich'', Praeger Publishers (1991), pp. 15-16; {{ISBN|0-275-93905-7}}</ref> and groundbreaking feature writer for U.S. newspapers,<ref name=sally>M. Williams Fuller, ''Axis Sally'', Paradise West Publishing, pg. 168; {{ISBN|0-9723675-7-8}}</ref> was indicted (but not tried or convicted) for [[treason]] in [[World War II]] for radio broadcasts from [[Berlin]] that extolled [[Nazi]] virtues.<ref name=indict>Associated Press, "8 Indicted on Charges of Treason", ''Moberly Monitor-Index'', July 26, 1943, at page 1.</ref>
She became famous falsely claiming to be an heiress of the famous Drexel family of [[Philadelphia]].<ref name=oakland>"Society by Suzette", ''Oakland Tribune'', August 8, 1915, at page 26.</ref><ref name=ohio>Editorial, Hamilton (OH) Evening Journal, 1916-10-18 at 8.</ref><ref name=coffee>Constance Drexel, “United States Spikes Imports of Brazilian Coffee into Germany — Economic Pressure Makes Large Part of Fatherland Population Quit Beverage,” Oakland Tribune, 1939-07-16 at B-7.</ref><ref name=hawhaw>Madelin Blitzstein, “Berlin’s Lady Haw Haw Philadelphia’s Who Who?” Brownsville Herald, 1940-08-24, at 3.</ref> Arrested in [[Vienna]] and jailed at war’s end by American troops,<ref name=arrest>“Constance Drexel Held as 'Traitor'”, ''The Port Arthur News'', August 17, 1945; page 8.</ref> she was released and allowed to return to the United States to live.<ref name=freed>“Constance Drexel Freed; Citizenship Held Not Forefeited,” Wisconsin State Journal, October 3, 1946; page 21.</ref> The [[U.S. Department of Justice]] eventually dismissed the treason charges against her because her broadcasts were not deemed “political in nature.”<ref name=dismiss>“US Dismisses Charges Against Miss Drexel”, ''Council Bluffs Nonpareil'', April 14, 1948; page 9.</ref>
==Family and childhood== Public references to Drexel's nation of origin and pedigree were contrary to privately recorded facts. As early as 1915 (in American press reports) and as late as the 1940s (in Nazi broadcasts), she was described as a member of the "famous Drexel family" of [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]], an apparent reference to the descendants of [[Francis Martin Drexel]] (who founded the Drexel & Company banking empire), including his son [[Anthony Joseph Drexel]] (who founded [[Drexel University]] in Philadelphia) and his granddaughter [[Saint Katharine Drexel]].
Yet by all accounts, including the one provided by Constance Drexel to the [[Bureau of Investigation]] in 1918,<ref name=fbi>Interview reports of Agent J.F. McDevitt regarding “Constance Drexel, application for passport” June 21, 1918, available at footnote.com; accessed August 5, 2008.</ref> she was born in [[Germany]], apparently in the 1880s, many decades after Francis Drexel emigrated from Europe to Philadelphia in 1817. After she began broadcasting from Nazi Germany during wartime, at least one American syndicated columnist speculated that “Drexel” was a [[pseudonym]].<ref>Baukhage, "Washington Digest: Imperial Hopes may Linger but Where will Nazis Flee?", ''Rock Valley (IA) Bee'', September 19, 1944; page 3.</ref>
Published information regarding her age and date of birth is also wildly inconsistent.<ref name=calling/><ref name=arrest/> Historian John Carver Edwards has concluded Drexel was born in [[Darmstadt, Germany]] on November 28, 1894, to Theodore Drexel, scion of a wealthy family in [[Frankfurt]], Germany, and Zelda Audemar Drexel, daughter of a prominent Swiss watch manufacturer, and was brought to the United States by her father the following year.<ref name=calling/>
However, all five of the ship manifests in Ellis Island records documenting her re-entry into the Port of New York between 1905 and 1923 give an age commensurate with birth in the 1880s.<ref>[http://www.ellisisland.org/search/matchMore.asp?MID=04146261940936556416&FNM=CONSTANCE&LNM=DREXEL&PLNM=DREXEL&first_kind=1&kind=exact&offset=0&dwpdone=1 Ellis Island Passenger Ship Database, search results for Constance Drexel]; accessed March 7, 2009.</ref>
A U.S. Department of Justice internal memorandum prepared in 1946 described her birth date as November 24, 1884.<ref name=fbimemo>[http://www.justice.gov/criminal/foia/records/ezra-pound-p4.pdf Office Memorandum from Nathan T. Elliff to Assistant Attorney General Theron L. Caudle re: Treason Cases], June 14, 1946; accessed October 10, 2010.</ref>
Drexel became a [[United States citizen]] upon her father’s naturalization in 1899.<ref name=calling/><ref name=fbi/> She reported to the FBI in 1918 that she had a sister named Norma Georgia Drexel, then living in Switzerland.<ref name=fbi/> Constance grew up not in Philadelphia, but in [[Roslindale, Massachusetts]], where she attended public schools. "As an adolescent she divided her time between the United States and Europe, attending school in four different countries and honing her skills as a writer", completing her education at the [[Sorbonne]] in [[Paris, France]].<ref name=calling/>
==World War I== Miss Drexel first received national publicity in early 1915, when American newspapers began to report that “Philadelphia Heiress” Constance Drexel had volunteered briefly as a [[Red Cross]] nurse near the front lines in France in the early months of World War I, and reported on her experiences.<ref name=heiress>"Heiress Helps Cause", ''The Washington Post'', January 30, 1915, at page 4</ref><ref>''Philadelphia Evening Public Ledger'', February 8, 1915, at page 16.</ref><ref>[http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045211/1915-02-08/ed-1/seq-16 Portrait of Constance Drexel], chroniclingamerica.loc.gov, ''Philadelphia Evening Public Ledger'', February 8, 1915; accessed January 29, 2018.</ref>
She became active nationally and internationally in the International Woman's Congress, which met at [[The Hague]] in the neutral [[Netherlands]], in April 1915. When she agreed to write dispatches regarding the Congress for American newspapers to publish, her career as a professional journalist began.<ref name=calling/>
She soon joined the staff of the ''[[Public Ledger (Philadelphia)|Philadelphia Public Ledger]]''. When her stories expanded to include not just her experiences but also her opinions, reactions were mixed. In one such article, she wrote "[one] must realize that an increase in horrors hastens the end of the war; so in the long run it's the most humane thing to have no relief funds or nurses. That's why I left the Red Cross".<ref>"Red Cross Nurses Prolong the War: So Declares a Girl who is Tired of Her Job", ''The Fort Wayne News'', September 14, 1915; page 9.</ref>
A ''[[Chicago Herald-Examiner|Chicago Herald]]'' editorial entitled “Horrible Logic” observed that her statement went far to confirm “that, when once moved to cruelty, women are infinitely more cruel than men.”<ref name=chicago>Editorial in the Chicago Herald entitled “Horrible Logic”, reprinted in the ''Newark Advocate'', September 18, 1915, at page 4.</ref> In another column, she opined that "perhaps the greatest curse of war" was "the effect of the loss of men on women and on the race". She explained that the most "harrowing sight in all of war-ridden Europe today" was "the spectacle of the young girls who must always live unmated, robbed of their birthright".<ref name=oakland/> "Her writings suggested an enthusiasm for Germany's preparedness campaign, and especially women's role in that effort", according to Edwards.<ref name=calling/> She became involved in the women's [[suffrage]] movement,<ref name=heiress/> and, in 1916, as a campaigner for the re-election of [[Woodrow Wilson]].<ref name=ohio/>
After the United States declared war on the [[German Empire]], she attempted to return to Europe with the announced purpose of visiting her ailing sister in [[Switzerland]], but a complaint from a colleague at the ''Public Ledger'' who alleged she had made pro-German comments led to a federal investigation.<ref name=fbi/> Her editors attested to her loyalty, but in part because of her German birth and her pacifism, the investigating agent concluded that she should not be permitted to use her passport.<ref name=fbi/>
==Covering the Paris Conference, Congress and the League of Nations== She returned to Europe soon after the end of the war, first to cover the [[Paris Peace Conference, 1919|Paris Peace Conference]] and then to cover and participate in the conference of the International Conference of Women and [[International Woman Suffrage Alliance]] (which succeeded in obtaining a woman’s equality clause in the Covenant of the [[League of Nations]]).<ref name=calling/>
Returning to the United States, she covered the suffrage campaign, and when women won the right to vote, she became one of [[Capitol Hill]]'s few women political correspondents.<ref name=calling/><ref name=sally/>
Her readership peaked in the 1920s, when her columns on the status of women around the world, and interviews with world leaders, were published in many newspapers, including not only the ''Public Ledger'' but also the ''Chicago Tribune'', ''The New York Times'',<ref>Constance Drexel, [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1924/06/01/101600498.pdf "Women to be a Force at Party Conventions"], ''The New York Times'', June 1, 1924.</ref><ref>[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1924/07/27/101606523.pdf "Parliament Gives Heed Now to its Women Members"], ''The New York Times'', July 27, 1924.</ref><ref>[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1925/01/04/101630455.pdf Woman's Status Highest in America"], ''The New York Times'', January 4, 1925.</ref> and members of the McClure Syndicate.<ref name=calling/>
==Interest in Nazi Germany== By the early 1930s she achieved a “growing stature among the press corps and certain political circles,” on issues such as international [[arms control]] and world peace.<ref name=calling/>
Ironically, her interest in those issues did not prevent her from becoming enamored with the rise of [[Adolf Hitler]] and the [[Nazi]] movement in Germany. Edwards concluded that she liked Hitler because she was impressed by his support for other aspects of her “reform agenda,″ including a greater role for women, the eradication of a parasitic social elite, welfare legislation for minors, and [[eugenics|social hygiene regulatory laws]].<ref name=calling/> "Drexel eagerly anticipated visits to the new Reich, and on several of these working holidays the Propaganda Ministry awarded her writing assignments."<ref name=calling/>
In 1938, she became employed in Philadelphia in the [[Works Progress Administration]] (WPA) [[Federal Writers' Project]] and, later, as an instructor of French on the WPA Education Project, when her writing made at least one journalist question whether she had already become a Nazi propagandist.<ref name=calling/>
==Berlin-based correspondent== Drexel returned to Germany in 1939, officially to care for her ailing mother in [[Wiesbaden, Germany]], but travelling at the expense of the German government.<ref name=calling/> In the months leading to Hitler’s invasion of [[Poland]] in September 1939, Drexel wrote feature stories for American newspapers that were ostensibly about the home life of ordinary Germans, but that consistently reflected positively on the Nazi regime and negatively on its future adversaries.<ref name=coffee/><ref name=onions>Constance Drexel, "German Government Diverts Onions to Munitions Channels", ''[[Oakland Tribune]]'', July 30, 1939, at page 9-B.</ref>
For example, six weeks before the outbreak of war, she wrote in the ''[[Oakland Tribune]]'' that the [[Anschluss|annexation of Austria]] had prevented the Viennese population from starving; even though this was "[r]endered more difficult by the [[United States]] sudden boycott of manufactured goods from the annexed territories ... now that the peculiar genius of the North Germans for organization and efficient administration is in full play under the new regime, this and other problems with which they are harassed are being overcome."<ref name=onions/>
For a few months after World War II began, she wrote more feature articles about life in Germany that appeared in ''[[The New York Times]]''.<ref>Constance Drexel, "Women in Three Lands at War: the Home Fronts in Britain, France, and Germany", ''The New York Times'', October 8, 1939.</ref><ref>"Many Changes Made by War in German Schools", ''The New York Times'', December 24, 1939.</ref>
But by that stage of her career, her colleagues in the American press corps had little respect for the quality or integrity of her work. One American network hired her at the beginning of the war, but dropped her almost at once.<ref name=shirerd>William L. Shirer, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=ExOVUEzmCo8C&pg=PA529&dq=constance+drexel&hl=en&ei=CLNUTNDFFsuVnAealrX8Ag&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAjgK#v=onepage&q=constance%20drexel&f=false Berlin Diary]'' (1941), Johns Hopkins University Press (pg 529); {{ISBN|0-8018-7056-9}}</ref>
She had constantly pestered Berlin-based [[CBS radio]] correspondent [[William L. Shirer]] for a job, but as he later explained, he had considered her "the worst broadcaster I ever heard".<ref name=shirer1>William L. Shirer, "William L. Shirer Reviews – Parade of American Turncoats", ''Nebraska State Journal'', February 14, 1943, at page D5.</ref>
In 1940, she began broadcasting on Nazi-controlled shortwave radio channels.<ref name=calling/> She was introduced to listeners as a “world-renowned journalist and a member of the famous Drexel family of Philadelphia.”<ref>William Wilson, "Six Americans Broadcasting for Axis to be Indicted for Treason", ''Lowell Sun'', January 13, 1943, at page 1.</ref>
According to M. Williams Fuller, "[s]ounding like a grand dame with a stuffy nose, she described Germany as a cornucopia – a land of plenty destined for a glorious future. Her broadcasts concluded with titillating accounts of Germany's art exhibits, concerts, food surplus, haute couture and world-class entertainment."<ref name=sally/> Shirer's September 26, 1940 entry in his "''[[Berlin Diary]]''" notes that "the Nazis hire her, as far as I can find out, principally because she's the only woman in town who will sell her American accent to them."<ref name=shirerd/>
When applying (through Swiss authorities) for an extension of her U.S. passport in November 1942, she stated that "[i]n speaking for the German radio, I am following my own ideas; I am not [a] speaker about political or military matters but reporting cultural activities such as activities in the theatre, music and the film."<ref name=fbimemo/>
Drexel soon fell from grace among her new colleagues, and top Nazis began avoiding her.<ref name=spy>[[William B. Breuer]], '''The Air Raid Warden was a Spy and other tales from Home-Front America in World War II'' pg. 133, John Wiley & Sons, Inc. (2003); {{ISBN|0-471-23488-5}}</ref>
Long after the war, it was reported that she had committed a faux pas while attending a reception for Nazi Party leaders. "On being introduced to a beautiful young German woman, Drexel blurted: 'oh, you are the girlfriend of Adolf Hitler!'"<ref name=spy/> As Propaganda Ministry official Inge Doman later testified in the treason trial of [[Mildred Gillars]], known as "[[Axis Sally]]", Doman warned Gillars "to keep your distance from that Drexel woman. She's a pest and a crackpot."<ref name=sally/>
==Indictment, arrest, and release== On October 1, 1942, President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] sent a memo to [[U.S. Attorney General]] [[Francis Biddle]] that stated in part, ''"There are a number of Americans in Europe who are aiding Hitler et al on the radio. Why should we not proceed to indict them for treason even though we might not be able to try them until after the war?"''<ref name=whmemo>[http://www.justice.gov/criminal/foia/records/ezra-pound-p1.pdf October 1, 1942, Memo from the White House (signed F.D.R.) to the Office of the Attorney General]; accessed October 10, 2010.</ref>
A Federal Bureau of Investigation review of excerpts of such broadcasts stated that Drexel was attempting to show that the war had not lowered the morale of the German people in an effort to discourage the American people from continuing with the war effort.<ref name=whmemo/> In July 1943, the [[United States Department of Justice]] filed treason charges against Drexel and seven other United States citizens who had been broadcasting from Axis-controlled radio stations.<ref name=indict/>
On August 17, 1945, over three months after the war in Europe had ended, she was arrested in Vienna by American forces after she revealed her identity to a [[Stars and Stripes (newspaper)|Stars and Stripes]] reporter on a walk behind the Vienna City Hall.<ref name=arrest/><ref name=downey>"Capt. Downey of Pittsfield Arrests Two Americans Indicted for Treason", ''Berkshire Evening Eagle'', August 21, 1945, at page 1.</ref>
Wearing an American flag lapel pin, she claimed she had always been a loyal citizen, and had only broadcast on cultural questions.<ref name=downey/> At the time of her arrest, her age was listed as 60 (in one newspaper)<ref name=arrest/> and almost 70 (in another).<ref name=downey/>
Drexel was detained for over a year before she was transferred to [[Ellis Island]] in [[New York Harbor]], pending an October 1946 hearing by a board of inquiry of the [[U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service]], on her eligibility to re-enter the United States.<ref>"Miss Drexel Held at Ellis As Treasonist", ''Berkshire Evening Eagle'', October 1, 1946, at page 14.</ref> On October 3, 1946, the board decided that she had not forfeited her citizenship, and allowed her to re-enter the country.<ref name=freed/>
At the time of her release and re-entry, the United States Department of Justice said that her prosecution on the treason charges was no longer contemplated because lawyers who went to Germany to seek further evidence against her failed to uncover any.<ref name=freed/> An internal Department of Justice memorandum dated June 14, 1946, repeats information from the [[Office of Strategic Services]] that she "was stranded in Germany and since she needed money she found a job with the American Propaganda Section of the Reichrundfunk" but that her twice-weekly broadcasts dealt "mainly with women, children, and the beauties of the German landscape."<ref name=fbimemo/> The memo recommended taking no further action against her.<ref name=fbimemo/>
[[Walter Winchell]] and others were still urging prosecution and stiff sentences for the Berlin broadcasters.<ref>Walter Winchell, "Case Histories of Nazi Stooges Who Played Judas to Uncle Sam", ''Syracuse Herald Journal'', November 12, 1947, at page 39.</ref> When the charges were formally dropped on April 14, 1948, the investigators explained that none of Drexel's broadcasts was "political in nature".<ref name=dismiss/><ref>[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1948/04/14/96423582.pdf "Constance Drexel Freed of Charges"], ''The New York Times'', April 14, 1948.</ref>
==Death== Drexel died in [[Waterbury, Connecticut]], on August 28, 1956.<ref name=obit>“[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1956/08/29/91149178.pdf "Constance Drexel, Ex-newswoman, Dies; Broadcast for the Nazis During War"], ''The New York Times'', August 29, 1956.</ref> She collapsed at the home of a cousin before leaving on the first leg of a trip to Geneva, Switzerland, where she intended to move.<ref name=obit2>"Constance Drexel, 68; Broadcast for Nazis", ''Berkshire Eagle'', August 29, 1956, at page 20.</ref> The obituaries listed her age as 68.<ref name=obit/><ref name=obit2/>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://courtroombattles.blogspot.com/2007/12/aftermath-of-war-part-2.html Courtroom Battle of World War II (Part 1 of 3).] contains information on the careers and fates of some of the Nazi broadcasters and other collaborators. *[http://courtroombattles.blogspot.com/2007/12/werner-best.html Courtroom Battles of World War II (Part 2 of 3).] *[http://courtroombattles.blogspot.com/2007/12/terboven.html Courtroom Battles of World War II (Part 3 of 3).]

{{hatnote|This article is about the biblical genealogy of Christ. For the article about claims to a genealogical descent from the historical Jesus, see [[Jesus bloodline]].}} {{Jesus|expanded=background}}[[File:St Denis transept south.jpg|thumb|270px|Rose window in [[Basilica of St Denis]], France, depicting the ancestors of Jesus from Jesse onwards]] The [[New Testament]] provides two accounts of the '''genealogy of Jesus''', one in the [[Gospel of Matthew]] and another in the [[Gospel of Luke]].{{bibleref2|Matthew|1:1–16}}; {{bibleref2|Luke|3:23–38}} Matthew starts with [[Abraham]], while Luke begins with [[Adam]]. The lists are identical between Abraham and [[David]], but differ radically from that point. Matthew has twenty-seven generations from David to [[Joseph]], whereas Luke has forty-two, with almost no overlap between the names on the two lists.⁠ Notably, the two accounts also disagree on who Joseph's father was: Matthew says he was Jacob, while Luke says he was Heli.{{bibleverse|Matthew|1:16}}; {{bibleverse|Luke|3:23}} Traditional Christian scholars (starting with the historian [[Eusebius]]Eusebius Pamphilius, ''Church history, Life of Constantine'' §VII.) have put forward various theories that seek to explain why the lineages are so different,R. T. France, ''The Gospel According to Matthew: An Introduction and Commentary'' (Eerdmans, 1985) page 71-72. such as that Matthew's account follows the lineage of Joseph, while Luke's follows the lineage of Mary. Some modern critical scholars like [[Marcus Borg]] and [[John Dominic Crossan]] claim both genealogies as inventions, to bring the Messianic claims into conformity with Jewish criteria.Marcus J. Borg, John Dominic Crossan, The First Christmas (HarperCollins, 2009) page 95. ==Matthew's genealogy== [[File:Genealogy of Jesus mosaic at Chora (1).jpg|thumb|South dome of inner narthex at [[Chora Church]], Istanbul, depicting the ancestors of Christ from Adam onwards]] [[File:JesseTree.jpg|right|thumb|upright|Patrilineage in Matthew was traditionally illustrated by a [[Tree of Jesse]] showing the descent of Jesus from [[Jesse]], father of King [[David]]]] Matthew 1:1–17 begins the Gospel, "A record of the origin of Jesus Christ, the son of David, the son of Abraham: Abraham begot Isaac…" and continues on until "…and Jacob begot Joseph, the husband of Mary, of whom was born Jesus, who is called Christ. Thus there were fourteen generations in all from Abraham to David, fourteen from David to the [[Babylonian captivity|exile to Babylon]], and fourteen from the exile to the Christ." Matthew emphasizes, right from the beginning, Jesus' title ''[[Christ (title)|Christ]]''—the Greek rendering of the Hebrew title ''[[Messiah]]''—meaning ''anointed'', in the sense of an anointed king. Jesus is presented as the long-awaited Messiah, who was expected to be a descendant of King David. Matthew begins by calling Jesus ''the son of David'', indicating his royal origin, and also ''son of Abraham'', indicating that he was an Israelite; both are stock phrases, in which ''son'' means ''descendant'', calling to mind the promises God made to David and to Abraham.{{citation |last=Nolland |first=John |year=2005 |title=The Gospel of Matthew: a commentary on the Greek text |pages=65–87 |isbn=978-0-8028-2389-2 |publisher=W. B. Eerdmans |location=Grand Rapids}} Matthew's introductory title ({{lang|grc|βίβλος γενέσεως}}, ''book of generations'') has been interpreted in various ways, but most likely is simply a title for the genealogy that follows, echoing the [[Septuagint]] use of the same phrase for genealogies. {| class="wikitable" style="margin:1em auto 1em auto; page-break-inside:avoid" |+ '''Patrilineage of Jesus according to [[Gospel of Matthew|Matthew]]''' |- valign="top" | style="border:none;"|

|} [[File:Hortus Deliciarum, Der Stammbaum Christi.JPG|thumb|upright|[[Tree of Jesse]] illustration based on the ''[[Hortus deliciarum]]'' of [[Herrad of Landsberg]] (12th century)]] Matthew's genealogy is considerably more complex than Luke's. It is overtly schematic, organized into three [[tesseradecads]] (sets of fourteen), each of a distinct character: *The first is rich in annotations, including four mothers and mentioning the brothers of Judah and the brother [[Zerah]] of Perez. *The second spans the [[Davidic line|Davidic royal line]], but omits several generations, ending with "Jeconiah and his brothers at the time of the exile to Babylon." *The last, which appears to span only thirteen generations, connects Joseph to Zerubbabel through a series of otherwise unknown names, remarkably few for such a long period. The total of 42 generations is achieved only by omitting several names, so the choice of three sets of fourteen seems deliberate. Various explanations have been suggested: fourteen is twice [[7 (number)#Judaism|seven]], symbolizing perfection and covenant, and is also the [[gematria]] (numerical value) of the name ''[[David (name)|David]]''. The rendering into Greek of Hebrew names in this genealogy is mostly in accord with the Septuagint, but there are a few peculiarities. The form ''Asaph'' seems to identify King Asa with the psalmist [[Psalms of Asaph|Asaph]]. Likewise, some see the form ''Amos'' for King Amon as suggesting the prophet [[Amos (prophet)|Amos]], though the Septuagint does have this form. Both may simply be assimilations to more familiar names. More interesting, though, are the unique forms ''Boes'' (Boaz, LXX ''Boos'') and ''Rachab'' (Rahab, LXX ''Raab'').{{citation |last=Bauckham |first=Richard |authorlink=Richard Bauckham |title=Tamar's Ancestry and Rahab's Marriage: Two Problems in the Matthean Genealogy |journal=Novum Testamentum |volume=37 |year=1995 |pages=313–329 |doi=10.1163/1568536952663168 |postscript=. |issue=4}} ===Omissions=== {| class="wikitable" style="margin:1em; float:right;" |+ Omission of generations |- style="vertical-align:bottom;" ! style="width:50%;"|Old Testament{{bibleverse|1Chronicles|3:4-19|NIV}}!! style="width:50%;"|Matthew |- |

|} Three consecutive kings of Judah are omitted: [[Ahaziah of Judah|Ahaziah]], [[Jehoash of Judah|Jehoash]], and [[Amaziah of Judah|Amaziah]]. These three kings are seen as especially wicked, from the cursed line of [[Ahab]] through his daughter [[Athaliah]] to the third and fourth generation.{{bibleverse|1Kings|21:21-29|NIV}}; cf. {{bibleverse|Exodus|20:5|NIV}}, {{bibleverse|Deuteronomy|29:20|NIV}}. The author could have omitted them to create a second set of fourteen.{{citation |last=Nolland |first=John |title=Jechoniah and His Brothers |journal=[[Bulletin for Biblical Research]] |volume=7 |year=1997 |pages=169–178 |url=http://www.biblicalstudies.org.uk/pdf/genealogy_nolland.pdf}} Another omitted king is [[Jehoiakim]], the father of [[Jeconiah]], also known as Jehoiachin. In Greek the names are even more similar, both being sometimes called ''Joachim''. When Matthew says, "Josiah begot Jeconiah and his brothers at the time of the exile," he appears to conflate the two, because Jehoiakim, not Jeconiah, had brothers, but the exile was in the time of Jeconiah. While some see this as a mistake, others argue that the omission was once again deliberate, ensuring that the kings after David spanned exactly fourteen generations. The final group also contains fourteen generations. If Josiah's son was intended as Jehoiakim, then Jeconiah could be counted separately after the exile. Mary is counted as a generation, proceeding from her father, Joseph. Though such a reckoning is otherwise little known or understood, it fits with the fourteen generations. Otherwise, it confuses the father of Mary with the husband of Mary.{{citation |title=Dictionary of Jesus and the Gospels: A Compendium of Contemporary Biblical Scholarship |date=February 18, 1992 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9ntwNm-tOogC&pg=PA254#v=snippet&q=%22Matthew%20begins%20his%20Gospel%22&f=false |editors=Joel B. Green, Scot McKnight, & I. Howard Marshall|publisher=InterVarsity Press|isbn=0-8308-1777-8|pages=254–259}} Some have even proposed that Matthew's original text had one Joseph as the {{em|father}} of Mary, who then married another man of the same name.{{citation |last=Blair |first=Harold A. |title=Matthew 1,16 and the Matthaean Genealogy |journal=Studia Evangelica |volume=2 |year=1964 |pages=149–154}} Fourteen generations span the time from [[Jeconiah]], born about 616 BC, to Jesus, born circa 3 BC.{{Citation|title=Jesus Christ Our Passover|author=Dr. V. P. Wierwille}} The average generation gap would be around forty-four years. However, in the [[Old Testament]], there are even wider gaps between generations.For example, Ezra's, {{bibleverse|Ezra|7:1-5|NIV}} (cf. {{bibleverse|1Chronicles|6:3-14|NIV}}). Also, we do not see any instances of [[papponymic]] naming patterns, where children are named after their grandparents, which was a common custom throughout this period. This may indicate that Matthew has telescoped this segment by collapsing such repetitions.{{citation |last=Albright |first=William F. |authorlink= William F. Albright |last2=Mann |first2=C. S. |lastauthoramp=yes |title= Matthew: A New Translation with Introduction and Commentary |series=[[The Anchor Bible Series|The Anchor Bible]] |volume=26 |place=New York |publisher=Doubleday & Company |year=1971 |isbn=978-0-385-08658-5}} ==Luke's genealogy== [[File:KellsFol200rGeneolgyOfChrist.jpg|right|thumb|Luke's genealogy of Jesus, from the [[Book of Kells]], transcribed by [[Celtic Christianity|Celtic]] [[monk]]s c. 800]] In the Gospel of Luke, the genealogy appears at the beginning of the public life of Jesus. This version is in ascending order from Joseph to Adam.Maas, Anthony. [http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/06410a.htm "Genealogy of Christ"] The Catholic Encyclopedia. Vol. 6. New York: Robert Appleton Company, 1909. 9 Oct. 2013 After telling of the baptism of Jesus, {{bibleref2|Luke|3:23–38|9}} states, "Jesus himself began to be about thirty years of age, being (as was supposed) the son of Joseph, which was ''[the son]'' of Heli, ..." (3:23) and continues on until "Adam, which was ''[the son]'' of God." (3:38) The Greek text of Luke's Gospel does not use the word "son" in the genealogy after "son of Joseph". Robertson notes that, in the Greek, "Luke has the article ''tou'' repeating ''uiou'' (Son) except before Joseph". {| class="wikitable" style="margin:1em auto 1em auto; page-break-inside:avoid" |+ '''Patrilineage of Jesus according to [[Gospel of Luke|Luke]]''' |- valign="top" | style="border:none;"|

|} This genealogy descends from the [[Davidic line]] through [[Nathan (son of David)|Nathan]], who is an otherwise little-known son of David, mentioned briefly in the Old Testament.{{bibleverse|1Chronicles|3:5|NIV}}; but also see {{bibleverse|Zechariah|12:12|NIV}}. In the ancestry of David, Luke agrees completely with the Old Testament. [[Cainan]] is included between Shelah and Arphaxad, following the [[Septuagint]] text (though not included in the [[Masoretic text]] followed by most modern Bibles). [[Augustine of Hippo|Augustine]]{{citation |author=Augustine of Hippo|authorlink=Augustine of Hippo |title=De consensu evangelistarum (On the Harmony of the Gospels) |date=c. 400 |pages=[http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/npnf106.vi.v.v.html 2.4.12–13]}} notes that the count of generations in the Book of Luke is 77, a number symbolizing the forgiveness of all sins.{{bibleverse|Matthew|18:21-22|NIV}}; cf. {{bibleverse|Genesis|4:24|NIV}}. This count also agrees with the seventy generations from [[Enoch (ancestor of Noah)|Enoch]][http://www.ccel.org/c/charles/otpseudepig/enoch/ENOCH_1.HTM#10_12 1 Enoch 10:11–12]. set forth in the [[Book of Enoch]], which Luke probably knew.{{citation |last=Bauckham |first=Richard |authorlink=Richard Bauckham |title=Jude and the Relatives of Jesus in the Early Church |year=2004 |pages=315–373 |isbn=978-0-567-08297-8 |publisher=T & T Clark International |location=London}} Though Luke never counts the generations as Matthew does, it appears he also followed [[Archon#Hebdomad|hebdomad]]ic principle of working in sevens. However, [[Irenaeus]] counts only 72 generations from Adam.{{citation |author=Irenaeus |authorlink=Irenaeus |title=[[On the Detection and Overthrow of the So-Called Gnosis|Adversus haereses]] ("Against Heresies") |page=[http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/anf01.ix.iv.xxiii.html#ix.iv.xxiii–p10 3.22.3]}} The reading "son of Aminadab, son of Aram," from the Old Testament is well attested. The [[Nestle-Aland]] critical edition, considered the best authority by most modern scholars, accepts the variant "son of Aminadab, son of Admin, son of Arni,"{{citation |last=Willker |first=Wieland |url=http://www-user.uni-bremen.de/~wie/TCG/TC-Luke.pdf |title=A Textual Commentary on the Greek Gospels |volume=vol. 3: Luke |page=TVU 39 |year=2009 |edition=6th |accessdate=2009-03-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090327165542/http://www-user.uni-bremen.de/~wie/TCG/TC-Luke.pdf |archivedate=27 March 2009 |df=dmy-all }}. Willker details the textual evidence underlying the NA27 reading. counting the 76 generations from Adam rather than God."Faced with a bewildering variety of readings, the Committee adopted what seems to be the least unsatisfactory form of text, a reading that was current in the Alexandrian church at an early period," explains {{citation |last=Metzger |first=Bruce Manning |title=A textual commentary on the Greek New Testament |year=1971 |edition=2nd |publisher=United Bible Societies |page=136 |isbn=3-438-06010-8}} Luke's qualification "as was supposed" ({{lang|grc|ἐνομίζετο}}) avoids stating that Jesus was actually a son of Joseph, since [[Virgin birth of Jesus|his virgin birth]] is affirmed in the same gospel. From as early as [[John of Damascus]], the view of "as was supposed of Joseph" regards Luke as calling Jesus a son of Eli—meaning that [[Heli (Bible)|Heli]] ({{lang|grc|Ἠλί}}, Heli) was the maternal grandfather of Jesus, with Luke tracing the ancestry of Jesus through Mary.{{citation |last=Schaff |first=Philip |title=The Gospel According to Matthew |year=1882 |pages=4–5 |place=New York |publisher=Charles Scribner's Sons |isbn=0-8370-9740-1}} Therefore per [[Adam Clarke]] (1817), [[John Wesley]], [[John Kitto]] and others the expression "Joseph, [ ] of Heli", without the word "son" being present in the Greek, indicates that "Joseph, of Heli" is to be read "Joseph, [son-in-law] of Heli". There are, however, other interpretations of how this qualification relates to the rest of the genealogy. Some see the remainder as the true genealogy of Joseph, despite the different genealogy given in Matthew.{{citation |last=Farrar |first=F.W. |title=The Gospel According to St. Luke |year=1892 |pages=369–375 |place=Cambridge}} ==Comparison of the two genealogies== The following table is a side-by-side comparison of Matthew's and Luke's genealogies.
