[[Zentatsu Richard Baker]] |reincarnation of = |predecessor = |successor = Steven Allen |students = |spouse = |partner = |children = |website = }} '''Issan Dorsey''' (March 7, 1933 — September 6, 1990), born '''Tommy Dorsey, Jr.''', was a [[Sōtō]] [[Zen]] monk and teacher, Dharma heir of [[Zentatsu Richard Baker]] and onetime abbot of [[Hartford Street Zen Center]] (HSZC) located in the [[Castro district]] of [[San Francisco, California]]. Earlier in his life he had worked as a prostitute and a [[drag queen]], and had struggled at times with drug addiction. He died of complications from [[AIDS]] in 1990. He established the Maitri Hospice at HSZC for students and friends dying of AIDS during the spread of the epidemic in the 1980s—the first [[Buddhist]] [[hospice]] of its kind in the [[United States]]. Numbers of his students and colleagues have observed that Dorsey was the embodiment of a [[bodhisattva]].{{cite web| last =Whitney| first =Kobai Scott| authorlink =| title =The Lone Mountain Path: The Example of Issan Dorsey| work =| publisher =Shambhala Sun| date =March 1998| url =http://www.shambhalasun.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1980| format =| doi =| accessdate = 2008-03-02}} ==Biography== [[File:Hartford Street Zen Center.jpg|thumb|left|200px|[[Hartford Street Zen Center]]]] Issan Dorsey was born as Tommy Dorsey, Jr. in [[Santa Barbara, California]] in 1933.{{cite book| last =Comstock| first =Gary| authorlink =|author2=Susan E. Henking| title =Que(e)Rying Religion: A Critical Anthology| publisher =Continuum International Publishing Group| year =1997| location =| pages =251–252| url =http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/35178597&referer=brief_results| doi =| id = | isbn = 0-8264-0924-5}} He was raised as a [[Catholic]] and was the youngest child of ten siblings. As a boy he aspired to become an entertainer and studied [[dance]] and [[piano]]. While in [[junior college]] he became dissatisfied with his life, so he left school and joined the [[U.S. Navy]]. In the military he was able to fulfill his childhood dream of being an entertainer, putting on shows at his base and on [[television]] shows. During the [[Korean War]] Dorsey and a male lover were expelled from the Navy, leaving him to spend several years in and out of employment. He finally settled into a job as a [[waiter]] for a [[bar (establishment)|bar]] in [[North Beach, San Francisco, California|North Beach]], eventually becoming a performer there as a [[drag queen]]. His shows were a success and he traveled in a road show known as The Party of Four. On the road in the 1950s he would sometimes work as a [[prostitute]] at shows and afterhours, developing a nasty [[methamphetamine]] addiction during this period. On the road during his shows Dorsey was introduced as, "Tommy Dee, the boy who looks like the girl next door." In the 1960s he returned to [[San Francisco]], where he continued to shoot speed and engaged in dealing drugs on lower [[Haight Street]]. He founded his own [[Commune (intentional community)|commune]] and also managed a [[rock band]]. During this period he had a spiritual experience under the influence of [[LSD]] while observing a photograph of Ramana [[Maharshi]]. He constructed an [[altar]] with Maharshi's photograph, where he would shoot speed and gaze at the picture for several hours. Soon, he gave up using drugs and started sitting [[zazen]] at the [[San Francisco Zen Center]] (SFZC) under the guidance of [[Shunryu Suzuki]].{{cite book| last =Butler| first =Katy| authorlink =| title =Street Zen (book review)| publisher =Whole Earth Review| date =Spring 1994| location =| pages =| url =http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1510/is_n82/ai_15297800| doi =| id = | isbn = }} In 1980 (while Dorsey was director of SFZC) he became a member of The Gay Buddhist Club, which eventually became known as the [[Hartford Street Zen Center]] (HSZC).{{cite book| last =Coleman| first =James William| authorlink =| title =The New Buddhism: The Western Transformation of an Ancient Tradition| publisher =Oxford University Press| year =2001| location =| pages =165| url =http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/48932003&referer=one_hit| doi =| id = | isbn = 0-19-515241-7}} Originally a discussion group for [[gay]] Buddhists, the group eventually began sitting [[zazen]] in the basement of one member's house at 57 Hartford Street. In 1987[http://hszc.org/about/history-of-hszc/ History of HSZC] Dorsey had created a [[hospice]] (Maitri Hospice) within the Zen center on Hartford Street, serving primarily gay men who were dying of [[AIDS]]. Eventually Dorsey was made a [[Sōtō]] priest by his teacher—[[Zentatsu Richard Baker]]—installed as abbot of HSZC in 1989 and given the [[Dharma name]] Issan (meaning "One-Mountain"). Shortly before death, in particularly poor health, Issan was recognized as a [[Rōshi|roshi]].{{cite book| last =Halifax, Joan| first =| authorlink =Joan Halifax| title =Buddhism in America: Volume 1 (Audio)| publisher =[[Sounds True]]| year =2000| location =| pages =| url =http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/46867277&referer=one_hit| doi =| id = | isbn = 1-56455-816-9}} On September 6, 1990, Issan Dorsey died of complications linked to [[AIDS]]. ==See also== *[[Buddhism in the United States]] *[[Buddhism and sexual orientation]] *[[Timeline of Zen Buddhism in the United States]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== {{cite book| last =Schneider| first =David| authorlink =| title =Street Zen: The Life and Work of Issan Dorsey| publisher =Marlowe & Company| year =2000| location =| pages =| url =http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/43390506&referer=one_hit| doi =| id = | isbn = 1-56924-637-8}} {{Buddhism topics}} {{Modern Buddhist writers}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dorsey, Issan}} [[Category:1933 births]] [[Category:1990 deaths]] [[Category:HIV/AIDS activists]] [[Category:AIDS-related deaths in California]] [[Category:American drag queens]] [[Category:American health activists]] [[Category:American male prostitutes]] [[Category:American Zen Buddhists]] [[Category:Buddhism in San Francisco]] [[Category:LGBT clergy]] [[Category:LGBT Buddhists]] [[Category:San Francisco Zen Center]] [[Category:Soto Zen Buddhists]] [[Category:Zen Buddhist monks and priests]] [[Category:Activists from the San Francisco Bay Area]] [[Category:LGBT people from California]] [[Category:Religious leaders from the San Francisco Bay Area]]

[[File:Ivan Caryll.jpg|right|250px|thumb|Ivan Caryll]] '''Félix Marie Henri Tilkin'''<ref>{{Cite book|last = Gänzl|first = Kurt|contribution=Ivan Caryll|year=2001 |title=The Encyclopedia of the Musical Theatre, Second Edition |pages = 327 |publisher = Schirmer Books |isbn = 0-02-864970-2}}</ref> (12 May 1861 – 29 November 1921), better known by his pen name '''Ivan Caryll''', was a Belgian composer of [[operetta]]s and [[Edwardian musical comedies]] in the English language. He composed (or contributed to) some forty [[Edwardian musical comedies|musical comedies]] and [[operettas]].
Caryll's career encompassed three eras of the musical theatre, and unlike some of his contemporaries, he adapted readily to each new development. After composing a few [[Victorian burlesque|musical burlesques]], his first great successes were made in light musical comedies, epitomised by the [[George Edwardes]] productions at London's [[Gaiety Theatre, London|Gaiety Theatre]], such as ''[[The Shop Girl]]'', ''[[The Circus Girl]]'', ''[[The Gay Parisienne]]'', and ''[[A Runaway Girl]]''. He continued to write musical comedies throughout the next decade, including such hits as ''[[The Messenger Boy]]'', ''[[The Toreador]]'', ''[[The Girl From Kays]]'', ''[[The Earl and the Girl]]'', ''[[The Orchid]]'', ''[[The Spring Chicken]]'', ''[[The Girls of Gottenberg]]'' and ''[[Our Miss Gibbs]]''. He also wrote some [[operetta]] scores, such as ''[[The Duchess of Dantzic]]''. After this, he moved to New York City, where his post-war works, incorporating new [[fox-trot]] and [[one-step]] rhythms, included ''[[The Girl Behind the Gun]]'' (later a London hit as ''[[Kissing Time]]''). At the peak of his career, he had the unparalleled distinction of having five musicals running at the same time in the [[West End theatre|West End]].
==Life and career== Caryll was born in [[Liège]], Belgium, the son of Henry Tilkin, an engineer.<ref name=dnb>Gänzl, Kurt, [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/62430 "Caryll, Ivan (1861–1921)",] ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press, 2004, accessed 12 January 2011 {{subscription}}</ref> He studied at the [[Royal Conservatory of Liège|Liège Conservatoire]], where he was a fellow student of [[Eugène Ysaÿe]]. He then moved to France to study singing at the [[Paris Conservatoire]], where a classmate was [[Rose Caron]].<ref name=chat>"A Chat with Mr. Ivan Caryll", ''Musical Opinion and Music Trade Review'', August 1897, p. 756</ref> He moved to London in 1882. He was married for a time in the 1890s to [[Gilbert and Sullivan]] star [[Geraldine Ulmar]]. Later, he married Maud Hill. He had a daughter named Primrose Caryll, who became an actress.
The dashing, moustachioed Caryll was known as one of the best dressed men in London. He was an extravagant spender and a popular and lavish host, entertaining his theatrical friends in princely style. Caryll's free spending ways caused him trouble occasionally, and he had a few narrow escapes from his creditors.<ref name=Archive>[http://math.boisestate.edu/GaS/other_savoy/lucky_star/caryll.html "Ivan Caryll"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060906071846/http://math.boisestate.edu/gas/other_savoy/lucky_star/caryll.html |date=2006-09-06 }} at The Gilbert and Sullivan Archive's British Musical Theatre pages, 24 December 2003, accessed 11 January 2011</ref>
===Early career=== [[File:Rice's production of the latest London novelty, The girl from Paris written by George Dance ; music by Ivan Caryll. LCCN2014636229.jpg|left|thumb|1897 Poster for ''[[The Gay Parisienne|The Girl from Paris]]'']] At first, Caryll earned a poor living by giving music lessons to women in the suburbs.<ref name=chat/> Then he sold some songs to [[George Edwardes]], who eventually hired him as the musical director for the [[Gaiety Theatre, London|Gaiety]] and [[Lyric Theatre (London)|Lyric]] Theatres. He attempted to raise orchestral standards by banning the deputy system, under which a player who was offered a lucrative engagement could send a substitute to perform in the theatre.<ref name=chat/>
Caryll's first theatre piece was ''Lily of Léoville'' in 1886. He sent the score to [[Camille Saint-Saëns]], who used his influence to have it staged at the [[Théâtre des Bouffes Parisiens|Bouffes Parisiens]].<ref name=chat/> [[Violet Melnotte]] secured the English rights, and it was presented in London featuring a young [[Hayden Coffin]].<ref>[http://www.guidetomusicaltheatre.com/shows_l/lilyleoville.htm Lily of Leoville] at the Guide to Musical Theatre, accessed 29 October 2009</ref> This was followed the same year by ''[[Monte Cristo Jr.]]'', a [[Victorian burlesque|burlesque]] for the Gaiety and then by a number of shows produced for the Lyric, culminating with the very successful ''[[Little Christopher Columbus]]'' (1893). Caryll, known as a very expressive conductor, conducted [[W. S. Gilbert]] and [[Alfred Cellier]]'s ''[[The Mountebanks (opera)|The Mountebanks]]'' at the Lyric in 1892. Cellier died during rehearsals for the piece, and Caryll wrote the overture, the entr'acte, and finished some of the orchestration. His work on the piece received critical praise.<ref>Walker, Raymond J. [http://www.musicweb-international.com/classrev/2018/May/Cellier_mountebanks_2CDLX7349.htm "Alfred Cellier (1844-1891): ''The Mountebanks'', comic opera (1892); and ''Suite Symphonique'' (1878)"], Music Web International, 2018</ref> Also in 1892, with [[George Dance (dramatist)|George Dance]], Caryll adapted an [[opéra comique]] called ''[[Ma mie Rosette]]'', based on a French piece by [[Paul Lacôme]], starring [[Jessie Bond]] and [[Courtice Pounds]] at the Globe Theatre.<ref>Moss, Simon. [http://www.c20th.com/GSarchiveother.htm Programmes and descriptions of 1892 productions of ''Ma mie Rosette'',] ''Gilbert & Sullivan, a selling exhibition of memorabilia, Archive: Other items''</ref><ref>"The Theatres", ''The Times'', 27 December 1892, p. 6</ref> Caryll recalled of this production that he had been much criticised for adding numbers to Lacome's original score, although Lacome had specially requested him to do so.<ref name=chat/>
Caryll's first big success at the Gaiety was ''[[The Shop Girl]]'' (1894), which ran for an almost unprecedented 546 performances and heralded a new form of respectable musical comedy in London. The composer conducted the piece himself. Meanwhile, Caryll also had success elsewhere. ''[[The Gay Parisienne]]'' (1896), written with George Dance, ran for 369 performances at the [[Duke of York's Theatre]], played in New York as ''The Girl from Paris'' (281 performances) and toured internationally. At the same time, he continued to compose shows at other theatres, including the [[comic opera]] ''[[Dandy Dick Whittington]]'' (1895), at the [[Avenue Theatre]], with a libretto by [[George Robert Sims]].<ref>Adams, William Davenport. ''A Dictionary of the Drama: a Guide to the Plays, Playwrights'', Vol. 1, pp. 374–75, Chatto & Windus, 1904</ref>
[[File:Cover of the Vocal Score of Seymour Hicks' The Earl and the Girl.jpg|thumb|Cover of Vocal Score]] [[File:Pinklady1.jpg|thumb|Programme for [[The Pink Lady (musical)|''The Pink Lady'']]]] Caryll composed the music for almost all the Gaiety musical comedies over the next decade, in collaboration with [[Lionel Monckton]], and also established himself as the most famous conductor of light music in England. Edwardes apparently liked to have the word 'girl' in the titles of the shows, so ''[[The Shop Girl]]'' was followed by ''My Girl'', ''[[The Circus Girl]]'' (with over 500 performances in 1896 and 1897) and ''[[A Runaway Girl]]'' (1898). ''[[The Lucky Star]]'' was a less successful three-act [[comic opera]] (1899, produced by the [[D'Oyly Carte Opera Company]], based on ''L'Etoile'', an opéra-bouffe by [[Emmanuel Chabrier]]). It may have been too risqué for the [[Savoy Theatre]] audiences.
Caryll was said to compose very quickly in intense bouts. His scores were noted for swirling waltzes and semi-[[opera]]tic finales. He often took trips to Paris and elsewhere in search of new musical plays that he could adapt into English. Caryll's output also included songs, dances and salon pieces for his own light orchestra, for which [[Edward Elgar]] composed his shapely ''Serenade Lyrique'' in 1899.<ref>[http://www.musicweb-international.com/garlands/97.htm Profile of Caryll from Musicweb International]</ref>
===20th century London pieces=== After the turn of the century, Caryll wrote more successful scores, including ''[[The Messenger Boy]]'' (1900), ''[[The Toreador]]'' (1901) (with well over 600 performances), The Ladies' Paradise (1901) (the first musical comedy to be presented at the [[Metropolitan Opera]] in New York),<ref>[[Andrew Lamb (writer)|Lamb, Andrew]], [http://www.oxfordmusiconline.com/subscriber/article/grove/music/05053 "Caryll, Ivan",] ''Grove Music Online'', Oxford Music Online, accessed 12 January 2011 {{subscription}}; the piece closed quickly and controversially there, with the cast unpaid. See: [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1901/09/29/106920075.pdf "''The Ladies' Paradise'' Ends"]. ''The New York TImes'', 29 September 1901</ref> ''[[The Girl From Kays]]'' (1902), ''[[The Cherry Girl]]'' (1902), ''[[The Earl and the Girl]]'' (1903; another success, starring [[Walter Passmore]] and [[Henry Lytton]]), ''[[The Orchid]]'' (1903), and ''[[The Duchess of Dantzic]]'' (1903), a [[comic opera]] based on the story of Napoleon and Madame Sans-Gêne, the washerwoman who married Marshal Lefebvre and became a duchess.<ref>[http://www.guidetomusicaltheatre.com/shows_d/duchess_of_dantzic.htm Information from the Guide to Musical Theatre]</ref> During the Christmas season of 1903, he had what was at that time the unparalleled distinction of having five musicals running at the same time in the [[West End theatre|West End]].<ref name=dnb/>
Despite these successes, Caryll began to grow jealous of Monckton, who often wrote the most popular numbers in the shows.<ref name=Archive/> Still, they continued to work together, producing several successes: ''[[The Spring Chicken]]'' (1905), ''[[The New Aladdin]]'' (1906), ''[[The Girls of Gottenberg]]'' (1907), and the even more popular ''[[Our Miss Gibbs]]'' (1909), which ran for 636 performances. Typical of the plots of these shows, ''Our Miss Gibbs'' concerns a shop girl, courted by an earl in disguise. During this period, Caryll also wrote the less successful ''The Little Cherub'' (1906).
Many of Caryll's musicals were given in Paris, Vienna, and Budapest at a time when the English-language musicals were largely ignored on the continent, and he composed original scores for Paris (''S.A.R.'', or ''Son altesse royale'', 1908) and Vienna (''Die Reise nach Cuba'', 1901).<ref name=dnb/>
===Broadway musicals=== Caryll relocated to New York City in 1911, composing more than a dozen [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] musicals,<ref>[http://www.musicals101.com/who2.htm#Caryll Brief profile of Caryll at the musicals101 website]</ref> including [[The Pink Lady (musical)|''The Pink Lady'']] (1911, with Hugh Morton), ''Oh! Oh! Delphine!!!'' (1912), ''Chin-Chin'' (1914; including "[[Ragtime]] Temple Bells"),<ref>[https://archive.org/details/chinchinmusicalf00caryl Vocal score of ''Chin-Chin'']</ref><ref>[https://jscholarship.library.jhu.edu/handle/1774.2/26286 Temple Bells sheet music]. The Lester S. Levy Collection of Sheet Music, accessed 2 March 2011</ref> ''Jack o'Lantern'' (1917), and ''[[The Girl Behind the Gun]]'' (1918, with a book by [[P. G. Wodehouse]] and [[Guy Bolton]]; the following year, it was a hit in London as ''[[Kissing Time]]''). According to Wodehouse, Caryll was widely known as "Fabulous Felix", and "lived ''en prince'' ... having apartments in both London and Paris as well as a villa containing five bathrooms overlooking the [[Deauville]] racecourse."<ref>Wodehouse, p. 103</ref> He had just completed the music for ''Little Miss Raffles'' a day before his death.
Caryll died of a haemorrhage in New York at age 60 while rehearsing ''Little Miss Raffles''.<ref>{{cite news|author=|title=Ivan Caryll Dies as he Finishes Play|date=30 November 1921 |work=[[New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1921/11/30/archives/ivan-caryll-dies-as-he-finishes-play-noted-composer-stricken-with.html|page=14|accessdate=2008-08-08}}</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Jay Ruderman | image = Jay Ruderman April 2014.jpg | image_size = | caption = Jay Ruderman (April 2014) | birth_name = Jay Seth Ruderman | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1966|3|16}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Activist and Philanthropist | children = | parents = Morton Edward Ruderman, Marcia Jortner Ruderman | website = [http://www.rudermanfoundation.org www.rudermanfoundation.org] | spouse = {{marriage|Shira Menashe Ruderman|2002}} }} '''Jay Seth Ruderman''' (born 16 March 1966) is an American activist and philanthropist. He is the President of the [[Ruderman Family Foundation]], which focuses on the [[Inclusion (disability rights)|inclusion]] of people with disabilities and on the education of Israeli leaders regarding the [[American Jews|American Jewish community]]. The foundation maintains offices in [[Boston]], [[Israel]] and [[New York City]].
==Early life and education== Ruderman was born on March 16, 1966. He is the oldest of three siblings, the son of Marcia and Morton E. Ruderman. The latter cofounded [[Meditech]] and other successful business ventures, dedicating his later life to helping others.<ref>{{cite web | last=Negri | first=Gloria | title=Morton Ruderman, 75; devoted life to helping others | website=BostonGlobe.com | date=2011-10-31 | url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/obituaries/2011/10/31/morton-ruderman-devoted-life-helping-others/rL8YpiDtdYBG1iWAWLgpwI/story.html | access-date=2018-02-22}}</ref> Ruderman attended public schools in [[Lynnfield, Massachusetts]], and received his undergraduate degree from [[Brandeis University]], where he served as president of the student body in 1986-87. He earned his [[Juris Doctor|JD]] from [[Boston University School of Law]] in 1993. He served in the [[Israel Defense Forces]] as Liaison with the Jewish Diaspora.
==Career== === Assistant District Attorney, Essex County, MA === Ruderman began his career as Assistant District Attorney in [[Essex County, Massachusetts]].
===American Israel Public Affairs Committee === He later worked for the [[American Israel Public Affairs Committee]] (AIPAC), first as Deputy Director of the [[New England]] office and then as Leadership Director of the [[Jerusalem]] office.
=== Ruderman Family Foundation === Ruderman has been President of the [[Ruderman Family Foundation]] since 2008.
==Activist philanthropy== Ruderman grew the Ruderman Family Foundation from a local foundation serving the Boston Jewish community to one with an international focus. Under his leadership the Foundation seeks to change societal attitudes around disability and to advocate for the rights of people with disabilities.<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/claudia-jacobs/foundations-should-take-a_b_3670683.html "Foundations Should Take a Look at the Largest Poverty Minority. Think Inclusively, Act Inclusively"], The Huffington Post, [http://www.grantcraft.org/videos/60-seconds-with-jay-ruderman "60 Seconds with Jay Ruderman: The real measure of impact]</ref> The philanthropic strategy of the Foundation is to go narrow and deep: it focuses on a limited number of issues and works with the media to raise awareness of those issues across all sectors of society. These issues center around changing societal attitudes so that disability inclusion is seen as central to civil rights and social justice, and not an issue of charity.
The Ruderman Family Foundation, led by Jay Ruderman, is an international leader in the intersection between social advocacy, disabilities, and inclusion. Part of its advocacy involves publishing white papers on different topics related to disabilities and inclusion.
With the foundation as his vehicle, Jay Ruderman has established himself as one of the leading voices for disability rights on social media. Ruderman has used social media in past years to respond to derogatory language used by public figures toward people with disabilities. Examples of derogatory language to which Ruderman responded include the video showing the rapper [[50 Cent]] mocking a disabled airport employee, and the rude gestures made by President [[Donald Trump]] mimicking the disability of ''New York Times'' reporter Serge Kovaleski.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thejewishweek.com/blogs/new-normal/join-us-toward-inclusion-perspectives-disability-social-responsibility-and-belongin|title=Join Us: "Toward Inclusion: Perspectives on Disability, Social Responsibility, and Belonging"|date=2016-03-31|website=The Jewish Week {{!}} Connecting The World To Jewish News, Culture & Opinion|access-date=2016-05-24}}</ref> The response to the Donald Trump episode led to the Foundation being featured during the [[2016 Democratic National Convention]].
On a daily basis Ruderman engages in rapid response activism, much of which is done through numerous op-eds he has written for major publications in the US and Israel. Recently, the Foundation launched the Ruderman Family Awards for Excellence in Reporting on Disability at the [[Walter Cronkite School of Journalism]] at Arizona State University. The prize seeks to encourage excellent reporting on disability, by recognizing the best disability reporting produced each year by media organizations around the world.
Ruderman has also put together several signature programs as part of his activist philanthropy. Among them is the Ruderman Prize in Inclusion, which recognizes organizations around the world that serve as exemplars of disability inclusion. Twenty Ruderman Prizes have been awarded since 2012.
In 2017, the Foundation hosted its second Ruderman Inclusion Summit, which was one of the world's largest gathering of disability activists with over 1,400 people in attendance. The first such summit was held two years before that, in November 2015 in Boston, with 500 leaders and activists. Plenary speakers at both summits included Oscar Award Winner [[Marlee Matlin]], Former President of Malawi [[Joyce Banda]], former Senator [[Tom Harkin]] (D-Iowa), author [[Ron Suskind]], Special Olympian [[Loretta Claiborne]], Michigan State Supreme Court Justice Richard H. Bernstein, journalist and NPR host [[John Hockenberry]], Senator [[Maggie Hassan]] (D–NH), Congressman [[Gregg Harper]] (R-MS), and Congressman [[Jim Langevin]] (D–RI).
Ruderman has also launched Link20, a leadership network for young disability advocates aiming to develop a young cross-disability movement through strengthening the leadership of the participants and helping them raise awareness and shatter stereotypes about people with disabilities. The network began in Israel and has spread to Boston, New York, and Washington DC.
An additional signature program is the Morton E. Ruderman Award in Inclusion, which has been given annually since 2013 to an individual for outstanding accomplishment in the field of disability inclusion. In 2013 the award was given to Michael Stein, co-founder and Executive Director of the Harvard Law School Project on Disability. In 2014 it was given to Ari Ne’eman, President and co-founder of the Autistic Self Advocacy Network. In 2015, the recipient was Senator Tom Harkin (D-Iowa, retired), a writer of the [[Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990|Americans with Disabilities Act]]. The latest recipient was Oscar winning actress, Marlee Matlin.
The Foundation created the ADVANCE Conference series in 2011, 2012, and 2013 to educate the Jewish funding community about the issue of disability inclusion. As a result of those meetings the Disability Peer Network was founded at the Jewish Funders Network by the Foundation and others.
In addition to its activity surrounding people with disabilities, the Foundation led by Jay Ruderman also focuses on Israel-American Jewish relations and maintains major partnerships with the Government of Israel and many national Jewish organizations in the U.S. and Israel.
In November 2015, the Foundation organized a series of high-level events in Israel, focusing on the relationship between Israel and the American Jewish community. These included the Conference on Israel-American Jewish Relations, with speeches by former Israeli President and Nobel Peace Laureate [[Shimon Peres]], former U.S. Senator [[Joseph Lieberman]] (D-Connecticut), and U.S. Ambassador [[Daniel B. Shapiro]]; a public meeting of the [[Knesset]] Caucus on Israel-U.S. Relations; and the formal opening of the third year of [[University of Haifa|Haifa University]]'s Ruderman Program in American Jewish Studies.
The Foundation has also brought delegations of members of Israel's Knesset to the United States to expose them to the diversity of the U.S. Jewish community in 2011, 2012, 2014, 2016 and 2017. This program was instrumental in establishing the Knesset Caucus on Israel-U.S. Relations.
In 2013, with funding from the Foundation, Haifa University launched the Ruderman Program in American Jewish Studies, the only degree-granting program of its kind in Israel.
The Foundation also releases white papers on the topic of the US-Israel relationship, including one entitled ''The Jewish Vote: Political Power and Identity in US Elections''.
Jay has also called for a more democratic, representative and inclusive Jewish community, as shown in an op-ed for [http://blogs.timesofisrael.com/time-for-a-change-how-our-major-jewish-organizations-can-better-represent-the-diversity-of-our-american-jewish-community/ The Times of Israel].
==Hollywood activism== Over the years, an important part of Ruderman's activism has focused on Hollywood and the film industry, particularly its representation of people with disabilities and lack of inclusion of disabled actors in leading roles. Ruderman has publicly criticized [[Hollywood]] productions, and this has earned him much media coverage.
Most recently, Ruderman publicly criticized the movie ''[[Don't Worry, He Won't Get Far on Foot]]'' for casting [[Joaquin Phoenix]] in the role of a disabled man, instead of casting an actor with a disability.<ref>[http://www.indiewire.com/2018/01/joaquin-phoenix-casting-dont-worry-he-wont-get-far-on-foot-ruderman-disability-foundation-1201918359/ "Joaquin Phoenix’s ‘Don’t Worry, He Won’t Get Far on Foot’ Casting Slammed as Offensive by Ruderman Disability Foundation"] ''IndieWire''. Retrieved 2018-03-22.</ref>
In July 2017, Ruderman similarly condemned<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/news/alec-baldwin-criticized-for-portraying-blind-man-in-new-film-w491281|title=Alec Baldwin Criticized for Portraying Blind Man in Upcoming Film|work=Rolling Stone|access-date=2017-07-07}}</ref> the movie [[Blind (2016 film)|Blind]] starring [[Alec Baldwin]] and [[Demi Moore]] on grounds that Baldwin played a blind character. Ruderman's main claim is that the movie "is just the latest example of treating disability as a costume."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/blind-alec-baldwin-controversy-1202488128/|title=Disability Organization Slams ‘Blind’ for Casting Alec Baldwin in Lead Role|last=Rubin|first=Rebecca|date=2017-07-06|work=Variety|access-date=2017-07-07|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/la-et-entertainment-news-updates-july-disability-organization-condemns-1499273816-htmlstory.html|title=Today in Entertainment: Blue Ivy makes her rap debut on Jay-Z's new album; Angela Lansbury, Emily Watson to star in 'Little Women'|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2017-07-07|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref> He likened the casting of able-bodied actors to portray characters with disabilities to blackface<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2017/jul/06/how-alec-baldwin-casting-in-blind-is-part-of-a-catch-22-for-disabled-actors|title=How Alec Baldwin's casting in Blind is part of a catch-22 for disabled actors|last=Ellis-Petersen|first=Hannah|date=2017-07-06|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-07|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> and states that it's time for society to condemn the practice just like casting white actors to play black characters is no longer socially acceptable.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2017/07/alec-baldwin-new-movie-blind-disability-rights-ableism-1201851800/|title=Alec Baldwin’s New Movie ‘Blind’ Criticized By Disability Rights Group {{!}} IndieWire|last=Dry|first=Jude|website=www.indiewire.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-07}}</ref> The incident led to written exchanges between the movie's director, [[Michael Mailer]], and Ruderman, both published by the industry publication Deadline.com.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2017/07/blind-alec-baldwin-backlash-director-responds-michael-mailer-1202129011/|title=‘Blind’ Director Addresses Backlash Over Casting Alec Baldwin And Not Disabled Actor In Lead Role|last=Mailer|first=Michael|date=2017-07-14|work=Deadline|access-date=2017-07-20|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2017/07/blind-movie-controversy-alec-baldwin-ruderman-foundation-responds-guest-column-1202130794/|title=‘Blind’ Movie: Ruderman Foundation Responds To Director Over Alec Baldwin Casting Flap|last=Ruderman|first=Jay|date=2017-07-18|work=Deadline|access-date=2017-07-20|language=en-US}}</ref>
In response to the release of the 2016 film [[Me Before You (film)|Me Before You]], Ruderman condemned the film's widely criticized portrayal of disability, in which the protagonist{{ndash}}who is paralyzed{{ndash}}ends up committing suicide because he feels his life is not worth living. Ruderman was widely quoted as stating, "To the millions of people with significant disabilities currently leading fulfilling, rich lives, it posits that they are better off committing suicide."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/06/05/me-before-you-ending-director-responds|title='Me Before You' director responds to controversy over film's ending|access-date=2016-07-01}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cosmopolitan.com.au/celebrity/celebrity-gossip/2016/6/me-before-you-movie-ending/|title=The director of Me Before You is #sorrynotsorry about its controversial ending|access-date=2016-07-01}}</ref> Ruderman's second major point in this controversy was that it is problematic for an able-bodied actor to play a character with a disabilitiy, a topic he often speaks up about.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/opinion/op-ed/la-oe-woodburn-ruderman-disability-stats-tv-20160711-snap-story.html|title=Why are we OK with disability drag in Hollywood?|date=2016-07-11|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2017-03-10|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref>
In addition to commenting on movie productions, Ruderman has also released two white papers focusing on television content and people with disabilities.
The Ruderman Family Foundation was awarded the 2017 [[SAG-AFTRA]] Disability Awareness Award for its work in fighting for self-representation of people with disabilities on screen.
==Awards== Jay Ruderman has received numerous awards for his work over the years including: * DLC Disability Law Center Edward M. Kennedy Leadership Award (2016) * [[Arc of the United States|Arc]]’s Catalyst Award for Foundation Philanthropist of the year (2016) * University of Haifa's degree of Doctor of Philosophy, Honoris Causa (2015) * Hebrew College S’fatai Tiftah Award (2015) * SAG-AFTRA Disability Awareness Award (2017)
==Board memberships== * Jewish Funders Network * [[American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee]], Board of Directors and Executive Committee * University of Haifa, Board of Governors
==Personal life== Ruderman is married to Israeli-American Shira Menashe Ruderman. They live in the Greater Boston area and have four children.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Linde|first1=Steve|title=Jerusalem Post 50 Most Influential Jews: Number 46|url=http://www.jpost.com/Not-Just-News/Jerusalem-Post-50-Most-Influential-Jews-Number-46-Jay-and-Shira-Ruderman-469086|accessdate=12 March 2018|publisher=The Jerusalem Post|date=September 29, 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.rudermanfoundation.org/ The Ruderman Family Foundation homepage] * [http://www.rudermanfoundation.org/about-us/staff/jay-ruderman Jay Ruderman bio], on the Ruderman Family Foundation website

{{short description|American stand-up comedian, actress and author}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Jenny Slate | image = Jenny Slate Obvious Child Premiere 2014 (cropped).jpg | caption = Slate at the 2014 ''[[Obvious Child]]'' premiere at the ArcLight Hollywood theater | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1982|3|25}} | birth_place = [[Milton, Massachusetts]], U.S. | residence = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] | education = [[Milton Academy]] | alma_mater = [[Columbia University]] | occupation = {{flatlist| *Stand-up comedian *actress *author}} | years_active = 2005–present | spouse = {{marriage|Dean Fleischer-Camp
|2012|2016|reason=sep.}}{{cite news|last1=King|first1=Brittany|title=Jenny Slate and Husband Dean Fleischer-Camp Split|url=http://www.people.com/article/jenny-slate-husband-dean-fleischer-camp-split|accessdate=August 1, 2016|publisher=People|date=May 4, 2016}} | birthname = Jenny Sarah Slate }} '''Jenny Sarah Slate''' (born March 25, 1982) is an American stand-up comedian, actress and author, best known for her role as Mona-Lisa Saperstein on ''[[Parks and Recreation]]'' as well as being the co-creator of the ''[[Marcel the Shell with Shoes On]]'' short films and children's book series. She was a cast member on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' for the [[Saturday Night Live (season 35)|2009/10 season]] and appeared in shows such as ''[[House of Lies]]'', ''[[Married (TV series)|Married]]'', ''[[Bob's Burgers]]'', [[Hello Ladies|''Hello'' ''Ladies'']], ''[[Kroll Show]]'', ''[[Bored to Death]]'', and ''[[Girls (TV series)|Girls]]'', as well as movies like ''[[Zootopia]]'', ''[[The Secret Life of Pets]]'', and ''[[Despicable Me 3]]''. Slate played the lead role in the 2014 film ''[[Obvious Child]]'', and in 2016 she was in ''[[Brain on Fire (film)|Brain on Fire]]''. ==Early life== Slate was born on March 25, 1982 in [[Milton, Massachusetts]],{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/jenny-slate/photos/298545/ | title=Jenny Slate| publisher=[[TV Guide|TVGuide.com]]| accessdate=May 11, 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:KK7N-VJW |title= Jenny Sarah Slate| publisher=FamilySearch.org|accessdate=May 11, 2016}} to Ron Slate (born 1950),{{cite web|url=http://www.ronslate.com/about_ron_slate|title=About Ron Slate - On the Seawall: A Literary Website by Ron Slate (GD)|website=www.ronslate.com}} a businessman and poet who worked as vice president of global communications for the [[Dell EMC|EMC Corporation]] and later as CEO of a biotech startup,{{Cite web|url=http://www.ronslate.com/about_ron_slate|title=About Ron Slate {{!}} On the Seawall: A Literary Website by Ron Slate (GD)|website=www.ronslate.com|language=en|access-date=July 25, 2017}}{{Cite news|url=http://blogs.bostonmagazine.com/boston_daily/2009/02/27/questions-for-jenny-slate |title=Questions For: Jenny Slate |date=February 27, 2009 |work=Boston Daily |accessdate=August 18, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091113152818/http://blogs.bostonmagazine.com/boston_daily/2009/02/27/questions-for-jenny-slate |archivedate=November 13, 2009 }}Slate, Ron (April 7, 2005). [https://books.google.com/books?id=DJM1pnyJC2MC&pg=PT64&dq=%22The+Incentive+of+the+Maggot%22#v=onepage&q=Jenny ''The Incentive of the Maggot'']. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt. p. v. Archived at [[Google Books]]. Retrieved September 10, 2014. and Nancy ([[née]] Gilson), a [[Ceramic art|ceramicist]].{{Cite news|url=http://jewishjournal.com/culture/arts/130066/|title=Comedian Jenny Slate in Obvious Child|date=June 30, 2014|work=Jewish Journal|accessdate=June 30, 2014}} She is the middle child of three, with an older sister named Abigail and younger sister named Stacey.{{Cite news|url=http://www.miltontimes.com/DOTnet-frontJUMPS-JennySlate.html |title=Jenny Slate Joins the Cast of 'Saturday Night Live' |last=Kurtz Ferrari |first=Kathy |date=September 24, 2009 |work=Milton Times |accessdate=August 18, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714094755/http://www.miltontimes.com/DOTnet-frontJUMPS-JennySlate.html |archivedate=July 14, 2011 |df= }}{{cite web|last1=Yuan|first1=Jada|title=The Year of Living Publicly|url=http://www.vulture.com/2017/03/jenny-slate-gifted-chris-evans-breakup.html|publisher=Vulture.com|accessdate=March 21, 2017|date=March 21, 2017}} She was raised in a [[Jewish]] family.{{Cite news|url=http://www.laweekly.com/arts/jenny-slate-2612392|title=Jenny Slate|last=Molyneaux|first=Libby|date=December 6, 2012|work=[[LA Weekly]]|accessdate=June 23, 2018}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.tabletmag.com/scroll/227356/drawing-inspiration-from-jenny-slates-game-changing-hair|title=Jewish Comedian Jenny Slate on Learning to Love Her Curly Hair|accessdate=June 23, 2018|date=March 13, 2017|last=Cooper|first=Miranda|work=[[Tablet (magazine)|Tablet Magazine]]}} One of her grandmothers was born in [[Cuba]], to a family from Russia and Turkey, and was raised in France.{{cite web|url=http://bullettmedia.com/article/jenny-slate-career-making-film-obvious-child/ |title=Jenny Slate On Her Career-Making Film 'Obvious Child' |work=bullettmedia.com |accessdate=May 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151023215249/http://bullettmedia.com/article/jenny-slate-career-making-film-obvious-child/ |archivedate=October 23, 2015 |df= }} After graduating from [[Milton Academy]] as the [[valedictorian]], Slate attended [[Columbia University]] as a literature major, where she helped form the [[Improvisational theatre|improv]] group Fruit Paunch, starred in the Varsity Show{{Cite news|url=http://www.columbiaspectator.com/2002/05/03/varsity-show-reach-exceeds-its-grasp|title=Varsity Show Reach Exceeds Its Grasp|last=Fitzner|first=Ana|date=May 3, 2002|work=Columbia Spectator|accessdate=August 18, 2010}} and met Gabe Liedman, who would become her comedy partner.{{Cite news|url=http://intothegloss.com/2014/06/jenny-slate-quote/|title=Jenny Slate|date=June 2014|work=Into the Gloss|accessdate=July 2, 2014}} Slate graduated from Columbia in 2004. ==Career== Alongside Gabe Liedman, Slate was half of the comedy duo Gabe & Jenny.{{Cite news|url=http://gothamist.com/2009/06/10/gabe_liedman_and_jenny_slate_comedi.php|title=Gabe Liedman and Jenny Slate, Comedians|last=Parker|first=Billy|date=June 10, 2009|work=Gothamist|accessdate=August 18, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100304101223/http://gothamist.com/2009/06/10/gabe_liedman_and_jenny_slate_comedi.php|archivedate=March 4, 2010|df=mdy-all}} Their live stand-up shows with Max Silvestri titled ''Big Terrific'' were named best new variety show of 2008 by ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]] [[New York City|New York]]''.{{Cite news|url=http://newyork.timeout.com/articles/comedy/69876/comedy-the-best-and-worst-of-2008|title=Comedy: The best (and worst) of 2008|last=Borden|first=Jane|date=December 2008|work=Time Out New York|accessdate=August 18, 2010}} In 2015, Slate, Liedman, and Silvestri announced that the show would be ending due to their busy schedules,{{cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2015/04/slate-liedman-and-silvestri-on-big-terrific.html|title=Jenny Slate, Gabe Liedman, and Max Silvestri on the End of Their Weekly Comedy Show, Big Terrific|date=April 22, 2015|publisher=}} though they continue to perform together when possible. Slate first met Liedman in 2000 while attending [[Columbia University]].{{Cite news|url=http://gothamist.com/2007/05/04/gabe_liedman_an.php|title=Gabe Liedman and Jenny Slate, A Night with Gabe and Jenny|last=Karakh|first=Ben|date=May 4, 2007|work=Gothamist|accessdate=August 18, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100412000839/http://gothamist.com/2007/05/04/gabe_liedman_an.php|archivedate=April 12, 2010|df=mdy-all}} They describe their relationship as a "nonsexual romance" and Slate says, "I like to think of us as kind of like [[Elaine Benes]] and [[George Costanza]], but we like each other." Throughout 2008 and 2009, Slate regularly performed her one-woman show titled ''Jenny Slate: Dead Millionaire'' at the [[Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre]] (UCBT) in [[New York City]].{{Cite web|url=http://newyork.ucbtheatre.com/performers/3982 |title=Jenny Slate |work=Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre |accessdate=August 18, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100830030251/http://newyork.ucbtheatre.com/performers/3982 |archivedate=August 30, 2010 |df= }} [[File:Jenny Slate and Gabe Liedman in 2007.jpg|thumb|left|Slate with comedy partner Gabe Liedman in 2007]] Slate was a regular commentator on many [[VH1]] "talking head" commentary programs. In early 2009, she had made several appearances on the ''[[Late Night with Jimmy Fallon]]'' recurring sketch "7th Floor West", where she played an [[NBC page]] also named Jenny, who was later promoted to [[Jimmy Fallon|Fallon]]'s assistant. She also had a recurring role in ''[[Bored to Death]]''.{{Cite news|url=http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2009/09/vulture_interviews_new_saturda.html|title=Vulture Interviews New ''Saturday Night Live'' Cast Member Jenny Slate|date=September 11, 2009|work=Vulture|publisher=New York Magazine|accessdate=August 18, 2010}}{{Cite news|url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2009/11/09/bored-to-death-jenny-slate-hbo/|title='Bored to Death:' Jenny Slate, please come back|last=Barrett|first=Annie|date=November 9, 2009|work=PopWatch|publisher=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=August 18, 2010}} Slate has made guest appearances on television programs, such as ''[[Bob's Burgers]]'', ''[[Girls (TV series)|Girls]]'', ''[[The Whitest Kids U' Know]]'', ''[[Important Things with Demetri Martin]]'' and ''[[Raising Hope]]''. Slate joined the cast of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' for one season from 2009 to 2010.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/bios/jenny-slate.shtml |title=Jenny Slate |accessdate=September 28, 2009|publisher=''[[Saturday Night Live]]''}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/SNL-New-Cast-1009401.aspx|title=Saturday Night Live Adds Two New Cast Members|last=Bryant|first=Adam|date=September 9, 2009|publisher=tvguide.com}} In her first episode, she accidentally said "fucking" during her debut sketch "Biker Chick Chat", which was heard on the live broadcast, but removed from reruns.Schwindt, Oriana (September 15, 2014). "What's Worth Watching". ''[[TV Guide]]''. p. 79{{Cite news|url=http://www.pbpulse.com/tv/saturday-night-live/2009/09/28/saturday-night-live-starts-season-with-f-bomb/#more-32270|title='Saturday Night Live' starts season with F-bomb|date=September 28, 2009|work=Associated Press|accessdate=August 18, 2010}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.tvsquad.com/2009/12/13/jenny-slate-drops-the-f-bomb-on-snl/|title=TV Moment of 2009: Jenny Slate Drops the F-Bomb on 'SNL'|last=Hollowell|first=Jenny|date=December 13, 2009|work=TV Squad|accessdate=August 18, 2010}} During her brief time on the series, she impersonated celebrities such as [[Hoda Kotb]], [[Lady Gaga]], [[Kristen Stewart]], [[Ashley Olsen]], and [[Olympia Snowe]] and became known for Tina-Tina Cheneuse, an infomercial pitchwoman who advertises personalized doorbells, car horns, and alarm clocks.{{cite web|last=Anne|first=Sarah|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/celebritology/2010/09/jenny_slate_leaves_saturday_ni.html|title=Celebritology 2.0 – Jenny Slate leaves 'Saturday Night Live', and we ask, what went wrong?|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=September 8, 2010}} Slate's contract was not renewed for another season.{{cite web|last=Itzkoff|first=Dave|url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/09/07/saturday-night-live-cast-adds-four-and-loses-one-more|title='Saturday Night Live' Cast Adds Four and Loses One More - NYTimes.com|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=September 7, 2010|accessdate=February 24, 2011}} In August 2010, she co-wrote and voiced ''[[Marcel the Shell with Shoes On]]'', which garnered viral success. This led to ''Marcel the Shell with Shoes on, Two''.{{Cite news|url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2010/08/17/jenny-slatess-marcel-the-shell-with-shoes-on-is-fantastic/|title=Jenny Slates's 'Marcel the Shell with Shoes On' is fantastic|last=Lyons|first=Margaret|date=August 17, 2010|work=PopWatch|publisher=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=August 18, 2010}}{{Cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/popcandy/post/2010/08/exclusive-snl-star-jenny-slate-chats-about-marcel-the-shell/1|title=Exclusive: 'SNL' star Jenny Slate chats about 'Marcel the Shell'|last=Matheson|first=Whitney|date=August 29, 2010|work=Pop Candy|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=August 30, 2010}} Slate also wrote a "Marcel"-themed children's book that was released on November 1, 2011.{{cite web|last=Swerdloff |first=Alexis |url=http://www.papermag.com/arts_and_style/2010/11/jenny-slate-emerges-from-her-shellas-a-shell.php |title=Jenny Slate Emerges From Her Shell ... As A Shell |publisher=Papermag.com |date=November 3, 2010 |accessdate=February 24, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101106165211/http://www.papermag.com/arts_and_style/2010/11/jenny-slate-emerges-from-her-shellas-a-shell.php |archivedate=November 6, 2010 |df= }} Her first major film role was as Zoe in ''[[Alvin and the Chipmunks: Chipwrecked]]''; more films followed in 2012, including the voice of Ted's mother in ''[[The Lorax (film)|The Lorax]]''. Her first appearance in ''[[Parks and Recreation]]'' was in the 2013 episode "Bailout", in which she portrayed Mona-Lisa Saperstein. Following her success on the NBC show, Slate released and starred in a 12 episode mini-series on YouTube called ''Catherine'', celebrating late 1980' and early 1990s soap opera aesthetics.{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2940332/|title=Catherine|date=May 19, 2013|accessdate=June 23, 2016}} On July 23, 2013, she appeared in ''[[Drunk History]]'' retelling the history of how [[Coca-Cola]] was made. In 2014, Slate starred in the comedy-drama film ''[[Obvious Child]]'', which follows the life of a young stand up comic as she grapples with an unplanned pregnancy and eventual abortion.{{cite web|last1=Pickett|first1=Leah|title=Performance of the Year: Jenny Slate|url=http://consequenceofsound.net/2014/12/performance-of-the-year-2014/|website=Consequence of Sound}} Slate went on to win the [[Critics' Choice Movie Awards|Critics Choice Award]] for Best Actress in a Comedy,{{cite web|last1=Cappadona|first1=Bryanna|title=Jenny Slate Wins Big at the Critics' Choice Awards|url=http://www.bostonmagazine.com/arts-entertainment/blog/2015/01/16/jenny-slate-critics-choice-awards-2015/|website=Boston Magazine}} Best Breakout Performance at the Newport Beach Film Festival, the Virtuosos Award at the Santa Barbara Film Festival, and Best Comedic Actress at the Women Film Circle Awards for her performance in the film. Slate co-starred with [[Judy Greer]] and [[Nat Faxon]] in the first season of the [[FX (TV channel)|FX]] series ''[[Married (TV series)|Married]]''.{{cite web |url=http://splitsider.com/2014/01/fx-orders-series-starring-nat-faxon-judy-greer-brett-gelman-and-jenny-slate-coming-in-july/ |title=FX Orders Series Starring Nat Faxon, Judy Greer, Brett Gelman, and Jenny Slate; Coming in July |publisher=Splitsider |date=January 24, 2014}} She left the series as a series regular in season two, but still appeared in a few episodes. [[Sarah Burns]] took her place in the series. Slate appeared as Liz B. in the recurring "PubLIZity" sketches in ''[[Kroll Show]]'', as well as many other recurring and one-off characters, performing in some capacity in almost every episode until the series ended in 2015. In 2016, Slate voiced Dawn Bellwether in the [[Disney]] animated comedy-adventure film ''[[Zootopia]]'' and Gidget in the animated feature ''[[The Secret Life of Pets]]''. Slate and her father co-wrote a book about their time living in Slate's childhood home in Milton, Massachusetts, titled ''About the House,'' which was published in December 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.bostonmagazine.com/property/blog/2016/11/03/jenny-slate-milton-house/|title=Jenny Slate and Her Father Wrote a Book About Their House in Milton|date=November 3, 2016|access-date=February 15, 2017|author=Madeline Bilis|periodical=[[Boston Magazine]]}} In 2017, Slate starred in the film ''[[Gifted (film)|Gifted]]'' as Bonnie Stevenson, the teacher of a 7-year-old mathematical genius. Slate appeared in the 2018 film ''[[Venom (2018 film)|Venom]]'', where she portrayed Dr. Dora Skirth, a scientist at the Life Foundation. ==Personal life== She lived in [[Cobble Hill, Brooklyn]], before moving with her former husband to Los Angeles in the early 2010s.{{cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/news/laugh-track-jenny-slates-winding-road-from-snl-to-obvious-child-20140602|title=How Jenny Slate Went from an 'SNL' Blunder to 'Obvious ChildSuccess|last=Battan|first=Carrie|date=June 2, 2014|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|quote=Slate decamped for Los Angeles a couple of years ago with her now-husband, director Dean Fleischer-Camp.|accessdate=June 4, 2014|archivedate=May 6, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160506044721/http://www.rollingstone.com/movies/news/laugh-track-jenny-slates-winding-road-from-snl-to-obvious-child-20140602|deadurl=no}} In September 2012, Slate married filmmaker Dean Fleischer-Camp,{{cite news |last=Killoran |first=Ellen |url= http://www.thelmagazine.com/gyrobase/the-rise-and-fall-and-rise-of-jenny-slate/Content?oid=2104645&storyPage=1|title=The Rise and Fall and Rise of Jenny Slate |work=[[L Magazine]] |date=May 25, 2011 |accessdate=June 19, 2011}} with whom she collaborated on the ''Marcel the Shell with Shoes On'' books and short films. [[University of Kansas]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]], [[Juris Doctor|JD]]) |website = {{url|moran.senate.gov|Senate website}} }} '''Gerald Wesley Moran''' (born May 29, 1954) is an American politician serving as the [[Seniority in the United States Senate|junior]] [[United States Senate|United States Senator]] from [[Kansas]] since 2011. A member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]], he served as Chairman of the [[National Republican Senatorial Committee]] for the [[113th United States Congress|113th U.S. Congress]], during which he led successful Republican efforts in [[United States Senate elections, 2014|2014 election]], producing the first Republican Senate majority since 2006.{{cite news|title=Cornyn Elected Whip, Moran NRSC Chair|url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/blogs/hotlineoncall/2012/11/cornyn-elected-whip-moran-nrsc-chair-14|accessdate=15 November 2012|newspaper=National Journal|date=14 November 2012}} Previously, he served as a member of the [[United States House of Representatives]], representing {{ushr|KS|1}}. Raised in [[Plainville, Kansas]], Moran graduated from the [[University of Kansas]] and the [[University of Kansas School of Law]]. He worked in private law and served as the state special assistant attorney general (1982–85) and deputy attorney of [[Rooks County, Kansas|Rooks County]] (1987–95). He served in the [[Kansas Senate]] (1989–1997), and was [[majority leader]] for his last two years. He was elected to the House of Representatives in 1996 and served six terms with little electoral opposition. He was elected to the U.S. Senate in [[United States Senate election in Kansas, 2010|2010]] after defeating fellow [[U.S. Representative]] [[Todd Tiahrt]] in a contentious primary. He was re-elected to the U.S. Senate in [[United States Senate election in Kansas, 2016|2016]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/politics-government/election/article113463638.html|title=Sen. Jerry Moran of Kansas easily wins second term in U.S. Senate|work=mcclatchydc|access-date=2017-03-24|language=en}} == Early life, education and career == Moran was born in [[Great Bend, Kansas|Great Bend]], [[Kansas]], the son of Madeline Eleanor (née Fletcher) and Raymond Edwin "Ray" Moran.{{cite web|url=http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~battle/senators/moranjerry.htm|title=Jerry Moran ancestry|publisher=freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com|accessdate=13 September 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208073607/http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~battle/senators/moranjerry.htm|archive-date=8 December 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} He was raised in [[Plainville, Kansas|Plainville]].{{cite news|work=Biographical Directory of the United States Congress|title=Moran, Jerry, (1954–)|url=http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=m000934}} He attended [[Fort Hays State University]] before enrolling at the [[University of Kansas]] in [[Lawrence, Kansas|Lawrence]], where he earned a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in economics in 1976.{{cite news|work=Project Vote Smart|title=Senator Jerry Moran (KS)|url=http://www.votesmart.org/bio.php?can_id=542}} While attending the University of Kansas, he worked as a summer intern for [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] [[Keith Sebelius]] in 1974, when impeachment proceedings were being prepared against [[President of the United States|President]] [[Richard Nixon]]. Moran worked as a banker before receiving his [[Juris Doctor]] from the [[University of Kansas School of Law]] in 1982.{{cite news|work=United States Senator Jerry Moran|title=About Jerry|url=https://moran.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/aboutjerry|access-date=2017-11-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170215133406/http://www.moran.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/aboutjerry|archive-date=2017-02-15|dead-url=yes|df=}} He practiced law at Stinson, Mag & Fizzell in [[Kansas City, Kansas|Kansas City]], and later joined Jeter & Larson Law Firm in [[Hays, Kansas|Hays]], where he practiced law for fifteen years. In addition to his law practice, he served as the state special assistant attorney general (1982–85) and deputy county attorney of [[Rooks County, Kansas|Rooks County]] (1987–95). He also served as an adjunct professor of political science at Fort Hays State University. == Kansas Senate == Moran served for eight years (1989–1997) in the [[Kansas Senate]]. He served two years as the Vice President and his last two years as majority leader.{{cite web |url=http://www.jerrymoran.house.gov/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=37&Itemid=102 |title=About Jerry, Serving Kansas' 'Big First' |publisher=Congressman Jerry Moran Official Page |access-date=2010-09-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101007034332/http://www.jerrymoran.house.gov/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=37&Itemid=102 |archive-date=2010-10-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }} == U.S. House of Representatives == [[File:Jerry Moran, 109th Congress, official portrait.jpg|thumb|Moran's [[109th United States Congress|109th Congress]] portrait]] === Elections === Moran was elected to Congress in 1996 and reelected five times, never facing serious opposition in the conservative 1st district. In 2006, his [[United States House elections, 2006 complete list#Kansas|opponent for the 2006 midterm election]] was [[John Doll (Kansas politician)|John Doll]], against whom he received almost 79 percent of the vote—one of the highest totals for a Republican congressional incumbent in that election.{{cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/ELECTION/2006/pages/results/house/ |title=CNN 2006 Election Totals |publisher=cnn.com|accessdate=13 September 2015}} === Tenure === During his time in the House of Representatives, Jerry Moran conducted an annual town hall meeting in each of the 69 counties in Kansas' "Big First" Congressional District. He continues the tradition in the U.S. Senate for all 105 counties.{{cite web|title=Moran invites Kansans to join him during annual listening tour |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-2190795451.html |work=U.S. News Service|publisher=High Beam Research}} As a senior member of the House Agriculture Committee in the U.S. House of Representatives, then-Congressman Moran worked with colleagues to craft legislation to aid Kansas farms and ranches. Moran was also an active member of the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee and the House Veterans' Affairs Committee, where he served as chairman of the Subcommittee on Health.{{cite web|last=United States Senate|first=Jerry Moran|title=Official Biography|url=https://moran.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/biography|work=Official Page|publisher=U.S. Senate}} Slate's David Weigel pointed out that, despite his insistence that earmarks are a way that get members of Congress to vote for spending "that we can't afford," Moran requested $19.4 million in earmarks in the 2010 budget.{{cite news|last1=Weigel|first1=David|title=From Earmarker to Tea Partyer: The Ballad of Jerry Moran |publisher=Slate|date=27 January 2011 |url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/weigel/2011/01/27/from_earmarker_to_tea_partyer_the_ballad_of_jerry_moran.html|accessdate=15 August 2014}} == U.S. Senate == === Elections === Moran became the 2010 [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[United States Senate election in Kansas, 2010|nominee for U.S. Senate in Kansas]] after defeating fellow Congressman [[Todd Tiahrt]] in the Republican primary, 50–45%.{{cite web|url=http://www.kansasfreepress.com/2010/08/live-election-results-right-here-kansas-state-primaries.html|title=2010: Kansas Primary Election Results | Kansas Free Press|publisher=kansasfreepress.com|accessdate=13 September 2015}} In the general election, Moran took 70 percent of the vote, defeating [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] Lisa Johnston, September 2015}} === NRSC Chairmanship === Moran was elected Chairman of the [[National Republican Senatorial Committee]] for the 113th U.S. Congress on November 14, 2012.{{cite web web|title=Members|author=|url=http://www.afterschoolalliance.org/policyCongressionalCaucuses.cfm|format=|publisher=Afterschool Alliance|date=|accessdate=17 April 2018}} == Political positions == Moran's voting record is highly conservative. He has a lifetime rating of 92 from the [[American Conservative Union]]. The ''Southwest Daily Times'' once quoted him as saying, "I will always put Kansans ahead of the pressures in Washington"—a quote he posted on his House Web site.[https://web.archive.org/web/20090810005006/http://www.jerrymoran.house.gov/ Archive of Moran's House site from 2009] === Agriculture === [[File:Jerry Moran at Dinner.jpg|thumb|Jerry Moran (far right) assisting with a dinner at [[Fort Riley]]]] === Health care === Moran opposed the [[Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act|Medicare reform package of 2003]], unlike most congressmen from rural districts. He also opposed the [[Affordable Care Act]] of 2010, the health care reform bill championed by President Obama. In May 2011, Moran sponsored S. 1058, the [[Pharmacy Competition and Consumer Choice Act of 2011]].{{cite news|last=Associated Press|title=Sen. Moran Tours Topeka Hospital|url=http://www2.ljworld.com/news/2011/jun/27/sen-jerry-moran-tours-topeka-hospital/|newspaper=Lawrence Journal World|date=June 27, 2011}} In the House, he served as Co-Chairman of the House Rural Health Care Coalition and co-founder of the Congressional Community Pharmacy Coalition.{{cite web |url=https://moran.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/health-care|title=Health Care – Issues – United States Senator Jerry Moran|publisher=moran.senate.gov|accessdate=13 September 2015}} Moran announced that he was voting 'no' on the July 2017 Senate health care bill. Moran criticized the closed-door process for developing the bill and criticized the legislation for not repealing the entire 2010 health law.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/07/17/politics/health-care-motion-to-proceed-jerry-moran-mike-lee/index.html|title=Latest health care bill collapses|last=CNN|first=MJ Lee, Phil Mattingly and Ted Barrett,|work=CNN|access-date=2018-08-13}}{{cite web|last1=Everett|first1=Burgess|title=Four Republicans block Obamacare repeal bill in Senate|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/07/17/obamacare-senators-turn-on-mcconnell-240646}} === National security and military === [[File:U.S. Senator Jerry Moran (R-KS) with Kansans serving in Afghanistan, April 2011.jpeg|thumb|left|alt=U.S. Senator Jerry Moran with Kansans serving in Afghanistan in April 2011.|U.S. Senator Jerry Moran with Kansans serving in Afghanistan in April 2011.]] Since 2014, Moran has served on the [[United States Air Force Academy]] Board of Visitors.{{cite web|url=https://www.moran.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/news-releases?ID=9654a2f2-725b-484d-ac34-fb8162fa7efa|title=Sen. Moran Appointed to U.S. Air Force Academy Board of Visitors – News Releases – Newsroom – United States Senator Jerry Moran|publisher=moran.senate.gov|accessdate=13 September 2015}} In the early 2000s, Moran opposed a timetable for military withdrawal from Iraq. Since entering Congress, Moran has traveled to Afghanistan, Iraq, and Pakistan to visit deployed American forces and meet with foreign leaders.{{cite news|title=Moran Visits Troops |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1429&dat=20060202&id=65xkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Z4UNAAAAIBAJ&pg=3561,123827|accessdate=8 August 2012|newspaper=The Johnson Pioneer |date=February 2, 2006}} His most recent trip to the region was in August 2017 to the Northern regions of Afghanistan. ===Immigration and refugees=== Moran critiqued President [[Donald Trump]]'s 2017 [[Executive Order 13769|executive order]] imposing a temporary ban on entry to the U.S. to citizens of seven Muslim-majority countries, stating: "While I support thorough vetting, I do not support restricting the rights of U.S. citizens and lawful permanent residents. Furthermore, far-reaching national security policy should always be devised in consultation with Congress and relevant government agencies."{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2017/01/29/heres-where-republicans-stand-on-president-trumps-controversial-travel-ban/|title=Whip Count: Here's where Republicans stand on Trump's controversial travel ban|date=January 31, 2017|last1=Blake|first1=Aaron|work=Washington Post}} === Education === Moran supports accountability metrics for public schools, but believes federal initiatives need to provide flexibility to states. In 2001, Moran voted against passage of the No Child Left Behind Act (NCLB) because he felt it did not afford sufficient flexibility to schools.{{cite web|url=http://www.thekansan.com/features/x698066356/Moran-Stop-spending|title=Moran: ‘Stop spending|author=Cristina Janney|newspaper=The Kansan|access-date=2015-09-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120318215006/http://www.thekansan.com/features/x698066356/Moran-Stop-spending|archive-date=2012-03-18|dead-url=yes|df=}} In 2017, Moran voted to confirm [[Betsy DeVos]] as [[United States Secretary of Education]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/02/07/us/politics/betsy-devos-confirmation-vote.html|title=How Senators Voted on Betsy DeVos|date=February 7, 2017|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331}}Peter Hancock, [http://www2.ljworld.com/weblogs/capitol-report/2017/feb/2/sens-roberts-moran-unite-behind-devos-fo/ Sens. Roberts, Moran unite behind DeVos for education secretary despite widespread criticism], ''Lawrence Journal-World'' (February 2, 2017). === Gun policy=== Moran has an "A" rating from the [[National Rifle Association]] (NRA) for his consistent support of pro-gun policies.{{cite web|title=The Voter's Self Defense System|url=https://votesmart.org/candidate/542/jerry-moran?categoryId=37|website=Vote Smart|accessdate=4 October 2017}} The NRA endorsed him for his 2010 Senate run. He was described as a "steadfast supporter of our freedom," by NRA-Political Victory Fund chairman Chris W. Cox.{{cite web|title=NRA-PVF Endorses Jerry Moran for U.S. Senate|url=https://www.nrapvf.org/articles/20100913/nra-pvf-endorses-jerry-moran-for-us-senate|website=NRA-PVF|accessdate=4 October 2017|language=en}} Since 1998, the NRA has donated $23,850 to Moran's political efforts.{{cite web|last1=Kraske|first1=Steve|title=Who's the top recipient of NRA donations anywhere in the country? Take a bow, Sen. Roy Blunt|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/local/news-columns-blogs/the-buzz/article83852587.html|website=The Kansas City Star|accessdate=4 October 2017|language=en}} In 2013, Moran joined other Republicans in saying they would [[filibuster]] any Democrat's proposals that Republican's considered a threat to the Second Amendment.{{cite web|last1=Gendreau|first1=LeAnne|title=Sandy Hook Victim's Daughter Calls Out Senators|url=http://www.nbcconnecticut.com/news/local/Sandy-Hooks-Victims-Daughter-Calls-Out-Senators-202179811.html|website=NBC Connecticut|accessdate=4 October 2017|language=en}} In April, Moran voted against the Manchin-Toomey proposal for [[universal background check]]s for gun purchases.{{cite web|last1=Willis|first1=Derek|title=Defeats Manchin-Toomey Background... – S.649: Safe Communities, Safe Schools Act of 2013|url=https://projects.propublica.org/represent/votes/113/senate/1/97|website=ProPublica|accessdate=4 October 2017|language=en}}{{cite web|last1=Hancock|first1=Peter|title=Roberts, Moran vote against expanded background checks in gun sales {{!}} Statehouse Live / LJWorld.com|url=http://www2.ljworld.com/weblogs/capitol-report/2013/apr/18/roberts-moran-vote-against-expanded-back/|website=Lawrence Journal-World|accessdate=4 October 2017|language=en}} Moran supports the concept of eliminating gun-free zones on military installations and recruitment centers. He stated that they are an "infringement on the constitutional rights of our service members" and that gun-free zones make military sites "increasingly vulnerable to those who wish to do harm."{{cite web|last1=Kraske|first1=Steve|title=TheChat: Sen. Jerry Moran takes aim at "gun-free zones" on military bases|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/local/news-columns-blogs/the-buzz/article28244719.html|website=The Kansas City Star|accessdate=4 October 2017|language=en}} In 2016, Moran voted against the Feinstein Amendment, which would have banned suspected terrorists from acquiring guns.{{cite web|last1=Editorial Board|title=Pandering politicians fail again on gun control|url=http://www.kansascity.com/opinion/editorials/article85116882.html|website=The Kansas City Star|accessdate=4 October 2017|language=en}} Moran responded to the [[2017 Olathe, Kansas shooting]] stating "I strongly condemn violence of any kind, especially if it is motivated by prejudice and xenophobia."{{cite web|last1=Oroñdez|first1=Franco|title=Kansas shooting likely to test what Trump views as a hate crime|url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/politics-government/white-house/article134858389.html|website=McClatchy|accessdate=4 October 2017|language=en}} In response to the [[Orlando nightclub shooting]] and the [[2017 Las Vegas shooting|Las Vegas shooting]], Moran offered thoughts and prayers with his wife, Robba.{{cite web|last1=Wheat|first1=Shawn|title=Kansas Politicians React to Orlando Nightclub Shooting – WIBW News Now!|url=http://www.wibwnewsnow.com/kansas-politicians-react-orlando-nightclub-shooting/|website=WIBW News Now!|accessdate=4 October 2017|date=12 June 2016}}{{cite web|title=Kansas officials release statements after Las Vegas shooting|url=http://ksn.com/2017/10/02/kansas-officials-release-statements-after-las-vegas-shooting/|website=KSN-TV|accessdate=4 October 2017|date=2 October 2017}} === Environment and climate change=== As of 2017, based on his environment-related votes, Moran had a lifetime score of 8% from the [[League of Conservation Voters]], and a 0% score for 2016.{{Cite web | title=National Environmental Scorecard: Jerry Moran|year=2017|url=http://scorecard.lcv.org/moc/jerry-moran|publisher=League of Conservation Voters}} Moran voted in 2015 against a Senate amendment acknowledging that [[Anthropogenic climate change|human activity contributes to climate change]].Victoria Wang, [https://www.wired.com/2015/01/senators-dont-believe-human-caused-climate-change/ Here Are All the Senators Who Do and Don’t Believe in Human-Caused Climate Change], ''Wired'' (January 21, 2015). In 2016, Moran and several other Senate Republicans signed a letter calling upon the U.S. to withdraw funding from the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change]].Kate Sheppard & Jessica Schulberg, [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/republican-senators-climate-change-palestine_us_5716a0ebe4b06f35cb7108ef Senate Republicans Want To Cut Funding For UN Climate Change Agency, Because Palestine], ''Huffington Post'' (April 19, 2016). In 2009, Moran voted against the [[American Clean Energy and Security Act]] (Waxman-Markey), which would have established a [[cap-and-trade]] system to reduce [[carbon emissions]] and combat climate change.James Carlson, [http://cjonline.com/state/2009-06-29/cap-and-trade-vote-splits-delegation Cap and trade vote splits delegation], ''Topeka Capitol-Journal'' (June 29, 2009). Moran is a strong supporter of the construction of the [[Keystone XL]] oil pipeline.John Hanna, [http://cjonline.com/news-business-state/2014-11-20/us-sens-moran-roberts-predicting-success-keystone-xl-project# U.S. Sens. Moran, Roberts predicting success on Keystone XL project], 'Topeka Capitol-Journal'' (November 20, 2014).[https://www.moran.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/news-releases?ID=b2939b5b-3b2e-49fd-9417-6f86fec8be2a Sen. Moran Statement on Senate Keystone XL Passage] (press release), Office of Senator Jerry Moran (January 29, 2015). During the consideration of the Keystone XL pipeline legislation, Moran introduced an amendment to remove the [[lesser prairie chicken]] from the list of [[threatened species]]. The amendment failed on a 54–44 vote, having failed to get the required 60 votes.Lindsay Wise, [http://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/politics-government/congress/article24779323.html Senate votes not to remove lesser prairie chicken from 'threatened' list], McClatchy Washington Bureau (January 28, 2015).[http://www.mercurynews.com/2015/01/29/keystone-xl-bill-lesser-prairie-chicken-amendment-is-rejected/ Keystone XL bill: Lesser prairie chicken amendment is rejected], Associated Press (January 29, 2015). ===Entrepreneurship and startups=== [[File:Jerry Moran at SXSW 2013.jpg|thumb|right|alt=U.S. Senator Jerry Moran talking with entrepreneurs about their startup competing at the 2013 South by Southwest Accelerator competition.|U.S. Senator Jerry Moran talking with entrepreneurs about their startup competing at the 2013 South by Southwest Accelerator competition.]] Moran is "one of the most active members of Congress when it comes to reaching out to Silicon Valley."{{cite web|url=http://pandodaily.com/2013/05/29/the-talented-mr-green-how-fwd-us-lost-new-york-elon-musk-and-the-tech-moral-high-ground/|title=Pando: The talented Mr Green: How FWD.us lost New York, Elon Musk, and the tech moral high ground|publisher=pandodaily.com|accessdate=13 September 2015}} In 2014, [[Consumer Electronics Association]] President and CEO [[Gary Shapiro]] dubbed Moran, "Mr. Innovation" and described him as "one of the biggest tech entrepreneurship leaders in the U.S. Senate."{{cite web|url=http://siliconprairienews.com/2014/10/five-open-ended-questions-cea-ceo-gary-shapiro/|title=Five questions with the man behind CES, Gary Shapiro |publisher=siliconprairienews.com|accessdate=13 September 2015}} Moran is the lead sponsor of [[Startup Act 3.0]] legislation which includes several provisions that would reform the American visa system for high-skilled, American educated, and entrepreneurial immigrants. Moran also sponsored the [[Jumpstart Our Business Startups Act]], also known as the JOBS Act, legislation to expand crowdfunding options for startups. Since the bill's 2012 passage, he has criticized the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]]'s JOBS Act rulemaking as drawn out and potentially counter productive to the legislation's intent.{{cite web|url=https://www.moran.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/files/serve?File_id=14463f92-554e-4a34-bee2-bfe82f065b81|title=Letter to The Honorable Mary Jo White, Chairman of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, from Jerry Moran and Mark Warner|publisher=moran.senate.gov|accessdate=13 September 2015}} Moran is an advocate of increased engagement between Washington and the Startup community and has spoken on the issue at events like [[South by Southwest]] (SXSW) and the [[Consumer Electronics Show]] (CES).{{cite web|url=http://pandodaily.com/2013/08/28/washington-needs-to-escape-its-jobland-fantasy/|title=Pando: Washington needs to escape its jobland fantasy|publisher=pandodaily.com|accessdate=13 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://schedule.sxsw.com/2013/events/event_IAP5365|title=Why Public Policy Should Matter to Your Startup | Schedule | sxsw.com|publisher=schedule.sxsw.com|accessdate=13 September 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://www.siliconprairienews.com/2013/03/sen-jerry-moran-makes-second-sxsw-trip-to-promote-startup-act-3-0|title=Sen. Jerry Moran makes second SXSW trip to promote Startup Act 3.0 – Silicon Prairie News|publisher=siliconprairienews.com|accessdate=13 September 2015}} === Internet issues=== Moran opposed the [[Protect Intellectual Property Act]] (PIPA) and [[Stop Online Piracy Act]] (SOPA).{{cite book|title=Without Their Permission: How the 21st Century Will Be Made, Not Managed|author=Ohanian, A.|date=2013|publisher=Grand Central Publishing|isbn=9781455520039|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5xK0Rc_WP_IC&pg=PT123|accessdate=13 September 2015}} On November 2011, Moran, along with Republican Senator [[Rand Paul]] and Democratic Senators [[Ron Wyden]] and [[Maria Cantwell]], sent a letter to Senate Leadership indicating they would place a [[Senate hold]] on PIPA, citing the threats PIPA (and SOPA) posed to liberty and innovation.{{cite web |url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/188690699/Protect-IP-Act-Objection-Letter|title=Protect IP Act Objection Letter|publisher=scribd.com|accessdate=13 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.techdirt.com/articles/20111117/15492016808/|title=Senators Rand Paul, Jerry Moran And Maria Cantwell All Warn That PROTECT IP Will Kill Jobs|work=TechDirt|accessdate=13 September 2015}} In 2017, Moran voted to repeal [[FCC]] Internet privacy rules that blocked internet providers from sharing or selling data on customers' private data (such as browsing history) without the customer's permission.Peter Hancock, [http://www2.ljworld.com/weblogs/capitol-report/2017/mar/31/most-of-kansas-congressional-delegation-/ Most of Kansas congressional delegation supported repealing internet privacy rules], ''Lawrence Journal-World'' (March 31, 2017).[https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/congress-trump-score/jerry-moran/ Tracking Jerry Moran in the Age of Trump], ''FiveThirtyEight'' (last accessed April 4, 2017). === Abortion === Moran opposes abortion.Steve Kraske, [http://www.kansas.com/news/politics-government/election/article1029580.html Moran, Tiahrt seen as more alike than at odds], ''Wichita Eagle'' (April 18, 2010).Dave Ranney, [http://www2.ljworld.com/news/2005/aug/12/antiabortion_leader_berates_shallenburgers_inclusi/ Anti-abortion leader berates Shallenburger’s inclusiveness], ''Lawrence Journal World'' (August 12, 2005). He has cosponsored legislation to ban abortions after the 20th week of pregnancy.James Rosen, [http://www.kansas.com/news/politics-government/article1127172.html Sen. Graham pushes measure to limit abortions], ''Wichita Eagle'' (November 7, 2013). === Gay rights === Moran opposes [[same-sex marriage in the United States|same-sex marriage]]. The [[Human Rights Campaign]] has rated his voting record as zero in five separate scorecards.{{cite web|title=Congressional Scorecard for the 107th Congress|year=2002|url=http://www.hrc.org/documents/2002scorecard.pdf|format=PDF|publisher=Human Rights Campaign, Inc|page=8|accessdate=22 November
