The third part presents a similar analysis for capital market liberalization. ===''Making Globalization Work'' (2006)=== ''[[Making Globalization Work]]'' surveys the inequities of the global economy, and the mechanisms by which developed countries exert an excessive influence over developing nations. Dr. Stiglitz argues that through tariffs, subsidies, an over-complex patent system and pollution, the world is being both economically and politically destabilised. Stiglitz argues that strong, transparent institutions are needed to address these problems. He shows how an examination of incomplete markets can make corrective government policies desirable. Stiglitz is an exception to the general pro-globalisation view of professional economists, according to economist [[Martin Wolf]]."Why Globalization Works" (Yale University Press 2004) {{ISBN|978-0-300-10252-9}}, p. 8. Also Wolf criticizes World Bank heavily (pp. xiii–xv). Stiglitz argues that economic opportunities are not widely enough available, that financial crises are too costly and too frequent, and that the rich countries have done too little to address these problems. ''Making Globalization Work''see {{YouTube|UzhD7KVs-R4|Stiglitz discuss his book}} has sold more than two million copies. ===''Fair Trade for All'' (2005)=== In ''Fair Trade for All'', authors Stiglitz and Andrew Charlton argue that it is important to make the trading world more development friendly.{{cite journal | last1 = Blandford | first1 = David | year = | title = review of ''Fair Trade for All'', by J.E. Stiglitz and Andrew Charlton | url = | journal = American Journal of Agricultural Economics | volume = 90 | issue = 2| page = 2008 }} The idea is put forth that the present regime of tariffs and agricultural subsidies is dominated by the interests of former colonial powers and needs to change. The removal of the bias toward the developed world will be beneficial to both developing and developed nations. The developing world is in needs of assistance, and this can only be achieved when developed nations abandon mercantilist based priorities and work towards a more liberal world trade regime.{{cite journal | last1 = Northcott | first1 = Michael S. | year = | title = review of ''Fair Trade For All'' by J.E. Stiglitz and Andrew Charlton | url = | journal = Studies in World Christianity | volume = 12 | issue = 3| page = 2006 }} ===''New Paradigm for Monetary Economics'' (2003)=== ===''The Roaring Nineties'' (2003)=== ''The Roaring Nineties'' is Stiglitz' analysis of the boom and bust of the 1990s. Presented from an insider's point of view, firstly as chair of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisors, and later as chief economist of the World Bank, it continues his argument on how misplaced faith in free-market ideology led to the global economic issues of today, with a perceptive focus on US policies. ===''Globalization and Its Discontents'' (2002)=== In ''[[Globalization and Its Discontents]]'', Stiglitz argues that what are often called "developing economies" are, in fact, not developing at all, and puts much of the blame on the IMF. Stiglitz bases his argument on the themes that his decades of theoretical work have emphasized: namely, what happens when people lack the key information that bears on the decisions they have to make, or when markets for important kinds of transactions are inadequate or don't exist, or when other institutions that standard economic thinking takes for granted are absent or flawed. Stiglitz stresses the point: "Recent advances in economic theory" (in part referring to his own work) "have shown that whenever information is imperfect and markets incomplete, which is to say always, and especially in developing countries, then the invisible hand works most imperfectly." As a result, Stiglitz continues, governments can improve the outcome by well-chosen interventions. Stiglitz argues that when families and firms seek to buy too little compared to what the economy can produce, governments can fight recessions and depressions by using expansionary monetary and fiscal policies to spur the demand for goods and services. At the microeconomic level, governments can regulate banks and other financial institutions to keep them sound. They can also use tax policy to steer investment into more productive industries and trade policies to allow new industries to mature to the point at which they can survive foreign competition. And governments can use a variety of devices, ranging from job creation to manpower training to welfare assistance, to put unemployed labor back to work and cushion human hardship. Stiglitz complains bitterly that the IMF has done great damage through the economic policies it has prescribed that countries must follow in order to qualify for IMF loans, or for loans from banks and other private-sector lenders that look to the IMF to indicate whether a borrower is creditworthy. The organization and its officials, he argues, have ignored the implications of incomplete information, inadequate markets, and unworkable institutions{{snd}} all of which are especially characteristic of newly developing countries. As a result, Stiglitz argues, the IMF has often called for policies that conform to textbook economics but do not make sense for the countries to which the IMF is recommending them. Stiglitz seeks to show that these policies have been disastrous for the countries that have followed them. ===''Whither Socialism?'' (1994) === ''[[Whither Socialism?]]'' is based on Stiglitz's Wicksell Lectures, presented at the [[Stockholm School of Economics]] in 1990 and presents a summary of [[information economics]] and the theory of markets with imperfect information and imperfect competition, as well as being a critique of both free market and market socialist approaches (see Roemer critique, op. cit.). Stiglitz explains how the [[neoclassical economics|neoclassical]], or [[Walrasian model]] ("Walrasian economics" refers to the result of the process which has given birth to a formal representation of [[Adam Smith]]'s notion of the "invisible hand", along the lines put forward by [[Léon Walras]] and encapsulated in the general equilibrium model of [[Arrow–Debreu model|Arrow–Debreu]]), may have wrongly encouraged the belief that [[market socialism]] could work. Stiglitz proposes an alternative model, based on the [[information economics]] established by the Greenwald–Stiglitz theorems. One of the reasons Stiglitz sees for the critical failing in the standard [[neoclassical economics|neoclassical model]], on which [[market socialism]] was built, is its failure to consider the problems that arise from lack of perfect information and from the costs of acquiring information. He also identifies problems arising from its assumptions concerning completeness.{{cite web|url=http://www.econ-pol.unisi.it/pubdocenti/HEI99.pdf |author=Zapia, Carlo |title=The economics of information, market socialism and Hayek's legacy |publisher=Dipartimento di Economia Politica, Università di Siena |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=October 29, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070614110711/http://www.econ-pol.unisi.it/pubdocenti/HEI99.pdf |archivedate=June 14, 2007 |df= }} ===Papers and conferences=== Stiglitz wrote a series of papers and held a series of conferences explaining how such information uncertainties may have influence on everything from unemployment to lending shortages. As the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers during the first term of the Clinton Administration and former chief economist at the [[World Bank]], Stiglitz was able to put some of his views into action. For example, he was an outspoken critic of quickly opening up financial markets in developing countries. These markets rely on access to good financial data and sound bankruptcy laws, but he argued that many of these countries didn't have the regulatory institutions needed to ensure that the markets would operate soundly. ==Awards and honors== In addition to being awarded the Nobel Memorial prize, Stiglitz has over 40 honorary doctorates and at least eight honorary professorships as well as an honorary deanship.[http://www2.gsb.columbia.edu/faculty/jstiglitz/download/Stiglitz_CV.pdf Curriculum Vitae] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110513134138/http://www2.gsb.columbia.edu/faculty/jstiglitz/download/Stiglitz_CV.pdf |date=2011-05-13 }}, Joseph E. Stiglitz{{cite web |url=http://www.dur.ac.uk/dbs/news/archive/?itemno=788 |title=Durham University Business School recognises Nobel Laureate winning economist |publisher=Durham University |date=September 23, 2005}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cerge-ei.cz/people/executive-and-supervisory-committee |title=CERGE-EI | Executive and Supervisory Committee | Governance Bodies | People Herald|date=21 April 2018}} ==Personal life== Stiglitz married Jane Hannaway in 1978; the couple later divorced.{{cite news|author=[ Displaying Abstract ] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1978/12/24/archives/dr-jane-hannaway-bride-of-joseph-stiglitz.html |title=Dr. Jane Hannaway Bride of Joseph Stiglitz |work=NYTimes.com |date=June 10, 2012 '''José Ignacio Hualde''' is a [[linguist]] from [[Navarre]],<ref>{{eu icon}} [http://www.euskadi.net/euskara_berripapera/euskera/26eus.pdf «Idatzitakoa nola ahoskatu eta mintzoaren soinua»] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110622055507/http://www.euskadi.net/euskara_berripapera/euskera/26eus.pdf |date=2011-06-22 }}, ''Euskararen Berripapera'', number 26, July 1994, page 3.</ref> specialised in [[Basque language|Basque]] linguistics and in [[Spanish language|Spanish]] synchronic and diachronic [[phonology]],<ref>[http://www.sip.illinois.edu/people/jihualde/ Web page on Dr Jose Ignacio Hualde] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100701153935/http://www.sip.illinois.edu/people/jihualde/ |date=2010-07-01 }} in the area of the Department of Spanish, Italian and Portuguese in the website of the University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign.</ref> professor of Linguistics and Latin American and Caribbean Studies<ref>[http://www.linguistics.illinois.edu/people/jihualde Web page on Dr Jose Ignacio Hualde] in the area of the Department of Linguistics in the website of the University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign</ref> in the Department of Spanish, Italian and Portuguese, and in the Department of Linguistics, at the [[University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign]].<ref>[https://netfiles.uiuc.edu/jihualde/www/ The page of professor José Ignacio Hualde] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100615112331/https://netfiles.uiuc.edu/jihualde/www/ |date=2010-06-15 }} in the website of the University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign</ref> He is also the current Vice President of the [[Association for Laboratory Phonology]].
== Bibliography == === Authored books === * ''Catalan'' (1992) * ''Basque Phonology'' (1991) * ''Euskararen azentuerak'' [the accentual systems of Basque] (1977)
=== Co-authored books === * ''The sounds of Spanish'' (2005) * ''Introducción a la lingüística hispánica'' (2001) * ''A Phonological Study of the Basque Dialect of Getxo'' (1992) * ''The Basque Dialect of Lekeitio'' (1994)
=== Co-edited books === * ''Generative Studies in Basque Linguistics'' (1993) * ''Towards a History of the Basque Language'' (1995) * ''A Grammar of Basque'' (2003)
=== Journal articles === * Hualde, José I. "Unstressed words in Spanish." Language Sciences 31.2-3 (2009): 199-212. * Hualde, José I., Oihana Lujanbio, and Francisco Torreira. "Lexical tone and stress in Goizueta Basque." ''Journal of the International Phonetic Association'' 38.1 (2008): 1-24. * Hualde, José I., Miquel Simonet, and Francisco Torreira. "Postlexical contraction of nonhigh vowels in Spanish." ''Lingua'' 118 (2008): 1906-1925. * Hualde, José I., and Armin Schwegler. "Intonation in Palenquero." ''Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages'' 23.1 (2008): 1-31. * Eddington, David, and José I. Hualde. "El abundante agua fría: Hermaphroditic Spanish nouns." ''Studies in Hispanic and Lusophone Linguistics'' 1.1 (2008): 5-31. * Chitoran, Ioana, and José I. Hualde. "From hiatus to diphthong: the evolution of vowel sequences in Romance." ''Phonology'' 24 (2007): 37-75. * Hualde, José I., and Koldo Zuazo. "The standardization process of the Basque language." ''Language Problems and Language Planning'' 31.2 (2007): 143-168. * Hualde, José I. "Stress removal and stress addition in Spanish." ''Journal of Portuguese Linguistics'' 5.2 (2006): 59-89.

And She's Getting Bigger: The Making of Britain's Latest Wild Child!|date=26 March 1995|work=The People|last=Stenson|first=Jules}} in [[London Borough of Brent|Brent]], [[Middlesex]]) is an English [[glamour model]], pornographic performer, and television personality who made her topless modelling debut in the ''[[Sunday Sport]]'' tabloid newspaper on her 16th birthday in 1994. Known for her naturally large 34GG breasts, she went on to feature in a wide range of adult magazines, websites, broadcast media, and videos, including [[hardcore pornography]] productions after 2000. She has attained minor celebrity status in the United Kingdom, where she has appeared on a number of mainstream television programmes, such as ''[[They Think It's All Over (TV series)|They Think It's All Over]]'', ''[[I'm Famous and Frightened!]]'', ''[[The Weakest Link]]'', and ''[[Four Weddings|Celebrity Four Weddings]]''. She has also appeared in documentaries about the lives of glamour models and was featured in [[Martin Gooch]]'s 2002 film ''Arthur's Amazing Things''. ==Career== In early 1994 when McKenzie was 15, she sent sample glamour photographs to local modelling agencies. She began her modelling career glamour modelling and swimsuit work, intending to progress to topless modelling when she turned 16 later that year.At the time, under the [[Protection of Children Act 1978]], 16-year-olds could legally model topless in the United Kingdom; the legal minimum age was raised to 18 by the [[Sexual Offences Act 2003]]. [[File:Linsey dawn mckenzie.JPG|thumb|upright|left|Linsey Dawn McKenzie at Erotica LA in 2006]] As McKenzie approached her 16th birthday, the ''[[Sunday Sport]]'' tabloid newspaper expressed an interest in turning her topless debut into a media event. Throughout June and July 1994, it published pictures of McKenzie counting down the days until it could legally show her topless.{{cite news|title=Glamour Model Says There's More to Her Than Just her 38GG assets|date=4 April 2004|work=Daily Mirror|last=Burniston|first=Julie|url=https://www.thefreelibrary.com/TRUTH+BEHIND+MY+PAP+PIX%3A+Linsey+Dawn+McKenzie+%60Jordan+was+a+good...-a0114896585|via=The Free Library}} After she turned 16, McKenzie continued to model topless for the ''[[Daily Sport]]'' and the ''Sunday Sport.'' She also made ''[[Page 3]]'' girl appearances in tabloid newspapers ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' and ''[[Daily Star (United Kingdom)|The Daily Star]]''; posed topless in [[lads' mags]] such as ''[[Loaded (magazine)|Loaded]]''; appeared fully nude in British magazines such as ''[[Mayfair (magazine)|Mayfair]]''''Mayfair,'' Vol. 30, Issue 3 (March 1995) and ''[[Men Only]]'';''Men Only'' Vol. 60, Issue 12 (December 1995) and performed in a variety of softcore videos. On 29 July 1995, shortly before her 17th birthday, McKenzie did a topless [[streaking|streak]] at a televised [[England cricket team|England]] v. [[West Indies cricket team|West Indies]] [[cricket]] match at [[Old Trafford (cricket)|Old Trafford]]. Wearing only a [[thong (clothing)|thong]] and a pair of [[athletic shoes|trainers]], she ran onto the field with the words "Only Teasing" written across her breasts.{{cite news|title=The Naked Truth About Streaking|date=9 July 2007|work=The Independent|last=McSmith|first=Andy}} After McKenzie turned 18 in 1996, she made her North American modelling debut in the [[breast fetishism]] magazine ''Score'', which marked the occasion by making McKenzie the [[cover girl]] of its December 1996 "50th Anniversary" issue.Graham, John, "Linsey: She's Finally Legal, and Now Everybody Can Enjoy This 18-Year-Old International Superstar!" ''Score'', Volume 5, Issue 12, pg. 22–30 (December 1996) In the late 1990s, McKenzie was frequently featured on the adult-oriented channels [[L!VE TV]] and [[Television X]]. She continued to appear regularly in magazines, DVDs, Internet sites, and broadcast media until late 2004, when she took a break from modelling to have a child and undergo a breast reduction operation. ==Appearances== [[File:D7K 1341 - Linsey Dawn McKenzie.jpg|thumb|upright|McKenzie at AVN Adult Entertainment Expo in 2011]] McKenzie's mainstream television appearances include the [[BBC]] sporting quiz show ''[[They Think It's All Over (TV series)|They Think It's All Over]]'', the reality television shows ''[[I'm Famous and Frightened!]]'' and ''[[The Salon]]'', and the science programme ''[[Brainiac: Science Abuse]].'' In the United States, she appeared on ''[[The Howard Stern Show]]'' in January 2003.{{cite web | url = http://www.linseysworld.biz/about/ | title = About: The girl they call "The Busty Legend" | accessdate =28 June 2011 }} On 8 September 2007, she appeared on a special charity edition of the BBC quiz show ''[[The Weakest Link]]'',{{IMDb episode|1140822|Wags and Glamour}} on which all contestants were glamour models who were dating or married to footballers.{{cite news|title=Laugh? We Could Have Cried|date=28 May 2008|work=Daily Mail|last=Platell|first=Amanda}} In December 2010, she featured with her husband Mark Williams on an episode of [[Living TV]]'s ''[[Four Weddings|Celebrity Four Weddings]]''. The episode also featured actress [[Tina Malone]], ''Big Brother'' contestant [[Spencer Smith (Big Brother)#Spencer|Spencer Smith]] and magician [[Paul Daniels]] and his wife, [[Debbie McGee]].{{cite web|url=http://www.livingtv.co.uk/shows/four-weddings/ |title=Celebrity Four Weddings official site |accessdate=7 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101225033028/http://www.livingtv.co.uk/shows/four-weddings/ |archivedate=25 December 2010 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.unrealitytv.co.uk/reality-tv/four-weddings-paul-daniels-debbie-mcgee-spencer-smith-tina-malone-and-lyndsey-dawn-mackenzie/|title=Four Weddings: Paul Daniels, Debbie McGee, Spencer Smith, Tina Malone and Lyndsey Dawn MacKenzie|accessdate=7 January 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101221225558/http://www.unrealitytv.co.uk/reality-tv/four-weddings-paul-daniels-debbie-mcgee-spencer-smith-tina-malone-and-lyndsey-dawn-mackenzie/|archivedate=21 December 2010|df=dmy-all}} Additionally, McKenzie has appeared in two documentaries about the lives of glamour models, ''The Curse of Page 3''{{IMDb title|0421123|The Curse of Page 3}} and ''Girls Behaving Badly.''{{cite news|title=Treasure Chests|date=25 January 2003|work=The Sun|last=Adams|first=Beth}}{{IMDb title|0588688|Girls Behaving Badly}} She also played the character Beryl Fforbes-Juggs in [[Martin Gooch]]'s 2002 film ''Arthur's Amazing Things''.{{IMDb title|0424808|Arthur's Amazing Things}} ==Personal life== McKenzie was born in [[London Borough of Brent|Brent]], [[Middlesex]] and grew up in [[Wallington, London|Wallington]], Surrey. She is the youngest of three children and her parents, Tony and Lesley McKenzie, divorced in 1987. In 1996 McKenzie became involved in an [[extramarital affair]] with 27-year-old footballer [[Dean Holdsworth]], who was then a [[Forward (football)|striker]] for [[Wimbledon F.C.]] The relationship received widespread attention in the British media.{{cite news|title=The Top 10 Footballers' Page 3 Playmates|date=15 January 2006|work=The Sunday Times|last=Aizelwood|first=John}} In 1998, she became engaged to actor [[Michael Greco (actor)|Michael Greco]], who at the time was playing the role of [[Beppe di Marco]] in the [[BBC]] soap opera ''[[EastEnders]]''.{{cite news|title=EastEnders Star to Wed Linsey Dawn McKenzie|date=29 August 1998|work=The Mirror|last=Grant|first=Clare}} She twice became pregnant over the course of her 15-month relationship with Greco, but miscarried both times.{{cite news|title=EastEnder Loses Baby|date=11 June 1999|work=The Mirror|last=Grant|first=Clare}} McKenzie began dating 21-year-old window cleaner Terry Canty in 2000. The couple married on 21 April 2001{{cite news|title=Linsey Dawn the Aisle|date=22 April 2001|work=The People|last=Murray|first=James}} and Canty performed with McKenzie in her first heterosexual hardcore photoshoots and video. Scenes featuring the couple were released on the 2001 DVD ''Ultimate Linsey.'' The couple separated six weeks after their wedding, and they divorced in 2001. In 2004, McKenzie began a relationship with former Wimbledon F.C. and [[Northern Ireland national football team|Northern Ireland]] footballer [[Mark Williams (Northern Irish footballer)|Mark Williams]]. On 16 May 2005, she gave birth to the couple's baby boy. McKenzie married Williams on 5 January 2006.{{cite news|title=Sexy Linsey's Wedded Bliss|date=8 January 2006|work=The People|last=Manley|first=Debbie}} ==See also== * [[List of British pornographic actors]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book|title=Temptress: The Linsey Dawn McKenzie Story|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=056EjgEACAAJ|first=Vikki|last=Dark|publisher=Chimera|year=2015|isbn=9781903136522}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Linsey Dawn McKenzie}} * {{IMDb name|0571566|Linsey Dawn McKenzie}} * {{iafd name|id=LindseyMcKenzie/gender=f/Linsey-McKenzie|gender=female|name=Linsey Dawn McKenzie}} * {{Bgafd name|l00087|Linsey Dawn McKenzie}} * {{afdb name|id=42557|gender=female|name=Linsey Dawn McKenzie}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:McKenzie, Linsey Dawn}} [[Category:English pornographic film actresses]] [[Category:English female adult models]] [[Category:Glamour models]] [[Category:Footballers' wives and girlfriends]] [[Category:Page 3 girls]] [[Category:1978 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Wallington, London]]

page.title: List of Pinoy Big Brother: All In housemates

revision.text:
The following is a list of contestants of ''[[Pinoy Big Brother: All In]]'', the fifth regular season of ''[[Pinoy Big Brother]]'', the Philippine version of the reality TV series ''Big Brother''.
The contestants are listed below in the order of their entry into the Big Brother House.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Blinkremz|title=Pinoy Big Brother (PBB) All In Housemates Profile Bios & Photos|url=http://philnews.ph/2014/04/28/pinoy-big-brother-pbb-all-in-housemates-profile-bios-photos/|website=www.philnews.ph|accessdate=23 August 2014}}</ref> {{TOC right}}
==Axel==
'''Alexander David Torres''' (born August 17, 1993<ref>http://www.candymag.com/cutiepedia/axel-torres</ref>) is a 21-year-old student of De La Salle University, and a former Candy Cutie in 2011. He is the eldest of seven siblings. He and his brother Thomas are both athletic scholars. In grade school and high school, he was part of the La Salle varsity team. When he reached college, he only made it to Team B unlike his brother Thomas who became the starting guard for La Salle Green Archers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb/housemates/profile/axel-torres |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-04-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140427142203/http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb/housemates/profile/axel-torres |archivedate=2014-04-27 |df= }}</ref> His stint inside the House was highlighted by his being emotional, and being close to female housemates [[Jane Oineza|Jane]] and Aina. He was evicted on Day 28.
==Jane== {{main article|Jane Oineza}} '''Elizabeth Jane Urbano Oineza''' (born July 22, 1996) is an actress and occasional TV host whose television career started when she was just a toddler. After a couple of TV commercials, she was cast to play the young Istah in [[Marina (Philippine TV series)|Marina]] and became a regular on [[Goin' Bulilit]]. After graduating from [[Goin' Bulilit]] and blossoming into a beautiful teen actress, she got meatier roles in different soap operas. She is now acknowledged as a serious artist after she bagged a Best Actress nomination in the 2013 New York Festivals for her role as "Nene" in a [[Maalaala Mo Kaya]] episode "Manika." <ref>http://www.philippineedition.com/2014/04/meet-female-housemates-of-pbb-all-in.html</ref> She is also a member of Star Magic Batch 2013 and an acknowledged breadwinner of the family, being the eldest. Her stint inside the House was controversial, as she was being disliked by fellow housemates calling her plastic, linked to several male housemates, including Joshua, among other things. She was awarded Third Big Placer.
==Cess==
'''Princess Mae Padilla Visitacion''' (born October 13, 1989<ref>https://www.facebook.com/pages/PBB-All-in-Housemate-Cess-Visitacion/301834466633215</ref>) is the breadwinner of their family. Her dad is a tricycle driver while her mother is a housewife. She has two younger brothers, and she dreams of sending them to school some day. She’s a certified ''raketera'' who would take on any job just to support her family – from peddling soap and other beauty products to taking on bit roles on TV and commercials. She was forcibly evicted on Day 21 as a result of numerous violations.
==Chevin==
'''Chevin Klein Cecilio''' is a 22-year-old property specialist.<ref>http://philippinenews.ph/pbb-all-in-chevin-klein-cecilio-impatikong-salesman/</ref> His family story is that of riches to rags because of a failed business venture. He is supposed to be in his first year as an IT student in college, but didn’t pursue schooling. He is now trying his luck in real estate sales. He has been single for the last three years because he is focusing on helping his family financially. He enjoys playing basketball with his brothers and friends during his free time. To the housemates, he was known for being short-tempered, having garnered most nomination points in his lone nomination. He was evicted on Day 21.
==Nichole==
'''Kim Nichole Baranda''' (born December 15, 1998<ref>http://philnews.ph/2014/04/28/pinoy-big-brother-pbb-all-in-housemates-profile-bios-photos/</ref>) is a 17-year-old student and daughter of TV host and celebrity, [[Phoemela Baranda]]. She was raised by her grandmother and didn’t become close to her mom until her grandmother died in 2009. She is a second year high school student at Colegio de San Agustin and is a part of the CSA Dance Troupe.<ref>http://www.philippineedition.com/2014/04/meet-female-housemates-of-pbb-all-in.html</ref> She is close friends with [[Loisa Andalio|Loisa]] and Maris. She and fellow teen housemate [[Manolo Pedrosa|Manolo]] have mutual admirations toward one another. She was evicted on Day 64.
==Aina==
'''Maina "Aina" Solano''' (birth name Maina Tutt) was born and raised in Boracay before her family moved to Switzerland when she was 8. She worked as an encoder and saleslady in Geneva and one of her passions was dancing. She became a dance teacher for kids. Due to her heartbreaking experience with her first boyfriend, she decided to go back to Boracay and worked as a mermaid swimming teacher. She is known for being upfront and outspoken, which caused her to have a rift with other housemates. She was evicted on Day 42.
==Joshua== {{main article|Joshua Garcia}} '''Joshua Espinelli Garcia<ref>http://www.pinoyexchange.com/forums/showthread.php?t=716898</ref>''' (born October 7, 1997) is an 18-year-old out-of-school youth born and raised in Bauan, Batangas. He temporarily stopped schooling. He was involved in a love triangle between himself, Jane and Loisa. He was evicted on Day 113. He portrayed the role of "Joel Galvez" in Nasaan Ka Nang Kailangan Kita, in his role first he is in love with Corrine (played by Jane Oineza) but later fell in love with Bea Natividad (played by Loisa Andalio) In the end Joel and Bea have their happily ever after. Rumor has it, that he is still in love with Jane Oineza. They say that Joshua will make the crowd wild because of his dance moves.
==Jayme==
'''Jayme Ann Jemimah Jalandoni''' (born March 30, 1991) is a 24-year-old nurse. She grew up in a conservative and religious family. She has two sisters and a brother. She’s very close to her mom but often consults her dad whenever she needs advise on anything. She loves to draw and paint. She wanted to study fine arts but pursued a degree in nursing. She was the subject of the nude painting task that caused controversy during her stint in the house. She was evicted on Day 57 as a result of the All Out twist along with Michelle.
==Manolo==
'''Manolo Pedrosa''' (born October 20, 1997) is a 17-year-old student and commercial model of Candy Magazine 2013. He used to study at La Salle Greenhills. His family owns a business importing and exporting ham products. He is well-liked by the housemates because of his natural charming eyes. He was evicted on Day 106.
==Maris== {{main article|Maris Racal}} '''Mariestella Canedo Racal''' (born September 22, 1997) is a 19-year-old student from Tagum City. She grew up in a musically inclined close-knit family. Both her parents sing and her dad also plays the guitar. But she learned how to play the guitar on her own by watching videos on the internet – the same way she learned how to play the piano and ukulele. She garnered 3.10% of the net votes on finale night, making her the runner-up for the season.She is also a member of a girlgroup : Girltrends
==Ranty==
'''Ranty Portento''' is a 26-year-old assistant waiter on a cruise ship. He was born and raised in Candelaria, Quezon. He wasn’t able to enter college due to financial difficulty. Instead, he finished a 2-year vocational course in hotel and restaurant management, which led to him becoming a seaman. He had been travelling around the world. He was evicted on Day 56 as a result of the All Out twist.
==Michele== {{main article|Michele Gumabao}} '''Michele Theresa Gumabao''' (born September 2, 1992) is a 22-year-old host, commercial model and a former collegiate star of the DLSU Lady Spikers, with an MVP award for Women’s Volleyball under her belt from the 75th UAAP Season. During her term in DLSU, she did not only deliver on the court, but was also a consistent Dean’s Lister until she graduated with a degree in Marketing Management. Her dad is former actor-politician turned pastor, [[Dennis Roldan]] and she has a younger brother, teen actor Marco Gumabao. Inside the house, she showed her strong leadership skills, which irritated some of the housemates, especially the teens. She was evicted on Day 57 as a result of the All Out twist.
==Jacob== {{main article|Jacob Benedicto}} '''Josemari Jacob Gayanelo''' (born April 29, 1992) is a 23-year-old singer and theater actor. He grew up in Indonesia where he first discovered his gift of music. He is now a graduating student with AB Communications degree at De La Salle University. He used to audition for [[Kanta Pilipinas]] and [[The Voice Philippines]]. He was evicted on Day 35.
==Loisa== {{main article|Loisa Andalio}} '''Josefina Loisa Francisco Andalio ''' (born April 21, 1999) was part of a sing-and-dance girl group called 3G that performed in mall shows and fiestas. She grew up in Paranaque with her parents and siblings, the second child among three. She was evicted on Day 119. After PBB, Loisa got her first teleserye Nasaan Ka nang Kailangan Kita, portraying the role of Bea Natividad. Also topbilled by Vina Morales, Christian Vasquez, Denise Laurel, Jane Oinesa, Joshua Garcia and Jerome Ponce. Loisa Andalio is now a brand ambassador of Surplus Clothing. Also, she has been recognized with multiple awards and nominations on online/polls. She has also been nominated for PUSH Awards Most Favorite Newcomer, RAWR Awards Breakthrough Artist of the Year, and 2015 PMPC Star Awards For TV as Best New Female TV Personality. She loves her fans including (LoiYals, LoiNie, LoiShua, LoiVes, ManoLoisa, NicoLoi, LoiRome and LoiRis). Currently, she is a member of a girl group from It's Showtime named GirlTrends.
==Fourth==
'''Roberto "Robert" Solomon Pagotan IV''' (born February 5, 1992) is a 23-year-old chef who works at one of the restaurants in a 5-star hotel in the country. During his stint in the house, he served as their main "chef" and also a "big brother" to his twin, Fifth. He was evicted on Day 85.
==Fifth==
'''Roberto "Bobby" Solomon Pagotan V''' (born February 5, 1992) is a 23-year-old businessman who owned a humble hamburger stall. He became a YouTube sensation, having uploaded short films and videos of his pranks. In 2009, he joined the reality competition [[Are You the Next Big Star?]] and made it to the Circle of 16. During his stay inside the House, he came out as bisexual. LGBTQ Rule. He, together with his twin brother Fourth, entered the House as separate housemates. He was evicted on Day 98.
==Vickie== {{main article|Vickie Rushton}} '''Vickie Marie Milagrosa Sausa Rushton''' (born May 8, 1992) is a half-Pinay, half-British Bacolod-based model who also wants to pursue a career as a flight attendant so she can travel. She joins beauty pageants for the prize money and to make her visually impaired mother proud. In 2011, she bagged the Mutya ng Pilipinas International title. She is in a relationship with actor [[Jason Abalos]] and they’ve been together for almost a year now. Inside the house, she was initially shy eerily silent, having been voted at one point as the least important regular housemate. But she became controversial after she admitted that she was not happy with her relationship with [[Jason Abalos|Jason]] and became close to fellow housemate [[Daniel Matsunaga|Daniel]]. She has since resolved her issues with [[Jason Abalos|Jason]] after she invited the latter to visit her inside the House. She garnered -0.78% of the net votes on the Big Night, ranking her fourth for this season.
==Daniel== {{main article|Daniel Matsunaga}} '''Daniel Kenji Matsunaga''' (born November 28, 1988) is a Brazilian-Japanese model and actor. He rose to fame after appearing in Cosmo’s September 2009 Men supplement issue. His father is pure Japanese but was born and raised in Brazil, while his mother is Brazilian. Before he decided to live in the Philippines, he lived in 25 countries. Longest countries he lived in are Philippines, Hong Kong, Thailand, Korea and Singapore. He and his sister left Brazil when they were 18 and 16 respectively, to pursue a career in modelling. He entered the House on Day 21 as a replacement housemate, after Cess was forcibly evicted. Inside the House, he was well-liked by the housemates for his positive demeanor, do-it-all attitude and humble personality. He emerged as the Big Winner of the season, garnering 11.69% of the net votes on finale night.
==Cheridel==
'''Cheridel Alejandrino''' (born March 27, 1986) is a 28-year-old elevator attendant at SM Olongapo City. She only finished second grade in school and has tried odd and various jobs ever since—from peddling ice candy on the streets making P100 per day to becoming a break time reliever making barely P350 per day. She recently rose to fame as the "Elevator Girl" after a video of her entertaining mall guests in the elevator went viral across local and global social media. She entered the house on Day 49 following [[Alex Gonzaga]]'s exit. She was evicted on Day 78.

{{refimprove|date=September 2015}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''Pop Idol'' finalists (series 1)}} ''[[Pop Idol]]'' was a British interactive [[reality television|reality]] [[talent show]]. The [[Pop Idol (series 1)|first series]] was broadcast on [[ITV Network|ITV]] between 6 October 2001 and 9 February 2002. The series saw a series of auditions for aspiring singers, with a final 50 performing in a series of five pre-recorded shows. Two contestants from each show went through to make up a final 10, who performed live in front of a studio audience.
One contestant who received the least votes from television viewers left the show each week. [[Will Young]] won the competition, beating [[Gareth Gates]] in the final on 9 February 2002.
==Finalists== ===Aaron Bayley=== Aaron Bayley was originally a train driver who came from [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle]]. At 26 years old, he was the oldest of the series finalists. He was eliminated in the third week of the finals, despite never previously appearing in the bottom two or three. Bayley is now a member of reality group G*Mania.<ref>[http://www.gmania.co.uk/the_artists.html G*Mania] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101208052516/http://www.gmania.co.uk/the_artists.html |date=2010-12-08 }}</ref>
===Zoe Birkett=== {{main|Zoe Birkett}} Zoe Birkett from [[County Durham]] was the youngest finalist, aged 16. She was the highest placed female in the series, finishing in fourth place. After the show, she scored a top 20 single, and has appeared in many stage musicals.
===Darius Danesh=== {{main|Darius Campbell}}
Darius Danesh, (aged 21) from [[Glasgow]] was already known to the public after an embarrassing audition on ''[[Popstars (UK)|Popstars]]''. He was originally eliminated from the competition in the top 50 stage, after failing to appear in the top 2 from his group, but he was given a reprieve when Rik Waller dropped out of the competition. He then went on to finish third in the competition, and scored a platinum selling album, and a number one single.
===Laura Doherty=== Laura Doherty, (aged 19) came from [[Derry]] in [[Northern Ireland]]. She was in the bottom two or three every week until her elimination in the fourth week of the finals.
===Hayley Evetts=== {{main|Hayley Evetts}} Hayley Evetts, (aged 25) from [[Birmingham]] was also known to the public after appearing on [[Popstars]] where she made the later stages. She went on to host several television presenting jobs, but failed to gain a record deal and has not released any material post show.
===Jessica Garlick=== {{main|Jessica Garlick}} [[File:Jessica Garlick.jpg|thumb|right|114px|Jessica Garlick]] Originating from [[Kidwelly]] in South Wales, 20-year-old Jessica Garlick placed 9th in the show. She went on to represent the [[United Kingdom]] in the 2002 [[Eurovision Song Contest 2002|Eurovision Song Contest]], where she placed joint 3rd, a result which remains the UK's best performance in the competition since 1998.
===Gareth Gates=== {{main|Gareth Gates}} Gareth Gates, (aged 17) from [[Bradford]] was the runner-up of the series. The widely accepted frontrunner, Gates spoke with a stammer, but it didn't affect him when he sang. He went on to release 4 number one singles, and three top 20 albums once the show was over.
===Korben=== Twenty-one-year-old Korben, (born Chris Niblett) was the first finalist to be eliminated from the show. In the week leading up to his elimination, he was [[Coming out|outed]] by tabloid newspapers, which led to speculation that this had hurt his chances in the competition.
===Rosie Ribbons=== {{main|Rosie Ribbons}} Rosie Ribbons (aged 18) is from [[Alltwen]] in South Wales. She was a favourite of judge [[Pete Waterman]], and made him cry at her initial audition. She signed to [[Telstar Records]] after the show, but her debut album was scrapped due to financial difficulties at the company. Ribbons did however release two top 20 singles in the UK. In 2007 she was a semi-finalist in [[Australian Idol]] after moving abroad, but failed to make the finals.
===Rik Waller=== {{main|Rik Waller}} Rik Waller from [[Gillingham, Kent|Gillingham]] in [[Kent]] was forced to resign from the competition after losing his voice. An early tip to win the show, he was given a bye to the second live show, but with his voice failing to improve he was unable to participate and had to leave. He was replaced by Darius Danesh. After the show ended, he appeared on reality shows [[Back to Reality (TV series)|Back to Reality]] and [[Celebrity Fit Club]] and released two singles.
===Will Young=== {{main|Will Young}} [[File:Will Young 2011.jpg|thumb|right|109px|Will Young]] Will Young, (aged 22) from [[Wokingham]], [[Berkshire]] won the competition. He was widely seen as the dark horse to win the title, but after the show was over, he was revealed to have led the voting several times. Post show, Young has gone on to have a lengthy music career, and as of 2009 has released four albums, all of which have reached the top 2, as well as achieving four number one singles.

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''The Apprentice'' candidates (UK series 9)}} {{The Apprentice UK candidate list}} {{Main|The Apprentice (UK series nine)}}
==Jaz Ampaw-Farr== Age: 41; Occupation: Literacy and Education Company Director.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p017h0j7/profiles/jaz-ampaw-farr |title=Series nine candidates: Jaz Ampaw-Farr |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2014-01-07}}</ref>
Ampaw-Farr described herself as "half machine. I can process things at a speed that is out of this world!", "I'm superwoman", and "the Brad Pitt of the Teacher Training Industry".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p017h0j7/profiles/jaz-ampaw-farr |title=BBC One - The Apprentice, Series 9 - Jaz Ampaw-Farr |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2014-01-07}}</ref> Despite these claims Ampaw-Farr was fired after the first task and became the first female project manager to be fired on the first task.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/youre-fired-jaz-ampawfarr-the-first-apprentice-to-face-lord-sugars-axe-says-she-felt-like-a-naughty-schoolgirl-8606629.html | title=You're fired Jaz Ampaw-Farr! The first Apprentice to face Lord Sugar's axe says she felt like a naughty schoolgirl | work=The Independent | date=8 May 2013 | accessdate=11 April 2014 | author=Lloyd, Albertina}}</ref> She was the only candidate that Tim Stillwell never worked with during the series.
At the time of her appearance on the show, Ampaw-Farr was 41, making her the oldest ever contestant to take part in the show, beating out [[List of The Apprentice candidates (UK series one)#Matthew Palmer|Matthew Palmer]] from Series 1 and [[List of The Apprentice candidates (UK series two)#Mani Sandher|Mani Sandher]] from Series 2, who were both 39 during their time on the show respectively. This would be beaten two years later by [[List of The Apprentice candidates (UK series eleven)#Ruth Whiteley|Ruth Whiteley]] from Series 11, who was 47 during her time on the show.
==Neil Clough== Age: 32; Occupation: Regional Manager - Soccer Centres.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p017h0j7/profiles/neil-clough |title=Series nine candidates: Neil Clough |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2014-01-07}}</ref>
Clough was educated at [[Woolston School|Woolston High School]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.warringtonguardian.co.uk/news/11297437.Ex_Apprentice_man_Neil_set_for_Peace_Centre_challenge/|title=Ex Apprentice man Neil set for Peace Centre challenge|work=Warrington Guardian|date=29 June 2014|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> a former comprehensive school in [[Woolston, Cheshire|Woolston]], a suburb of the city of [[Warrington, Cheshire|Warrington]] in [[Cheshire]] in [[Northern England]].
Early in the process, Karren Brady labelled Clough a "backseat driver", as he never volunteered to be project manager, though always ended up leading in some way. In week 4 Clough led his team to a loss, though survived based on past performance. He later won two other tasks as project manager - one being an overwhelming victory. In the Interviews stage of the process, [[Claude Littner]] said that Clough could not make his business idea work, but Clough continued to insist that he could make it work. [[Alan Sugar|Lord Sugar]] regrettably fired Clough for his obstinate nature, though was saddened to do so.
==Sophie Lau== Age: 22; Occupation: [[Restaurateur]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p017h0j7/profiles/sophie-lau |title=Series nine candidates: Sophie Lau |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2014-01-07}}</ref>
Lau was educated at [[Bristol Grammar School]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/Bristol-Apprentice-star-Sophie-Lau-makes-round/story-18921592-detail/story.html|title=Bristol Apprentice star Sophie Lau makes it through the first round|work=Bristol Post|author=Louis Emanuel|date=8 May 2013|accessdate=22 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129035223/http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/Bristol-Apprentice-star-Sophie-Lau-makes-round/story-18921592-detail/story.html#|archive-date=29 November 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> an [[independent school]] in the [[Tyndalls Park]] area in the centre of the city of [[Bristol]] in [[South West England]].
Lau described herself as having "raw talent, the drive and the competitive streak", but was fired in week 3.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p017h0j7/profiles/sophie-lau |title=BBC One - The Apprentice, Series 9 - Sophie Lau |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2014-01-07}}</ref>
==Jason Leech== Age: 29; Occupation: [[Historian]] and [[Real estate entrepreneur|Property Entrepreneur]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p017h0j7/profiles/jason-leech |title=Series nine candidates: Jason Leech |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2014-01-07}}</ref>
Leech was educated at [[Elliott School (London)|Elliott School]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.putneysw15.com/shared/issueelliottopenlet001.htm|title=Open Letter to the Prime Minister|work=PutneySW15.com|date=10 September 2013|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> a former state comprehensive school in [[Putney]] in South West London, which closed in 2012, followed by [[Wadham College, Oxford|Wadham College]] at the [[University of Oxford]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wadham.ox.ac.uk/about-wadham/famous-wadhamites|title=Famous Wadhamites|work=Wadham College, University of Oxford|date=17 July 2013|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> and [[King's College London]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://kcl.academia.edu/JasonLeech|title=Jason Leech|work=Academia.edu|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref>
Fired in week 8. Lord Sugar stating that Leech is an "awfully nice fellow, but it was time for (him) to go". In week 8 he became the first project manager to resign his position after being repeatedly pushed over by Luisa.
==Francesca MacDuff-Varley== Age: 32; Occupation: Dance and Entertainment Entrepreneur.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p017h0j7/profiles/francesca-macduff-varley |title=Series nine candidates: Francesca MacDuff-Varley |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2014-01-07}}</ref>
Macduff-Varley was educated at [[Outwood Grange Academy]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wakefieldexpress.co.uk/news/local-news/apprentice-star-and-former-outwood-grange-pupil-francesca-fired-by-lord-sugar-on-the-apprentice-1-5843231|title=Apprentice star and former Outwood Grange pupil Francesca fired by Lord Sugar on The Apprentice|work=Wakefield Express|date=11 July 2013|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> a comprehensive school with Academy status in the town of [[Outwood, West Yorkshire|Outwood]] (near [[Wakefield]]), in [[West Yorkshire]].
MacDuff-Varley claimed that her business had a turnover of 5 million pounds, whereas the actual turnover was 50,000. MacDuff-Varley was fired in week 11, albeit with regret from Lord Sugar, coming third place in the competition.
==Alex Mills== Age: 22; Occupation: Former Company Director.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p017h0j7/profiles/alex-mills |title=Series nine candidates: Alex Mills |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2014-01-07}}</ref>
Mills was educated at [[Cowbridge Comprehensive School]], a state comprehensive school in the [[market town]] of [[Cowbridge]] in the [[Vale of Glamorgan]] in [[South Wales]].
Mills claimed that "I’m the new breed of businessman that this process requires". Mills volunteered to be project manager a number of times, but was not selected. Eventually, in week 9, Lord Sugar made him project manager, and Mills led the team to a loss leading Lord Sugar to fire Mills.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p01byhyl |title=BBC One - The Apprentice, Series 9, Ready Meals, Alex Mills - Matt Edmondson's Awkward Conversations |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2013-06-26 |accessdate=2014-01-07}}</ref>
==Myles Mordaunt== Age: 39; Occupation: Marketing Company Co-Founder.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p017h0j7/profiles/myles-mordaunt |title=Series nine candidates: Myles Mordaunt |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2014-01-07}}</ref>
Mordaunt was educated at Burford Primary School,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maidenhead-advertiser.co.uk/News/Areas/Marlow-Bourne-End-Flackwell/The-Apprentice-Bad-taste-left-in-Myles-mouth-after-ready-meal-fail-27062013.htm|title=The Apprentice: Bad taste left in Myles' mouth after ready-meal fail|work=Maidenhead Advertiser|author=Lucy Golding|date=27 June 2013|accessdate=22 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130630215941/http://www.maidenhead-advertiser.co.uk/News/Areas/Marlow-Bourne-End-Flackwell/The-Apprentice-Bad-taste-left-in-Myles-mouth-after-ready-meal-fail-27062013.htm#|archive-date=30 June 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> a state primary school in the large village of [[Marlow Bottom]] in [[Buckinghamshire]], followed by [[Sir William Borlase's Grammar School]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maidenhead-advertiser.co.uk/News/Areas/Marlow-Bourne-End-Flackwell/Myles-Mordaunt-back-on-track-with-win-in-online-dating-task-20062013.htm|title=Myles Mordaunt back on track with win in online dating task|work=Maidenhead Advertiser|author=Lucy Golding|date=20 June 2013|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> a state grammar school, close to the centre of the town of [[Marlow, Buckinghamshire|Marlow]] (also in Buckinghamshire), in [[South East England]].
Mordaunt claimed "I’m business perfection personified". Mordaunt had a successful track record, being on the winning team for six consecutive weeks, and only being in the final boardroom twice in the last two weeks, before the interviews stage. However, Lord Sugar stated that he could not build a business, and fired him in week 10.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p017h0j7/profiles/myles-mordaunt |title=BBC One - The Apprentice, Series 9 - Myles Mordaunt |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2014-01-07}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2355142/Lord-Sugar-fires-Myles-Mordaunt-Week-10-The-Apprentice-losing-smell-sells-task.html|title= Lord Sugar fires Myles Mordaunt in Week 10 of The Apprentice after losing 'smell what sells' task|date=3 July 2013|work=Daily Mail|accessdate=4 July 2013 }}</ref> During his time on the show, he gained the nickname "Mr. Monaco" because he lived in Monaco.
==Natalie Panayi== Age: 30; Occupation: Recruitment Manager.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p017h0j7/profiles/natalie-panayi |title=Series nine candidates: Natalie Panayi |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2014-01-07}}</ref>
Panayi was educated at [[St Clement Danes School]],<ref name=HertLife>{{cite web|url=http://www.hertfordshirelife.co.uk/people/celebrity-interviews/croxley_green_apprentice_star_natalie_panayi_discusses_life_after_sugar_1_2594139|title=Croxley Green Apprentice star Natalie Panayi discusses life after Sugar|work=Hertfordshire Life|date=16 September 2014|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> a state comprehensive school in the village of [[Chorleywood]] in [[Hertfordshire]], in [[South East England]], followed by the [[Italia Conti Stage School]],<ref name=HertLife/> an [[independent school]] in London.
Panayi stated that "When it comes to business, I am the complete package and when it comes to sales, I’m the best." but was fired for failing the week 7 sales task. Panayi also stated that "Lord Sugar could learn from me". Lord Sugar disagreed and stated that Panayi "overestimates her abilities".
==Jordan Poulton== Age: 26; Occupation: Sales & Marketing Director, [[Makers Academy]].
Poulton was educated at Bramcote Preparatory School,<ref name=ZInfo>{{cite web|url=http://www.zoominfo.com/s/#!search/profile/person?personId=1337837227&targetid=profile|title=JordanPoulton|work=ZoomInfo|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> a former [[independent school]] for boys in the suburb of [[Bramcote]] in [[Nottinghamshire]] and [[Oundle School]],<ref name=ZInfo/> a boarding independent school in the town of [[Oundle]] in [[Northamptonshire]], followed by [[Worcester College, Oxford|Worcester College]] at the [[University of Oxford]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oxfordstudent.com/2013/05/16/worcester-graduate-aims-to-be-the-next-apprentice/|title=WORCESTER GRADUATE AIMS TO BE THE NEXT APPRENTICE|work=The Oxford Student|date=16 May 2013|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref>
Despite having the best record of anyone in the series, winning 7 out of the 10 previous tasks, during the interview stage Littner described Poulton as a 'parasite', citing that Poulton technically didn't own any share of the tech-startup business he claimed to be an existing partner of. The interview terminated early. Poulton also claimed to be able to solve a Rubik's cube in 3 minutes, however failed to do so during another interview. He was fired in Week 11, coming fifth place in the competition.
==Zeeshaan Shah== Age: 27; Occupation: CEO of Property Investment Company.<ref>http://oneinvestments.co.uk</ref>
Shah was born in the town of [[Doncaster]], in [[South Yorkshire]] in [[Northern England]], but moved to the city of [[Karachi]], in [[Pakistan]], from the ages of eight to nineteen. He then returned to the UK and attended a Sixth Form College in his birth town of Doncaster, followed by the [[University of Nottingham]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zeeshah.com/#!/page_company|title=Zeeshaan Shah - Biography|work=ZeeShah.com|accessdate=23 November 2014}}</ref>
Shah described himself as "I’m a ‘Great’ of my generation. I’m an innovator and leader in business. I take inspiration from Napoleon; I am here to conquer", and stated that "Zeeshaan Shah will go down in history". He also has a self-declared IQ of 137.<ref name="bbc.co.uk">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p019nqj0 |title=BBC One - The Apprentice, Series 9, Dubai, Zeeshaan Shah - Matt Edmondson's Awkward Conversations |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2013-05-28 |accessdate=2014-01-07}}</ref> He was fired after losing as project manager in the week 5.<ref name="zs">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p017h0j7/profiles/zeeshaan-shah |title=BBC One - The Apprentice, Series 9 - Zeeshaan Shah |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2014-01-07}}</ref>
==Rebecca Slater== Age: 35; Occupation: Pharmaceutical Sales Rep.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p017h0j7/profiles/rebecca-slater |title=Series nine candidates: Rebecca Slater |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2014-01-07}}</ref>
Slater was educated at [[Broughton High School, Lancashire|Broughton High School]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lep.co.uk/what-s-on/tv/new-venture-for-ex-apprentice-star-rebecca-slater-1-5746924|title=New venture for ex-Apprentice star Rebecca Slater|work=[[Lancashire Evening Post]]|date=7 June 2013|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> a state comprehensive school in the village of [[Broughton, Lancashire|Broughton]], near the city of [[Preston, Lancashire|Preston]], in [[Lancashire]], in [[North West England]].
Slater claimed that "I’m a pretty tough person. I don’t let people walk all over me in life or in business. And if somebody crosses me, it’s game over." Slater was the best sales-woman in week one and the best seller out of all of the candidates. Despite being brought back into the boardroom in week 2, she was the best seller in the out of all the candidates. She was fired for being the cause of the team's overspend in week 6, and for having no skills other than sales. After being fired Slater claimed that she did not deserve to get fired because she is "very good".
==Tim Stillwell== Age: 23; Occupation: Mexican Food Entrepreneur. Fired in week 2.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p017h0j7/profiles/tim-stillwell |title=Series nine candidates: Tim Stillwell |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2014-01-07}}</ref>
Stillwell was educated at [[Salesian College (Farnborough)|Salesian College]],<ref name=GS>{{cite web|url=http://www.getsurrey.co.uk/whats-on/find-things-to-do/apprentice-contestant-bouncing-back-burritos-4721811|title=Apprentice contestant bouncing back with burritos|work=Get Surrey|author=Jennifer Morris|date=17 May 2013|accessdate=23 November 2014}}</ref> a Roman Catholic [[independent school]] in the town of [[Farnborough, Hampshire|Farnborough]] in [[Hampshire]] in [[South East England]], and [[Godalming College]],<ref name=GS/> a Sixth Form College in the [[market town]] of [[Godalming]] (near [[Guildford]]) in [[Surrey]], followed by the [[University of Birmingham]].
==Leah Totton== {{Main|Leah Totton}} Age: 24; Occupation: Doctor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p017h0j7/profiles/leah-totton |title=Series nine candidates: Leah Totton |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2014-01-07}}</ref>
Totton was educated at Lisnagelvin Primary School,<ref name=DMail>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2370837/Dr-Leah-Tottons-mystery-company-investigated-Apprentice-backlash-grows.html|title=How Alan Sugar's Botox Queen gave her CV a nip and tuck: As Apprentice backlash grows, we investigate the mystery company 'Dr Leah' claimed to have set up|work=Daily Mail|author=Natalie Clarke|date=19 July 2013|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> a state primary school in the town of Lisnagelvin in [[County Londonderry]] in [[Northern Ireland]], followed by [[Foyle College|Foyle and Londonderry College]],<ref name=DMail/> a voluntary grammar school, also in County Londonderry.
Despite having little previous business experience, during week 11, Lord Sugar stated how Totton had learned the most and had good business knowledge. She ultimately won at the final, on 17 July 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2367452/The-Apprentice-2013-winner-Leah-Totton-beats-Luisa-Zissman-final-cosmetic-clinics-plans.html|title= HS doctor Leah Totton WINS The Apprentice after impressing Lord Sugar with her plans for cosmetic clinics... beating Luisa Zissman in all-female final|date=17 July 2013|work=Daily Mail|accessdate=30 July 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/reviews/the-apprentice-2013-tv-review-leah-totton-beats-luisa-zissman-8714775.html|title= The Apprentice 2013 TV review: Leah Totton beats Luisa Zissman|date=17 July 2013|work=The Independent|accessdate=30 July 2013 }}</ref>
==Kurt Wilson== Age: 26; Occupation: Health Drink Entrepreneur & Health and Safety Manager.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p017h0j7/profiles/kurt-wilson|title=Series nine candidates: Kurt Wilson|work=BBC}}</ref>
Wilson was educated at [[Holy Family Catholic High School, Thornton|Holy Family Catholic High School]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/local-news/blundellsands-businessman-kurt-wilson-talks-6957334|title=Blundellsands businessman Kurt Wilson talks about his experiences on The Apprentice|work=Liverpool Echo|date=20 June 2013|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> a [[voluntary aided school|voluntary aided]] Roman Catholic state comprehensive school in the village of [[Thornton, Merseyside|Thornton]] in [[Merseyside]], in [[North West England]].
Wilson described himself as "I’m an alpha male; I always get my own way and know how to make people do what I want.", but was fired for leading his team to a loss in week 7. Wilson was criticised for "terrible sexism" when he described Totton as "eye candy".<ref name="telegraph">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/the-apprentice/10116972/The-Apprentice-episode-7-BBC-One-review.html|title=The Apprentice, episode 7, BBC One, review|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|accessdate=17 June 2013}}</ref> He made a grave error when prompting PM Zeeshaan Shah with the wrong size for a flag of the United Arab Emirates, assuming that 1 foot was 12 centimetres and was blamed by PM Neil Clough in Week 4 who said he should be fired for the failure of the farm shop task.
==Uzma Yakoob== Age: 32; Occupation: Entrepreneur and Make Up Brand Owner.
Yakoob was educated at [[The Green School|The Green School for Girls]], a state comprehensive school in [[Isleworth]], in West London, followed by the [[London College of Fashion]].
Yakoob said that she was going to make millions, and that Lord Sugar would not be disappointed in her, but was fired in week 4.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p017h0j7/profiles/uzma-yakoob|title=Series nine candidates: Uzma Yakoob|work=BBC}}</ref>
==Luisa Zissman== {{Main|Luisa Zissman}} Age: 25; Occupation: Retail Entrepreneur.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p017h0j7/profiles/luisa-zissman|title=Series nine candidates: Luisa Zissman|work=BBC}}</ref> Zissman claimed to have a "brain like Einstein", yet got a C, D, and E at AS level.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episode/b036wfyz/The_Apprentice_Series_9_Interviews/|title=BBC One - The Apprentice, Series 9, Interviews|work=BBC}}</ref>
Zissman was educated at [[Northampton High School, Northamptonshire|Northampton High School for Girls]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/youre-fired-apprentice-beauty-luisa-1883958|title=You're FIRED: Apprentice beauty Luisa Zissman dumps co-star Jordan Poulton|work=Daily Mirror|author=Katie Hind|date=11 May 2013|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> an [[independent school]] in the village of [[Hardingstone]] in [[Northamptonshire]].
During the process, Luisa came across as very arrogant and pushy. In week 8, she forced Project Manager [[Jason|Jason Leech]] to give up his position as PM and let her be PM. They went on to lose the task and Lord Sugar didn't like what Luisa was like throughout the task. Despite this, he allowed to stay in the process, but didn't want to see her in the final three again. In weeks 9 & 10, Lord Sugar, Nick and Karren were very impressed with Luisa. Zissman made it to the final and came second, losing to [[Leah Totton]].Zissman said that during the process she had "learnt to keep her mouth shut".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p01cy112|title=BBC One - The Apprentice, Series 9, The Final and You're Hired, Luisa Zissman - Matt Edmondson's Awkward Conversations|work=BBC}}</ref>

'''Logan Mitchell''' (1802-1881) was a British [[Freethought|freethinker]] and writer.[[Joseph Mazzini Wheeler|Wheeler, Joseph Mazzini]]. (1889). ''A Biographical Dictionary of Freethinkers of All Ages and Nations''. London: Progressive Publishing Company. p. 229 Mitchell is best known for his book ''The Christian Mythology Unveiled''. Mitchell [[Suicide|committed suicide]] in November 1881. He left a large sum of money for any bookseller to publish his book.[[Warren Allen Smith|Smith, Warren Allen]]. (2000). ''Who's Who in Hell: A Handbook and International Directory for Humanists, Freethinkers, Naturalists, Rationalists, and Non-Theists''. Barricade Books. p. 754. {{ISBN|978-1569801581}} It was printed several times under different titles, most notably by the Freethought Publishing Company in 1881. Mitchell was an advocate of the [[Christ myth theory]].[[Acharya S|Murdock, Dorothy Milne]]. (2004). ''Suns of God: Krishna, Buddha and Christ Unveiled''. Adventures Unlimited Press. p. 492. {{ISBN|978-1931882316}} His views have been compared to [[Robert Taylor (Radical)|Robert Taylor]]'s.Wiener, Joel H. (1983). ''Radicalism and Freethought in Nineteenth-century Britain: The Life of Richard Carlile''. Greenwood Press. p. 263. {{ISBN|978-0313235320}} ==Quote==
Jesus Christ in the New Testament, has no reference whatever to any event that ever did in reality take place upon this globe; or to any personages that ever in truth existed: and that the whole is an astronomical allegory, or parable, having invariably a primary and sacred allusion to the sun, and his passage through the signs of the zodiac; or a verbal representation of the phenomena of the solar year and seasons.{{cite book|last=Mitchell|first=Logan|title=The Christian mythology unveiled, lectures |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4PkTAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA151|year=1842|publisher=Cousins|page=151|quote= (Image of [https://books.google.com/books?id=4PkTAAAAQAAJ&pg=PR3&img=1&zoom=3&hl=en&sig=ACfU3U2AIPMkTeyiajzAlC6kQckFI73S-Q Title page] & [https://books.google.com/books?id=4PkTAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA151&img=1&zoom=3&hl=en&sig=ACfU3U2D2OB_X2_DjhZ2f18Id3iUR0TVuA&ci=75%2C140%2C815%2C1057&edge=0 p. 151] at Google Books)}}

[[Magnetics]] |societies = |prizes = |spouse = |children = |handedness = |website = |footnotes = }} '''Marcel Joseph Vogel''' (April 14, 1917 – February 12, 1991) was a research scientist working at the [[IBM]] [[San Jose, California|San Jose]] [[IBM Almaden Research Center|Research Center]] for 27 years. He is sometimes referred to as Dr. Vogel, although this title was based on an [[honorary degree]], not a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] Later in his career, he became interested in various theories of quartz crystals and other [[occult]] and esoteric fields of study. The Vogel Crystal type cut was created by him. ==Mainstream scientific work== It is claimed that Vogel started his research into [[luminescence]] while he was still in his teens. This research eventually led him to publish his thesis, ''Luminescence in Liquids and Solids and Their Practical Application'', in collaboration with [[University of Chicago]]'s Dr. Peter Pringsheim in 1943. Two years after the publication, Vogel incorporated his own company, Vogel Luminescence, in [[San Francisco]]. For the next decade the firm developed a variety of new products: [[fluorescent]] [[crayon]]s, tags for [[insecticide]]s, a [[black light]] inspection kit to determine the secret trackways of [[rodent]]s in cellars from their [[urine]] and the [[psychedelic color]]s popular in "[[new age]]" posters. In 1957, Vogel Luminescence was sold to Ultra Violet Products and Vogel joined IBM as a full-time research scientist. He retired from IBM in 1984. He received 32 [[patent]]s for his inventions up through his tenure at IBM.[https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:cNs76uq_DdIJ:theyfly.com/PDF/Documentation%2520from%2520IBM%2520on.pdf+%22marcel+vogel%22&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESjxmvn61yYKPI2vBzoXbA06ratPIoF7Df5x4wzNnVprT93Rln52JGdeuYSc8YfgUxsjFe8Z3TxUG_dCGyE1qu-uo0KxmMHyhflVDs3abV5ChTrNVZHPg9kW0gUcaxfi3k4lyLLL&sig=AHIEtbTxH-ULFp5grKtR3fdwPXxb72ONRQ Documentation from IBM on Vogel patents, at GoogleDocs] Among these was the magnetic coating for the 24" [[hard disk drive]] systems still in use. His areas of expertise, besides luminescence, were [[phosphor]] technology, [[magnetic]]s and [[liquid crystal]] systems. At Vogel's February 14, 1991 funeral, IBM researcher and Sacramento, California physician Bernard McGinity, M.D. said of him, "He made his mark because of the brilliance of his mind, his prolific ideas, and his seemingly limitless creativity."{{cite web|url=http://www-03.ibm.com/ibm/history/ibm100/us/en/icons/magnetic/team/|title=IBM100 - Magnetic Stripe Technology|work=ibm.com}} ==Esoteric and occult studies== ===Billy Meier UFO metal sample=== According to the book ''Light Years'' by Gary Kinder,[http://www.billymeiertranslations.com/#contactotherbooks ''Light Years: An Investigation into the Extraterrestrial Experiences of Eduard Meier''] Vogel examined a metal sample which was allegedly given to [[Billy Meier]] by [[Extraterrestrial life|extraterrestrial]]s and marveled at its unusual properties (Vogel stated it contained the element [[thulium]]).https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xZmBW69OO1I Beamship - The Metal An investigator with the [[Independent Investigations Group]] said the element detected by Vogel was aluminum and not thulium.[http://www.iigwest.org/investigations/meier/metal_analysis_deconstruction_old.html Metal Analysis Deconstruction at IIG website] Kinder however states in his book that the metal sample had disappeared after Vogel's analysis and was never found again. ===Communication between plants=== Vogel said he could duplicate the "[[Cleve Backster|Backster effect]]" using plants as transducers for bio-energetic fields from the human mind, showing that they respond to human thought. He said his findings had the same effect irrespective of distance and suggested that "inverse square law does not apply to thought" (See also: [[Inverse square law]]).{{cite book|author=Joan D'Arc|title=Phenomenal World: Remote Viewing, Astral Travel, Apparitions, Extraterrestrials, Lucid Dreams and Other Forms of Intelligent Contact in the Magical Kingdom of Mind-at-Large|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bgTG1dxoQ8kC&pg=PA191|accessdate=7 August 2013|date=1 November 2000|publisher=Book Tree|isbn=978-1-58509-128-7|pages=191–192}} Vogel was a proponent of research into [[plant consciousness]]. He spurred fellow researcher [[Randall Fontes]] into furthering this work. Vogel was featured in the first episode of [[In Search of... (TV series)|In Search Of...]] hosted by [[Leonard Nimoy]], called "Other Voices". He gave his theories regarding the possibility of [[Plant consciousness|communication between plants]].[http://meiercase.0x2a.info/meiercase/001/article.php?id=40&sn=6#4 Confusion between thallium and thulium] ==See also== *[[Pyramid power]] *[[Crystal healing]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.vogelcrystals.net/legacy_of_marcel_vogel.htm Vogel biographical sketch at Vogel Crystals website] * [http://www-03.ibm.com/ibm/history/ibm100/us/en/icons/magnetic/team/ Vogel at the IBM100 Magnetic Stripe Technology team website] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Vogel, Marcel}} [[Category:1917 births]] [[Category:1991 deaths]] [[Category:American chemists]] [[Category:American inventors]] [[Category:Computer storage media]] [[Category:Esotericists]] [[Category:IBM employees]] [[Category:Liquid crystal displays]] [[Category:Luminescence]] [[Category:Materials scientists and engineers]] [[Category:People from San Jose, California]]

'''Sarah Margaret "Peggy" Hodges''' née Moore (July 26, 1911 – December 13, 2005)<ref name=hoover/> was an American writer of children's books, librarian, and storyteller.
Sarah Margaret Moore was born in [[Indianapolis, Indiana]] to [[Arthur Carlisle]] and [[Annie Marie Moore]]. She enrolled at [[Park Tudor School|Tudor Hall]], a college preparatory school for girls. A 1932 graduate of [[Vassar College]], she arrived in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] with her husband [[Fletcher Hodges Jr.]] when in 1937 he became curator at the [[Stephen Foster Memorial]]. She trained as a librarian at [[Carnegie Institute of Technology]], now [[Carnegie Mellon University]], under [[Elizabeth Nesbitt]], and she volunteered as a storyteller at the [[Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh]]. Beginning in 1958 with ''[[One Little Drum]]'', she wrote more than 40 published books. She also wrote the book ''[[John F. Kennedy Voice of Hope]]''. In 1953, she was hired as the storyteller for a radio show called ''[[Let's Tell A Story]]''.<ref name=lavelle/> It became the storytelling segment, "Tell Me a Story", for Fred Rogers' children's television show at [[WQED (TV)|WQED]], which ran from the mid-1960s to 1976<ref name=saxon/> (the first run of ''[[Mister Rogers' Neighborhood]]'').
Illustrator [[Trina Schart Hyman]] won the annual [[Caldecott Medal]] for the 1985 picture book ''[[Saint George and the Dragon (book)|Saint George and the Dragon]]'' written by Hodges.<ref name=CaldecottWinners /> Two more of her well-known works are ''[[What's for Lunch, Charley?]]'', and ''[[Merlin and the Making of the King]]''.
She was a professor of library science at the [[University of Pittsburgh]], where she retired in 1976.
Hodges died of heart disease December 13, 2005, at her home in [[Oakmont, Pennsylvania]]. She suffered from [[Parkinson's disease]].<ref name=hoover/><ref name=CaldecottWinners />
She wrote her stories on a [[notepad]] or a [[typewriter]]. "I need good ideas, and they don't come out of machines", she once said.
