'''Robert Jonathan Schifreen''' (born October 1963) is a former UK-based computer hacker and magazine editor, and the founder of IT security awareness training programme SecuritySmart.co.uk. He was the first person charged with illegally accessing a computer system, but was acquitted because there was no such specific criminal offence at the time. Later in life he became a computer security consultant, speaking at many conferences on information security and training banks, large companies and universities in the UK on IT security. In 2014 he began developing the software on which SecuritySmart runs from scratch which reached completion and product launch in June 2016.
==SecuritySmart.co.uk== {{Main article|SecuritySmart.co.uk}} The idea of SecuritySmart.co.uk came to Robert after speaking to many CISOs at conferences and repeatedly hearing that the biggest problem with traditional methods of IT security training was that they lacked any tangible way of measuring success. SecuritySmart is a micro-learning platform which sends an email a week to trainees on one security-related topic, ending in a multiple choice question to test trainee understanding. Managers have access to a dashboard that contains analytics related to trainee response to the training emails, including when they were opened, how long they took to answer the question and how regularly they got the answers right.
==Trial== He was arrested in 1985 for hacking into a [[British Telecom]] computer and accessing the [[Telecom Gold]] emails of [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|Prince Philip]]. As there was no specific law against hacking at this time, in June 1985 he became (together with his co-defendant, [[Steve Gold]]) one of the first two people to be charged under section 1 of the [[Forgery and Counterfeiting Act 1981]] with forgery which deceived a non-human target.<ref>"Two face computer charge", ''The Times'', 13 June 1985, p. 2.</ref> When the case came to trial in April 1986, Schifreen was said to have used an unprotected top level account identified as "2222222222" with a password of "1234"; Schifreen was said to have admitted obtaining user passwords but denied doing so for personal gain and said that his activities prompted Prestel to increase security.<ref>"Prestel password 'blunder helped hacker'", ''The Times'', 16 April 1986.</ref> On 24 April 1986 Schifreen was convicted on six counts of forgery and fined £750.<ref>"Hacker who broke into Duke's computer file found guilty of forgery", ''The Times'', 25 April 1986.</ref>
==Appeal== Schifreen's appeal to the [[Court of Appeal of England and Wales|Court of Appeal]] was heard by three judges including the [[Lord Chief Justice of England and Wales|Lord Chief Justice]], [[Geoffrey Lane, Baron Lane|Lord Lane]]; judgment was given on 21 July 1987, and found that the use of a charge of forgery was inappropriate and that an application that the charges should be dismissed as giving no case to answer should succeed. The judgment expressed the hope that "the [[Procrustes|Procrustean]] attempt to force the facts into the language of an Act not designed to fit them" would not be repeated.<ref name="Appeal">'Hacking' into Prestel is not a Forgery Act offence" (Law Report), ''The Times'', 21 July 1987.</ref>
==Law Lords== The Crown then appealed to the [[Judicial functions of the House of Lords|House of Lords]], but the appeal was turned down in April 1988.<ref>"Computer 'hacking' is not forgery" (Law Report), ''The Times'', 22 April 1988.</ref> The Law Lords agreed that the "making of a false instrument", a key part of proving a forgery case, revolved around the production of a "memory segment" with false information; as the computer had created this rather than Schifreen himself, the computer had effectively "forged itself".<ref name="BCS interview">{{cite web |url=http://archive.bcs.org/bulletin/sept02/intervie.htm |title=BCS Computer Bulletin: September 2002 Interview |work=[[British Computer Society]] |accessdate=2 October 2010}}</ref> This case led to introduction of the [[Computer Misuse Act 1990]].<ref name="BCS interview" />
==Later life== After his acquittal, Schifreen had to take a [[judicial review]] action against the police for the return of his computers.<ref>Wendy Grossman, "The strong arm of the law", ''The Guardian'', 22 September 1994, p. 5.</ref> For some years, Schifreen was the editor of ''[[.EXE Magazine]]'', a magazine for programmers. '<tt>[[hexadecimal|hex]]</tt>', his online name (shortened from the punning 'hex maniac'), was an active [[CIX]]en from the late 1980s, at a time when [[online community|online communities]] were still a rare novelty.
Schifreen now lives in East Sussex working as an IT security trainer and web developer at the [[University of Brighton]] and runs an IT security consultancy. He regularly speaks at conferences and writes articles for the computer press and other publications. In 2006, [[John Wiley & Sons]] published his book, ''Defeating the Hacker''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.defeatingthehacker.com/author.htm|title=Robert Schifreen - biography|accessdate=2 October 2010}}</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Scott Gilmore | other_names = | image = | image_size = | caption = Scott Gilmore, the founder of Building Markets speaking on BBC's Doha Debates | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Flin Flon]], Canada | death_date = | death_place = | alma mater = [[University of Alberta]], [[London School of Economics]] | known_for = Founding Building Markets | occupation = [[Social Entrepreneur]], Writer, [[Diplomat]] |party = [[Conservative Party of Canada|Conservative]] | spouse = [[Catherine McKenna]]<ref name="Catherine McKenna">{{cite web | url=http://www.canada.com/story.html?id=e3d5dc04-83b2-4c25-add7-bbfe2a59eeeb | title=Small NGO, big results | publisher=[[Ottawa Citizen]] | date=7 January 2015 | accessdate=31 October 2015 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160324222748/http://www.canada.com/story.html?id=e3d5dc04-83b2-4c25-add7-bbfe2a59eeeb | archivedate=24 March 2016 | df= }}</ref> | parents = | children = }}
'''Scott Gilmore''' is a Canadian [[social entrepreneur]], former diplomat, and writer who is known for founding the charity [[Peace Dividend Trust|Building Markets]] and as an advocate for reform in the international development and charity sectors.<ref name="Transformational Cdn" />
==Early life and education== Gilmore was born in northern [[Manitoba]], the son of hockey player [[Tom Gilmore (ice hockey)|Tom Gilmore]] and Collette Gilmore. He is the brother of actor [[Patrick Gilmore (actor)|Patrick Gilmore]]. Gilmore grew up in [[Edmonton, Alberta]] where he obtained a Bachelor of Commerce degree at the [[University of Alberta]].<ref name=Pilger>{{cite web|last1=Pilger|first1=Rick|title=Putting Money Where It Matters Most|url=http://newtrail.ualberta.ca/featurestories/scottgilmore|website=http://ualberta.ca|accessdate=26 October 2014}}</ref> He later graduated with a master's degree from the [[London School of Economics]].<ref name="Transformational Cdn" />
==Career==
Gilmore was a Canadian diplomat who began his career in Jakarta. From that post he covered the East Timor conflict and later joined the [[United Nations]] peacekeeping mission [[UNTAET]] under [[Sergio de Mello]]. In that role he became disillusioned with ineffective donor efforts to fight poverty. Based on this experience he quit his job as a diplomat in 2004 to launch the charity [[Peace Dividend Trust|Building Markets]].<ref name="This Mag">{{cite news|last1=Scott|first1=Graham F.|title=Interview with Peace Dividend Trust's Scott Gilmore|url=http://this.org/blog/2010/01/19/interview-scott-gilmore/|accessdate=26 October 2014|agency=This Magazine|date=January 19, 2010}}</ref> and focus on entrepreneurship instead of aid as a sustainable poverty solution.<ref name=Forbes>{{cite news|last1=Carlyle|first1=Erin|title=Building Markets: Meet The Start-Up Bringing Investors To The Fastest-Growing Economies in the World|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/erincarlyle/2013/11/17/building-markets-meet-the-start-up-bringing-investors-to-the-fastest-growing-economies-in-the-world/|accessdate=26 October 2014|publisher=Forbes Magazine|date=2013-11-17}}</ref>
In 2006 Gilmore led a [[World Bank]] study to trace spending in peacekeeping missions that revealed only 5% of donor money entered the local economies. Based on those findings Gilmore launched a project in Afghanistan to channel international spending through local small businesses. This approach was successful and expanded to other countries.<ref name="Transformational Cdn" /> Building Market's "buy local" policy was officially adopted by [[NATO]], the United States government, and the [[United Nations]].<ref name=Pilger /><ref>{{cite web|title=NATO Afghan First Policy|url=http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/official_texts_62851.htm|website=NATO|accessdate=27 October 2014}}</ref> In 2013 Gilmore was appointed to by the External Advisory Group overseeing the merger of the [[Department of Foreign Affairs and International Trade (Canada)|Canadian Department of Foreign Affairs and International Trade]] with the [[Canadian International Development Agency]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Blanchfield|first1=Mike|title=Paradis defends mining exec on advisory panel on international aid|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/935875/paradis-defends-mining-exec-on-advisory-panel-on-international-aid/|accessdate=27 October 2014|publisher=Global News|date=October 30, 2013}}</ref> He had previously been supportive of the merger.<ref name="CIDA Merger">{{cite news|last1=Berthiaume|first1=Lee|title=CIDA merger meets with controversy|url=http://www2.canada.com/vancouversun/news/archives/story.html?id=debacf11-51f7-45c8-be14-44eddda98579|accessdate=27 October 2014|publisher=Vancouver Sun|date=March 23, 2013}}</ref>
In 2014 Gilmore began writing a weekly column for the Canadian week national newsmagazine ''[[Maclean's]]''.<ref name=Macleans>{{cite web|title=Maclean's Magazine|url=http://www.macleans.ca/author/scottgilmore/|accessdate=26 October 2014}}</ref>
==Awards and honours== Gilmore was named a "[[25 Transformational Canadians|Transformational Canadian]]" by ''[[The Globe and Mail]]''<ref name="Transformational Cdn">{{cite news|last1=Rockel|first1=Nick|title=Scott Gilmore makes peace missions more effective|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/scott-gilmore-makes-peace-missions-more-effective/article1319533/|accessdate=26 October 2014|agency=The Globe and Mail|date=Dec 14, 2010}}</ref> and a [[Young Global Leader]]s by the [[World Economic Forum]]. In 2009 he was awarded the $765,000 dollar Skoll Prize for Social Entrepreneurship by philanthropist [[Jeffrey Skoll|Jeff Skoll]].<ref name=Newswire>{{cite news|title=Canadian NGO Wins Prestigious Skoll Award and Endorsement from US Leadership in Afghanistan|url=http://www.newswire.ca/en/story/493815/canadian-ngo-wins-prestigious-skoll-award-and-endorsement-from-us-leadership-in-afghanistan|accessdate=26 October 2014|agency=Newswire|date=December 15, 2009}}</ref> The University of Alberta awarded him a Distinguished Alumnus Award in 2013.<ref name=Pilger /> He received a [[Queen Elizabeth II Diamond Jubilee Medal]] for professional excellence.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cohen|first1=Andrew|title=Let's find a better way to honour Canadians|url=http://www.canada.com/story.html?id=4d434f3f-864b-4172-8636-c15158af46fc|accessdate=19 December 2014|agency=Times Colonist Victoria|date=Oct 31, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150221151005/http://www.canada.com/story.html?id=4d434f3f-864b-4172-8636-c15158af46fc|archivedate=21 February 2015|df=}}</ref>
==Personal life== Gilmore is married to [[Catherine McKenna]], the Minister of Environment and Climate Change and the [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal]] MP for [[Ottawa Centre]].<ref name="Catherine McKenna">{{cite web | url=http://www.canada.com/story.html?id=e3d5dc04-83b2-4c25-add7-bbfe2a59eeeb | title=Small NGO, big results | publisher=[[Ottawa Citizen]] | date=7 January 2015 | accessdate=31 October 2015 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160324222748/http://www.canada.com/story.html?id=e3d5dc04-83b2-4c25-add7-bbfe2a59eeeb | archivedate=24 March 2016 | df= }}</ref>

[[Columbia University]]
[[Yale University]] |alma_mater = [[California Institute of Technology]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]])
[[Princeton University]] ([[PhD]]) |thesis_title = On Quasi Algebraic Closure |thesis_year = 1951 |doctoral_advisor = [[Emil Artin]] |doctoral_students =[[Minhyong Kim]]
[[Stephen Schanuel]] |known_for = Work in [[number theory]] |prizes = [[Leroy P. Steele Prize]] (1999)
[[Cole Prize]] (1960) |footnotes = }} '''Serge Lang''' ({{IPA-fr|lɑ̃ɡ|lang}}; May 19, 1927 – September 12, 2005) was a French-American [[mathematician]] and activist. He is known for his work in [[number theory]] and for his mathematics textbooks, including the influential ''Algebra''. He was a member of the [[Bourbaki group]]. At the time of his death he was [[professor emeritus]] of mathematics at [[Yale University]]. ==Biography== Serge Lang was born in [[Saint-Germain-en-Laye]] close to [[Paris]] in 1927. Serge had a twin brother who became a basketball coach and a sister who became an actress.{{cite journal| editor1-last=Jorgenson| editor1-first=Jay| editor2-last=Krantz| editor2-first=Steven G. | editor2-link=Steven G. Krantz | date=May 2006 | title=Serge Lang, 1927–2005| url=http://www.ams.org/notices/200605/fea-lang.pdf|format=PDF| journal=[[Notices of the American Mathematical Society]]| volume=53| issue=5| pages=536–553}} Lang moved with his family to [[California]] as a teenager, where he graduated in 1943 from [[Beverly Hills High School]]. He subsequently graduated from the [[California Institute of Technology]] in 1946, and received a doctorate from [[Princeton University]] in 1951. He held faculty positions at the [[University of Chicago]], [[Columbia University]] (from 1955, leaving in 1971 in a dispute), and [[Yale University]]. ==Mathematical work== Lang studied under [[Emil Artin]] at Princeton University, writing his thesis on [[quasi-algebraic closure]].{{MathGenealogy|id=13268|title=Serge Lang}} Lang then worked on the geometric analogues of [[class field theory]] and [[diophantine geometry]]. Later he moved into [[diophantine approximation]] and [[transcendental number theory]], proving the [[Schneider–Lang theorem]]. A break in research while he was involved in trying to meet 1960s student activism halfway caused him (by his own description) difficulties in picking up the threads afterwards. He wrote on [[modular form]]s and [[modular unit]]s, the idea of a 'distribution' on a [[profinite group]], and [[value distribution theory]]. He made a number of conjectures in diophantine geometry: [[Mordell–Lang conjecture]], [[Bombieri–Lang conjecture]], [[Lang's integral point conjecture]], [[Lang–Trotter conjecture]], [[Lang conjecture on Gamma values]], [[Lang conjecture on analytically hyperbolic varieties]], [[Lang's height conjecture]] ... He introduced the [[Lang map]][[Daniel Bump]], "[http://sporadic.stanford.edu/bump/lang.ps The Lang Map]" and the [[Lang–Steinberg theorem]] (cf. [[Lang's theorem]]) in algebraic groups. He introduced the [[Katz–Lang finiteness theorem]]. ==Mathematical books== He was a prolific writer of mathematical texts, often completing one on his summer vacation. Most are at the graduate level. He wrote [[calculus]] texts and also prepared a book on [[group cohomology]] for Bourbaki. Lang's ''Algebra'', a graduate-level introduction to [[abstract algebra]], was a highly influential text that ran through numerous updated editions. His Steele prize citation stated, "Lang's ''Algebra'' changed the way graduate algebra is taught...It has affected all subsequent graduate-level algebra books." It contained ideas of his teacher, Artin; some of the most interesting passages in ''Algebraic Number Theory'' also reflect Artin's influence and ideas that might otherwise not have been published in that or any form. ==Awards as expositor== Lang was noted for his eagerness for contact with students. Many of his students at Yale considered him to be one of the greatest teachers of mathematics in the world. He won a [[Leroy P. Steele Prize]] for Mathematical Exposition (1999) from the [[American Mathematical Society]]. In 1960, he won the sixth [[Cole Prize|Frank Nelson Cole Prize]] in Algebra for his paper ''Unramified class field theory over function fields in several variables'' (Annals of Mathematics, Series 2, volume 64 (1956), pp. 285–325). ==Activism== {{Refimprove section|date=May 2016}} Lang spent much of his professional time engaged in political activism. He was a staunch [[socialist]] and active in [[Opposition to US involvement in the Vietnam War|opposition to the Vietnam War]], volunteering for the 1966 anti-war campaign of [[Robert Scheer]] (the subject of his book ''The Scheer Campaign'').{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} Lang later quit his position at Columbia in 1971 in protest over the university's treatment of anti-war protesters. Lang engaged in several efforts to challenge anyone he believed was spreading misinformation or misusing science or mathematics to further their own goals. He attacked the [[1977 Survey of the American Professoriate]], an opinion questionnaire that [[Seymour Martin Lipset]] and [[E. C. Ladd]] had sent to thousands of college professors in the United States, accusing it of containing numerous biased and loaded questions.{{citation|title=The Professors: A Survey of a Survey|date=18 May 1978|author=Serge Lang|work=The New York Review of Books}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=0avTrkyT1VcC&pg=PA226 available online as reprinted in Challenges] This led to a public and highly acrimonious conflict. In 1986, Lang mounted what the ''[[New York Times]]'' described as a "one-man challenge" against the nomination of political scientist [[Samuel P. Huntington]] to the [[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences]].{{cite news | work = [[New York Times]] | title = Serge Lang, 78, a Gadfly and Mathematical Theorist, Dies | first = Kenneth | last = Change |author2=Warren Leary | date = September 25, 2005 | accessdate = August 13, 2010 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2005/09/25/national/25lang.html}} Lang described Huntington's research, in particular his use of mathematical equations to demonstrate that South Africa was a "satisfied society", as "pseudoscience", arguing that it gave "the illusion of science without any of its substance." Despite support for Huntington from the Academy's social and behavioral scientists, Lang's challenge was successful, and Huntington was twice rejected for Academy membership. Huntington's supporters argued that Lang's opposition was political rather than scientific in nature.{{cite news | work = [[New York Times]] | title = Science Academy Rejects Harvard Political Scientist | first = George | last = Johnson |author2=Laura Mansnerus | date = May 3, 1987 | accessdate = August 13, 2010 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/03/weekinreview/ideas-trends-science-academy-rejects-harvard-political-scientist.html}} Lang kept his political correspondence and related documentation in extensive "files". He would send letters or publish articles, wait for responses, engage the writers in further correspondence, collect all these writings together and point out what he considered contradictions. He often mailed these files to people he considered important; some of them were also published in his books ''Challenges'' ({{isbn|0-387-94861-9}}) and ''[[The File]]'' ({{isbn|0-387-90607-X}}). His extensive file criticizing Nobel laureate [[David Baltimore]] was published in the journal ''Ethics and Behaviour'' in January 1993.[http://www.gatewaycoalition.org/files/Gateway_Project_Moshe_Kam/Resource/DBCre/serge.html Questions of Scientific Responsibility: The Baltimore Case] Reprinted from the journal Ethics and Behavior Vol. 3 No. 1 (1993) pp. 3–72, Serge Lang, Mathematics Department, Yale University Lang fought the decision by Yale University to hire [[Daniel Kevles]], a [[History of science|historian of science]], because Lang disagreed with Kevles' analysis in ''The Baltimore Case''. Lang's most controversial political stance was as an [[AIDS denialist]];{{cite journal| editor1-last=Jorgenson| editor1-first=Jay| editor2-last=Krantz| editor2-first=Steven G. | editor2-link=Steven G. Krantz | date=May 2006 | title=Serge Lang, 1927–2005| url=http://www.ams.org/notices/200605/fea-lang.pdf|format=PDF| journal=[[Notices of the American Mathematical Society]]| volume=53| issue=5| pages=536–553}} he maintained that the prevailing scientific consensus that [[HIV]] causes [[AIDS]] has not been backed up by reliable [[scientific method|scientific research]], yet for political and commercial reasons further research questioning the current point of view is suppressed. {{Infobox serial killer |name=Sheila LaBarre |image= |caption= |birthname=Sheila Kay Bailey |alias= |birth_date={{Birth date and age|1958|7|4|df=y}} |birth_place=[[Fort Payne, Alabama|Fort Payne]], [[Alabama]], US |death_date= |death_place= |cause= |conviction= |sentence=[[Life Imprisonment]] without [[parole]] |victims=2-4 |beginyear=2004 |endyear=2006 |country=[[United States|U.S.]] |states=[[Rockingham County, New Hampshire|New Hampshire]] |apprehended=April 2, 2006 }} '''Sheila LaBarre''' (born '''Sheila Kay Bailey''' on July 4, 1958 in [[Fort Payne, Alabama]]) is an American convicted murderer. She was sentenced to two consecutive life sentences, with no prospect of parole after being convicted of killing two men, Kenneth Countie and Michael DeLoge, in Epping, New Hampshire. At the time of the crimes, LaBarre lived in [[Epping, New Hampshire]] ([[Rockingham County, New Hampshire|Rockingham County]]) on a farm.
She regularly enticed younger men to her farm, where she would torture and control them.
At her trial she claimed she was an angel, sent by God to punish pedophiles.<ref name="foxnews1">{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/2008/06/20/murder-conviction-for-woman-who-claimed-was-pedophile-punishing-angel/ |title=Murder Conviction for Woman Who Claimed She Was Pedophile-Punishing Angel |publisher=Fox News |date=2008-06-20 |accessdate=2014-08-01}}</ref> She accused the two men she killed of being pedophiles.<ref>{{cite web|author=Lara Bricker |url=http://www.seacoastonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?aid=/20080213/news/802130361 |title=Insanity defense: LaBarre pleads not guilty in 2 murders |publisher=SeacoastOnline.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-01}}</ref>
==Biography== LaBarre was born Sheila Kaye Bailey in Alabama in 1958. She has a sister, Lynn Noojin.<ref name="fosters1">{{cite web|url=http://www.fosters.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080514/GJNEWS_01/76602961 |title=Dover NH, Rochester NH, Portsmouth NH, Sanford ME |publisher=Fosters.com |date=2008-05-14 |accessdate=2014-08-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seacoastonline.com/articles/20080514-NEWS-805140377 |title=Avenging 'angel' cries on jury tour |publisher=SeacoastOnline.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-01}}</ref> She graduated from [[Fort Payne City Schools|Fort Payne High School]] in 1976.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P5DHDoeKKboC&pg=PA8&lpg=PA8&dq=Fort+Payne+High+School+in+1976+sheila+bailey&source=bl&ots=BkML2e8vqv&sig=3HhcWb-P8nLvNHJWD_30rJX7YaQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=7hmyU5qRJMuiyATrsIKwAw&ved=0CEYQ6AEwBg |title=The Burn Farm - Michael Benson - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-01}}</ref>
After marrying Ronnie Jennings, she was known as Sheila Bailey Jennings. She wanted to divorce Ronnie but he refused to divorce her for some time.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P5DHDoeKKboC&pg=PA8&lpg=PA8&dq=Fort+Payne+High+School+in+1976+sheila+bailey&source=bl&ots=BkML2e8vqv&sig=3HhcWb-P8nLvNHJWD_30rJX7YaQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=7hmyU5qRJMuiyATrsIKwAw&ved=0CEYQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=Fort%20Payne%20High%20School%20in%201976%20sheila%20bailey&f=false |title=The Burn Farm - Michael Benson - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-01}}</ref> In the early 1980s, LaBarre was held in a [[mental hospital|psychiatric facility]] after attempting suicide; at the facility she was sexually assaulted by an orderly.<ref name="fosters1"/>
She married John Baxter in January 1981.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=40glj3pe--0C&pg=PA173-IA1&lpg=PA173-IA1&dq=sheila+labarre+john+baxter&source=bl&ots=JLwM5DCI5j&sig=RxOIrrPH2ktOvveMwfZ9I7-jCn4&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lUqyU5PWLPLlsAS62oLgCw&ved=0CDUQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=sheila%20labarre%20john%20baxter&f=false |title=Wicked Intentions: A Remote Farmhouse, A Beautiful Temptress, and the Lovers ... - Kevin Flynn - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date=2009-12-29 |accessdate=2014-08-01}}</ref>
LaBarre moved from Fort Payne to Epping, New Hampshire in 1987 after answering a personal ad placed by Dr. Wilfred "Bill" LaBarre, a chiropractor. She never legally married Bill LaBarre, but took his last name ("Sheila LaBarre") and they lived together from 1987 until his death at age 74 in 2000.<ref name="eagletribune1">{{cite web|url=http://www.eagletribune.com/local/x1876269565/LaBarre-married-divorced-while-claiming-to-be-common-law-wife/print |title=LaBarre married, divorced while claiming to be common-law wife » EagleTribune.com, North Andover, MA |publisher=Eagletribune.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Wilfred LaBarre's obituary|url=http://www.hampton.lib.nh.us/hampton/biog/obits/labarrewilfred.htm}}</ref> Bill LaBarre had been married twice before.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hampton.lib.nh.us/hampton/biog/obits/labarrewilfred.htm |title=Obituary of Wilfred Joseph LaBarre | Lane Memorial Library |publisher=Hampton.lib.nh.us |date= |accessdate=2014-08-01}}</ref> However, LaBarre married a [[Jamaica]]n citizen named Wayne Ennis in [[York, Maine]], on August 22, 1995.<ref name="eagletribune1"/><ref>{{cite web|author=The Associated Press |url=http://www.southcoasttoday.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060811/NEWS/308119970 |title=LaBarre wants divorce records sealed |publisher=SouthCoastToday.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-01}}</ref> LaBarre divorced Ennis in 1996.<ref name="google1">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P5DHDoeKKboC&pg=PA19&lpg=PA19&dq=wayne+ennis+divorce&source=bl&ots=BkML2fbmru&sig=pkJ7Xko3Dcf_QBoq_0H30EN7Iag&hl=en&sa=X&ei=PEmyU-uPAZOksQTDo4DoAw&ved=0CBwQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=wayne%20ennis%20divorce&f=false |title=The Burn Farm - Michael Benson - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-01}}</ref> In April 1997, Sheila LaBarre got a restraining order against Ennis after he had repeatedly assaulted her.<ref name="google1"/>
After Bill's death, Sheila LaBarre inherited his farm. She said she was his common-law wife. His children from a previous relationship attempted to contest the will to get money and property, but were informed they had a 50/50 chance of success and would have to pay $50,000 upfront.<ref name="Hampton.lib.nh.us">{{cite web|url=http://www.hampton.lib.nh.us/hampton/biog/labarre/sheilalabarreHU20060401.htm |title=Woman Wanted for Murder | Lane Memorial Library |publisher=Hampton.lib.nh.us |date=2006-04-01 |accessdate=2014-08-01}}</ref> After LaBarre's arrest there was speculation that she may have killed Bill,<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.seacoastonline.com/article/20060509/NEWS/305099994|title = Murder probe: Autopsy revisited|last = Dinan|first = Elizabeth|publisher = ''[[The Portsmouth Herald]]''|date = 9 May 2006|website = seacoastonline.com|accessdate = 2 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.seacoastonline.com/article/20090906/NEWS/909060335|title = New York true crime author pens book on LaBarre murders|last = Bricker|first = Lara|publisher = ''[[The Portsmouth Herald]]''|date = 6 September 2009|website = seacoastonline.com|accessdate = 2 February 2018}}</ref> an allegation which LaBarre has denied.<ref name = "Toes">{{cite web|url = http://www.unionleader.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20120704/NEWS03/707049957|title = Human toes found near Sheila LaBarre's Epping horse farm may lead to new homicide probe|last = West|first = Nancy|publisher = ''[[New Hampshire Union Leader]]''|date = 3 July 2012|website = unionleader.com|accessdate = 7 June 2017}}</ref>
==Crimes==
===Kenny Countie===
Kenny Countie met LaBarre via a personal ad in 2006 when he was 24. He moved in with her shortly after meeting her.<ref name="foxnews1"/> Countie was described as having a [[Intellectual disability|low IQ]] and "child like" trust. LaBarre made a recording of him vomiting whilst she accused him of being a paedophile. She stabbed him to death and then burnt his body. The police were able to identify his DNA from his army records.
Countie's mother subsequently accused the Epping Police Department of negligence. Prior to his death, he had been seen in a [[Walmart]] store, bruised and burned, in a wheelchair. Her lawsuit against the two police officers who had seen him in the store was rejected in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wmur.com/news/nh-news/Mother-of-LaBarre-victim-accuses-police-of-negligence/16446802#!U70C8 |title=Mother of LaBarre victim accuses police of negligence | Local News - WMUR Home |publisher=Wmur.com |date=2012-09-02 |accessdate=2014-08-01}}</ref>
===Michael Deloge===
Deloge was LaBarre's boyfriend, who lived with her at her farm. He was last seen alive in 2005. A bone of his and his birth certificate were found at the farm in 2008. It is unknown how he died.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eagletribune.com/newhampshire/x1876419217/LaBarre-admits-to-two-murders |title=LaBarre admits to two murders » New Hampshire » EagleTribune.com, North Andover, MA |publisher=Eagletribune.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-01}}</ref> His mother informed the police that she was worried LaBarre was trying to kill him.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eagletribune.com/newhampshire/x1876424893/New-details-of-LaBarre-case-revealed |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140605213323/http://www.eagletribune.com/newhampshire/x1876424893/New-details-of-LaBarre-case-revealed |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2014-06-05 |title=New details of LaBarre case revealed » New Hampshire » EagleTribune.com, North Andover, MA |publisher=Eagletribune.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-01}}</ref>
===Arrest=== An arrest warrant was issued on April 1, 2006 for Shelia LaBarre, for charges of first degree murder.<ref name="Hampton.lib.nh.us"/> She was arrested on April 2, and the police conducted a three-week search of her farm,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eagletribune.com/newhampshire/x1876227425/Details-revealed-in-murder-case-against-Sheila-LaBarre |title=Details revealed in murder case against Sheila LaBarre » New Hampshire » EagleTribune.com, North Andover, MA |publisher=Eagletribune.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-01}}{{dead link|date=March 2017}}</ref> which led to the discovery of three human toes which forensic analysis determined did not belong to either Kenny Countie or Michael Deloge.<ref name = "Toes"/>
===Trial=== The jury visited LaBarre's farm and the [[Walmart]] where she was seen with Countie. LaBarre attended too, wearing a stun belt.
LaBarre pleaded not guilty to murdering Countie and Deloge on the grounds of insanity. Her defense attorney described her as a "deeply, deeply sick individual".<ref>{{cite web|author=Lara Bricker |url=http://www.seacoastonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?aid=/20080213/news/802130361 |title=Insanity defense: LaBarre pleads not guilty in two murders |publisher=SeacoastOnline.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-01}}</ref>
At trial in May 2008, psychiatrists testified that LaBarre was diagnosed with [[schizoaffective disorder]] and [[delusional disorder]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fosters.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080604/GJNEWS_01/633523226 |title=Dover NH, Rochester NH, Portsmouth NH, Sanford ME |publisher=Fosters.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fosters.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080515/GJNEWS_01/430513413 |title=Dover NH, Rochester NH, Portsmouth NH, Sanford ME |publisher=Fosters.com |date=2008-05-15 |accessdate=2014-08-01}}</ref>
James Brackett testified in court that he was in an abusive relationship with LaBarre for six years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seacoastonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080530/NEWS/805300427 |title=Sheila LaBarre's ex-boyfriend says he is lucky to be alive |publisher=SeacoastOnline.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-01}}</ref>
LaBarre's ex-husband Wayne Ennis claimed that she had asked him to kill Wilfred.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eagletribune.com/local/x1876275655/Ex-husband-says-LaBarre-asked-him-to-murder-chiropractor |title=Ex-husband says LaBarre asked him to murder chiropractor » Merrimack Valley » EagleTribune.com, North Andover, MA |publisher=Eagletribune.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-01}}</ref>
Wilfred LaBarre's daughter Laura Melisi claimed that LaBarre had threatened to shoot people. She stated she always disliked Sheila LaBarre, and had warned her father against pursuing a relationship.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seacoastonline.com/article/20060401/NEWS/304019995 |title=Woman Wanted For Murder |publisher=SeacoastOnline.com |date=February 1, 2011|accessdate=2017-04-11}}</ref>
Her plea of [[Insanity defense|not guilty by reason of insanity]] was rejected by the jury. They found her guilty and LaBarre was sentenced to life in prison without parole in June 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fosters.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080215/GJNEWS_01/792950596&Template=printart |title=Murder experts analyze LaBarre: Call her pattern of behavior similar to that of serial killer |publisher=Fosters.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eagletribune.com/local/x1876438133/New-Hampshire-jury-says-Sheila-LaBarre-was-sane-sentenced-to-life-in-prison |title=New Hampshire jury says Sheila LaBarre was sane; sentenced to life in prison | Local News |publisher=eagletribune.com |date=2008-06-21 |accessdate=2017-03-08}}</ref>
Her appeal in 2010 was rejected.<ref>{{cite web|title = State of New Hampshire v. Sheila K. LaBarre|url = http://law.justia.com/cases/new-hampshire/supreme-court/2010/2010021labar.html|accessdate = 2015-08-05}}</ref> LaBarre is currently serving her sentence at Homestead Correctional Institution, in Florida City, Florida.

{{Infobox person | name = Philip Stephen Gray | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|1923|03|11|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Guildford]], [[Surrey]], England | death_date = {{death date and age|2012|11|30|1923|03|11|df=y}} | death_place = | other_names = | known_for = | occupation = Musical administrator | nationality = English }}
'''Philip Stephen Gray''' [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] (11 March 1923 – 30 November 2012) was an English musical administrator, who managed the [[Royal Liverpool Philharmonic|Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra]] for 23 years.
==Career==
In 1950, together with [[David Cairns (writer)|David Cairns]], Gray established the [[Chelsea Opera Group]]. This was an organisation that produced concert performances of operas rather than staged productions because they were less expensive for the audiences.<ref name=obit>{{Citation | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/culture-obituaries/music-obituaries/9748777/Stephen-Gray.html| title = Stephen Gray| accessdate = 18 December 2012| publisher = [[The Daily Telegraph]]}}</ref> For their first performance they persuaded [[Colin Davis]], at the time a 22-year-old [[clarinet]]ist, to conduct a concert performance of [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart’s]] ''[[Don Giovanni]]'' in the [[Holywell Music Room]], [[Oxford]].<ref>{{Citation | url = http://www.chelseaoperagroup.org.uk/About.htm| title = About COG| accessdate = 18 December 2012| publisher = Chelsea Opera Group}}</ref> Gray played in the orchestra, and Cairns sang the role of Leporello.<ref name=obit/>
In 1957 the [[London Philharmonic Orchestra]] invited Gray to leave his career at the [[Bank of England]] to assist with managing its finances. Two years later Gray joined the [[Philharmonia Orchestra]] as an administrator. In 1964 he moved to [[Liverpool]] to become the manager of the Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra, a post he held until his retirement in 1987. During this time, the orchestra had five principal conductors, [[Charles Groves|Sir Charles Groves]] (until 1977), [[Walter Weller]] (1977–80), [[David Atherton]] (1980–83), [[Marek Janowski]] (1983–87), and [[Libor Pešek]] (1987–97). Together with Sir Charles, Gray organised an annual conductors' seminar, in which young potential conductors worked with the orchestra for a fortnight. In 1972 Gray noticed the potential of [[Simon Rattle]] when, at the age of 17, he conducted the Merseyside Youth Orchestra in a performance of ''[[The Rite of Spring]]''. Gray appointed Rattle as an associate conductor of the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra in 1977. When Gray retired in 1987, a concert was organised in which each of the five principal conductors, and Simon Rattle, took part.<ref name=obit/><ref>{{Citation| url = http://www.liverpoolphil.com/10728/latest-press-releases/royal-liverpool-philharmonic-remembers-stephen-gray-obe.html| title = Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Remembers Stephen Gray OBE| accessdate = 18 December 2012| publisher = [[Royal Liverpool Philharmonic]]| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130218090304/http://www.liverpoolphil.com/10728/latest-press-releases/royal-liverpool-philharmonic-remembers-stephen-gray-obe.html| archivedate = 18 February 2013| df = }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | last = Henley| first = Darren| author-link = | last2 = McKernan| first2 = Vincent| author2-link = | year = 2009| title = The Original Liverpool Sound: The Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Society | publication-place = Liverpool | publisher = Liverpool University Press | page= 173| isbn = 978-1-84631-224-3}}</ref> Following his retirement, Gray remained active, helping to the rescue the Bluecoat Society of Arts, who were based in the [[Bluecoat Chambers]] in Liverpool, from closure.<ref name=obit/>
==Personal life==
Stephen Gray was born in [[Guildford]], [[Surrey]], England, and was the son of an [[Anglicanism|Anglican]] clergyman. He was educated at [[Rugby School]], where he took an active part in the school orchestra. After leaving school he worked at [[Bletchley Park]], but he never disclosed what he did there. He studied [[classics]] at [[Trinity College, Oxford]], then joined the Bank of England as a trainee. Gray married Frances, a member of the chorus of the Chelsea Opera Group, in 1953. Together they had a son and a daughter. Gray was appointed OBE in 1987.<ref name=obit/>

[[David Willetts]] (Work and Pensions){{Collapsed infobox section end}} | birth_name = Theresa Mary Brasier | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1956|10|1|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Eastbourne]], [[Sussex]], England | death_date = | death_place = | party = [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] | spouse = {{marriage|[[Philip May]]|6 September 1980}} | parents = {{plain list| * Hubert Brasier * Zaidee Mary Barnes }} | residence = [[10 Downing Street]] (official) | alma_mater = [[St Hugh's College, Oxford]] | signature = Signature of Theresa May.svg | website = {{Official URL}} }} {{Theresa May sidebar}} '''Theresa Mary May''' ({{IPAc-en|t|ə|ˈ|r|iː|z|ə}};{{cite web |title=This Is What It's Like To Work In Government For Theresa May |url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/jamesball/dont-pronounce-her-name-as-tree-za |first=James |last=Ball |authorlink=James Ball (journalist) |work=[[BuzzFeed News]] |date=17 July 2016 |accessdate=6 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170906033153/https://www.buzzfeed.com/jamesball/dont-pronounce-her-name-as-tree-za |archivedate=6 September 2017 }} {{nee|'''Brasier'''}}; born 1 October 1956) is a British politician serving as [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]] and [[Leader of the Conservative Party (UK)|Leader]] of the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] since [[Conservative Party (UK) leadership election, 2016|2016]]. She served as [[Home Secretary]] from 2010 to 2016. May was first elected [[Member of Parliament (United Kingdom)|Member of Parliament]] (MP) for [[Maidenhead (UK Parliament constituency)|Maidenhead]] in [[UK general election, 1997|1997]]. Ideologically, she identifies herself as a [[one-nation conservative]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jun/30/theresa-may-sets-out-one-nation-conservative-pitch-for-leadership |title=Theresa May sets out ‘one-nation Conservative’ pitch for leadership|first=Ben|last=Quinn|date=30 June 2016|work=The Guardian|accessdate=24 July 2018}} May grew up in [[Oxfordshire]] and attended [[St Hugh's College, Oxford]]. From 1977 until 1983, she worked for the [[Bank of England]], and from 1985 until 1997 at the [[Association for Payment Clearing Services]], also serving as a councillor for Durnsford in [[London Borough of Merton|Merton]]. After unsuccessful attempts to be elected to the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] in 1992 and 1994, she was elected as the MP for Maidenhead in the [[United Kingdom general election, 1997|1997 general election]]. From 1999 to 2010, May held a number of roles in the [[Official Opposition Shadow Cabinet (United Kingdom)|Shadow Cabinets]] of [[William Hague]], [[Iain Duncan Smith]], [[Michael Howard]], and [[David Cameron]], including [[Shadow Secretary of State for Transport|Shadow Transport Secretary]] and [[Shadow Secretary of State for Work and Pensions|Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary]]. She was also [[Chairman of the Conservative Party]] from 2002 to 2003. After the [[2010 United Kingdom government formation|formation]] of a [[Cameron–Clegg coalition|coalition government]] following the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010 general election]], May was appointed [[Home Secretary]] and [[Minister for Women and Equalities]], giving up the latter role in 2012. Reappointed after the Conservative victory in the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|2015 general election]], she went on to become the longest-serving Home Secretary in over 60 years. During her tenure she pursued reform of the [[Police Federation of England and Wales|Police Federation]], implemented a harder line on drugs policy including the banning of [[khat]], oversaw the introduction of elected [[Police and Crime Commissioners]], the deportation of [[Abu Qatada]], the creation of the [[National Crime Agency]] and brought in [[Home Office hostile environment policy|additional restrictions on immigration]].{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/boring-and-competent-theresa-may-is-what-the-nation-needs-after-the-shock-of-the-brexit-vote-a7114531.html |last=Rentoul |first=John |work=[[The Independent]] |title=Boring and competent Theresa May is what the nation needs after shock Brexit vote |date=1 July 2016 |accessdate=11 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160712173442/http://www.independent.co.uk/voices/boring-and-competent-theresa-may-is-what-the-nation-needs-after-the-shock-of-the-brexit-vote-a7114531.html |archivedate=12 July 2016 }} Following Cameron's resignation, May won a [[Conservative Party (UK) leadership election, 2016|leadership election]] in July 2016, becoming the second female Prime Minister, following [[Margaret Thatcher]]. As Prime Minister, May began the process of [[Brexit|withdrawing the UK from the European Union]], triggering [[Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union|Article 50]] in March 2017 then, the following month, announcing a [[snap election|snap]] [[United Kingdom general election, 2017|general election]] in June, with the aim of strengthening her hand in Brexit negotiations.{{cite news|url=http://www.gq-magazine.co.uk/article/brexit-secretary-david-davis-resigns|title=Political crises don't come much bigger than Brexit|last=Crace |first=John|date=9 July 2018|work=[[GQ]]|accessdate=10 July 2018|authorlink=John Crace (writer)}}{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/election-2017-40210957 |title=General election 2017: Why did Theresa May call an election? |date=9 June 2017 |work=[[BBC News Online]] |accessdate=4 September 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170905062304/http://www.bbc.com/news/election-2017-40210957 |archivedate=5 September 2017 }} This resulted in a [[hung parliament]], in which the number of Conservative seats fell from 330 to 317, despite the party winning their highest vote share [[United Kingdom general election, 1983|since 1983]], prompting her to broker a [[confidence and supply]] [[Conservative–DUP agreement|deal]] with the [[Democratic Unionist Party]] (DUP) to support a [[minority government]]. May is currently orchestrating the [[Brexit negotiations]] with the [[European Union]], adhering to the [[Chequers Agreement]], agreed in 2018. ==Early life and education== Born on 1 October 1956 in [[Eastbourne]], [[Sussex]], May is the only child of Zaidee Mary (née Barnes; 1928–1982) and Hubert Brasier (1917–1981).{{cite book|title=The International Who's Who|year=2004|publisher=Europa Publications|page=1114}} Her father was a [[Church of England]] clergyman (and an [[Anglo-Catholicism|Anglo-Catholic]]){{Cite newspaper |url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/mrs-may-is-our-first-catholic-prime-minister-zmbgdqjz3|title=Mrs May is our first Catholic prime minister|last=Gove|first=Michael|date=9 March 2017|work=The Times|accessdate=9 March 2017}} who was chaplain of an Eastbourne hospital.Brasier, Hubert, ''[[Crockford's Clerical Directory]] 1977–79'', [[Oxford University Press]] He later became vicar of [[Enstone]] with [[Heythrop]] and finally of [[St Mary the Virgin, Wheatley|St Mary's]] at [[Wheatley, Oxfordshire|Wheatley]], to the east of Oxford.{{cite web|title=Conservative Leader Hopefuls Have Faith |url=https://www.churchtimes.co.uk/articles/2016/8-july/news/uk/conservative-leader-hopefuls-have-faith|work=Church Times |accessdate=12 July 2016|deadurl=no |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/news/vote2001/hi/english/key_people/newsid_1179000/1179350.stm |title=Vote 2001: Key People Theresa May Education and Employment |last=Davies |first=Ben |date=22 May 2001 |archivedate=15 May 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://www.freebmd.org.uk/cgi/information.pl?cite=VNsoQkakVvS4ZOt%2BPDCNNw&scan=1 |title=Index entry|work=FreeBMD|publisher=ONS}}{{cite web |url=https://blog.findmypast.co.uk/famous-family-trees-theresa-may-1406260824.html |title=Famous family trees: Theresa May |publisher=Blog.findmypast.co.uk |date=19 March 2013 |accessdate=1 July 2016 |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/theresa-may-iron-lady-in-waiting-8527165.html|website=[[The Independent]] |accessdate=30 October 2016|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161031025743/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/theresa-may-iron-lady-in-waiting-8527165.html|archivedate=31 October 2016}} [[File:St Mary's Church and graveyard.jpg|thumb|200px|left|The [[St Mary the Virgin, Wheatley|Church of St. Mary the Virgin, Wheatley]], where May's father was vicar and where May married{{cite news|last=Mendick|first=Robert|title=The Oxford romance that has guided Theresa May from tragedy to triumph|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/07/09/the-oxford-romance-that-has-guided-theresa-may-from-tragedy-to-t/|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=9 July 2016|accessdate=13 July 2016|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160713070035/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/07/09/the-oxford-romance-that-has-guided-theresa-may-from-tragedy-to-t/|archivedate=13 July England and Wales|Roman Catholic]] independent school in [[Begbroke]], which closed in 1984.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/8513906/How-clashes-with-Theresa-May-led-Dame-Pauline-Neville-Jones-to-quit.html |title=How clashes with Theresa May led Dame Pauline Neville Jones to quit |work=The Sunday Telegraph |date=15 May 2011 |accessdate=5 July 2016 |last=Kite |first=Melissa |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160704190013/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/8513906/How-clashes-with-Theresa-May-led-Dame-Pauline-Neville-Jones-to-quit.html |archivedate=4 July 2016}}{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/in_depth/education/2000/first_day/741078.stm |title=Screaming arrival |date=8 May 2000 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=20 October 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170813153248/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/in_depth/education/2000/first_day/741078.stm |archivedate=13 August 2017}}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/?id=oXU7AwAAQBAJ&pg=PT230&lpg=PT230&dq=St.+Juliana's+Convent+School+for+Girls+1984#v=onepage&q=St.%20Juliana's%20Convent%20School%20for%20Girls%201984&f=false |title=The Little Book of Oxfordshire |first= Paul |last=Sullivan |publisher=History Press |date=2012 |location=New York |isbn=978-0-7524-8243-9 |accessdate=5 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archivedate=17 November 2017}} When she was 13, May won a place at the former Holton Park Girls' Grammar School, a state school in [[Wheatley, Oxfordshire|Wheatley]]. During her time as a pupil, the Oxfordshire education system was reorganised and the school became the new [[Wheatley Park School|Wheatley Park Comprehensive School]].{{cite news |url=http://www.oxfordmail.co.uk/news/community/memorylane/4424685.Girls_were_taught_in_idyllic_surroundings_at_Holton_Park/ |title=Girls were taught in idyllic surroundings at Holton Park |date=8 June 2009 |work=Oxford Mail |accessdate=28 July 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004232436/http://www.oxfordmail.co.uk/news/community/memorylane/4424685.Girls_were_taught_in_idyllic_surroundings_at_Holton_Park/ |archivedate=4 October 2013}} May later attended the [[University of Oxford]] where she read [[geography]] at [[St Hugh's College, Oxford|St Hugh's College]], graduating with a second class BA degree in 1977."Oxford University class list." ''The Times'' (London). 11 July 1977. p. 14. ==Early career== Between 1977 and 1983 May worked at the [[Bank of England]], and from 1985 to 1997 as a financial consultant and senior advisor in International Affairs at the [[UK Payments Administration|Association for Payment Clearing Services]].{{cite news|url=http://www.itv.com/news/meridian/2016-07-07/theresa-may-then-and-now-as-she-makes-a-bid-for-prime-minister-we-look-at-her-first-foray-into-westminster/|title=As Theresa May makes a bid for prime minister we look at her first foray into politics|accessdate=9 July 2016|date=7 July 2016|work=ITV News|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160708125747/http://www.itv.com/news/meridian/2016-07-07/theresa-may-then-and-now-as-she-makes-a-bid-for-prime-minister-we-look-at-her-first-foray-into-westminster/|archivedate=8 July 2016}} She married Philip May in September 1980. Her father died in a car accident in 1981 and her mother of [[multiple sclerosis]] the following year.{{cite news |last1=Day |first1=Elizabeth |title=Theresa May – what lies beyond the public image? |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/jul/27/theresa-may-profile-beyond-the-public-image |work=The Guardian |location=London |date=27 July 2014 |accessdate=10 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160715192717/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/jul/27/theresa-may-profile-beyond-the-public-image |archivedate=15 July 2016}}{{cite news |last1=Mendick January 2017}} on the [[London Borough of Merton]] from 1986 to 1994, where she was Chairman of Education (1988–90) and Deputy Group Leader and Housing Spokesman (1992–94). In the [[United Kingdom general election, 1992|1992 general election]] May stood unsuccessfully for the safe Labour seat of [[North West Durham (UK Parliament constituency)|North West Durham]], coming second to incumbent MP [[Hilary Armstrong]] by 12,747 votes (27.6%) to 26,734 (57.8%), with future Liberal Democrat leader [[Tim Farron]] coming third. May then stood at the [[Barking by-election, 1994|1994 Barking by-election]], which was prompted by the death of Labour MP [[Jo Richardson]]. The seat had been continuously held by Labour since it was created in 1945 and Labour candidate [[Margaret Hodge]] was expected to win easily, which she did, with 13,704 votes (72.1%). May came a distant third with 1,976 votes (10.4%). Ahead of the [[United Kingdom general election, 1997|1997 general election]], May was selected as the Conservative candidate for [[Maidenhead (UK Parliament constituency)|Maidenhead]], a new seat which was created from parts of the seats of [[Windsor and Maidenhead (UK Parliament constituency)|Windsor and Maidenhead]] and [[Wokingham (UK Parliament constituency)|Wokingham]]. She was elected with 25,344 votes (49.8%), almost double the total of second-placed Andrew Terence Ketteringham of the Liberal Democrats, who took 13,363 votes (26.3%). ==Early political career== Having entered [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Parliament]], May became a member of [[William Hague]]'s front-bench [[Her Majesty's Most Loyal Opposition (United Kingdom)|Opposition]] team, as Shadow Spokesman for Schools, Disabled People and Women (1998–1999). She became the first of the 1997 MPs to enter the Shadow Cabinet when in 1999 she was appointed Shadow Education and Employment Secretary. After the [[United Kingdom general election, 2001|2001 election]] the new Conservative leader [[Iain Duncan Smith]] kept her in the Shadow Cabinet, moving her to the Transport portfolio. May was appointed the first female [[Chairman of the Conservative Party]] in July 2002. During her speech at the 2002 Conservative Party Conference, she explained why, in her view, her party must change: "You know what people call us? The [[Nasty Party]]".{{cite book|first=Elizabeth|last=Knowles|title=Oxford Dictionary of Modern Quotations|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rjLTsncFKCgC&pg=PA217|date=23 August 2007|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|isbn=978-0-19-920895-1|page=217|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170225212002/https://books.google.com/books?id=rjLTsncFKCgC&pg=PA217|archivedate=25 February 2017}}{{cite book|first=Sarah|last=Childs|title=Women and British Party Politics: Descriptive, Substantive and Symbolic Representation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2yZ-AgAAQBAJ&pg=PT21|date=8 April 2008|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-21157-9|pages=21–22|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170225212241/https://books.google.com/books?id=2yZ-AgAAQBAJ&pg=PT21|archivedate=25 February 2017}} In 2003, she was sworn of the [[Privy Council of the United Kingdom|Privy Council]] and appointed Shadow [[Secretary of State for Transport]] after [[Michael Howard]]'s election as Conservative Party and Opposition Leader in November that year.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/3255441.stm |title=Howard unveils his top team |date=10 November 2003 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=9 June 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060311034146/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/3255441.stm |archivedate=11 March 2006}} In June 2004 she was moved to become [[Shadow Secretary of State for the Family]]. Following the [[United Kingdom general election, 2005|2005 general election]] she was also made Shadow [[Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport]]. [[David Cameron]] appointed her [[Shadow Leader of the House of Commons]] in December 2005 after his accession to the leadership. In January 2009, May was made Shadow [[Secretary of State for Work and Pensions]]. On 6 May 2010, May was re-elected MP for Maidenhead with an increased majority of 16,769{{spaced ndash}}60% of the vote. This followed an earlier failed attempt to unseat her in 2005 as one of the Liberal Democrats' leading "decapitation-strategy" targets.{{cite news ==Home Secretary== {{Main article|Home Office under Theresa May}} [[File:David Cameron's visit2.jpg|thumb|May with her then-leader [[David Cameron]], May 2010]] On 12 May 2010, when May was appointed [[Home Secretary]] and Minister for Women and Equality by Prime Minister [[David Cameron]] as part of his first Cabinet, she became the fourth woman to hold one of the British [[Great Offices of State]], after [[Margaret Thatcher]] ([[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]]), [[Margaret Beckett]] ([[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|Foreign Secretary]]) and [[Jacqui Smith]] (Home Secretary).{{cite news |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/theresa-may-flies-the-flag-for-women-in-government-1971727.html |title= Theresa May flies the flag for women in Government |work= The Independent |location= London |agency= Press Association |date= 12 May 2010 |accessdate= 16 September 2010 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100515123510/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/theresa-may-flies-the-flag-for-women-in-government-1971727.html |archivedate= 15 May 2010 |df= dmy-all }} As Home Secretary, May was also a member of the [[National Security Council (United Kingdom)|National Security Council]].{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/national-security/groups/national-security-council |title=National Security Council |publisher=Gov.uk |accessdate=7 November 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141107004019/https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/national-security/groups/national-security-council |archivedate=7 November 2014}} She was the longest-serving Home Secretary for over 60 years, since [[James Chuter Ede]] who served over six years and two months from August 1945 to October 1951. May's appointment as Home Secretary was somewhat unexpected, with [[Chris Grayling]] having served as shadow Home Secretary in opposition.{{cite news|last1=Morris|first1=Nigel|title=Theresa May is surprise choice to be Home Secretary|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/theresa-may-is-surprise-choice-to-be-home-secretary-1972260.html|work=The Independent|accessdate=10 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160819032255/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/theresa-may-is-surprise-choice-to-be-home-secretary-1972260.html|archivedate=19 August 2016}}{{cite web|title=Cabinet update: Theresa May is surprise Home Sec|url=http://www.theweek.co.uk/election-2015/14687/cabinet-update-theresa-may-is-surprise-home-sec|work=The Week|accessdate=10 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160918150316/http://www.theweek.co.uk/election-2015/14687/cabinet-update-theresa-may-is-surprise-home-sec|archivedate=18 September 2016}} May's debut as Home Secretary involved overturning several of the previous Labour government's measures on data collection and surveillance in England and Wales. By way of a government bill which became the [[Identity Documents Act 2010]], she brought about the abolition of the Labour government's [[Identity Cards Act 2006|National Identity Card]] and database scheme{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/identity-cards-to-be-scrapped-within-100-days-1984447.html |title=Identity cards to be scrapped within 100 days |date=27 May 2010 |work=The Independent |location=London |agency=Press Association |accessdate=28 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100530071415/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/identity-cards-to-be-scrapped-within-100-days-1984447.html |archivedate=30 May 2010}}{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/election_2010/8679072.stm |title=Identity cards set to be scrapped |date=12 May 2010 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=28 October 2010}} and reformed the regulations on the retention of DNA samples for suspects and controls on the use of [[CCTV]] cameras. In May 2010, May announced the adjournment of the deportation to the United States of alleged computer hacker [[Gary McKinnon]].{{cite news |url=http://timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article7131780.ece |title=Pentagon hacker Gary McKinnon wins extradition reprieve |last=Sugden |first=Joanna |date=21 May 2010 |work=The Times |accessdate=28 October 2010 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528062652/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article7131780.ece |archivedate=28 May 2010}} {{subscription required}} She also suspended the registration scheme for carers of children and vulnerable people, with May saying that the measures were "draconian. You were assumed to be guilty until you were proven innocent, and told you were able to work with children."{{cite news |last=Coughlan |first=Sean |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/10314055.stm |title=Child abuse vetting scheme cancelled as 'draconian' |publisher=BBC News |date=15 June 2010 |accessdate=16 September 2010}}{{cite press release Lib Dem peer and former Director of Public Prosecutions [[Ken Macdonald]] accused May of an "ugly and unhelpful" attempt to implicate those who were concerned about the police action of "condoning terrorism".{{cite news |last= Watt |first= Nicholas |url= https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2013/aug/22/theresa-may-david-miranda-comments |title= Theresa May attacked for comments on critics of David Miranda's detention |work= The Guardian |location= London |date= 22 August 2013 |accessdate= 19 October 2013 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131020231937/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2013/aug/22/theresa-may-david-miranda-comments |archivedate= 20 October 2013 |df= dmy-all }} The High Court subsequently acknowledged there were "indirect implications for press freedom" but ruled the detention legal.{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/feb/19/david-miranda-detention-lawful-court-glenn-greenwald |title= David Miranda detention at Heathrow airport was lawful, high court rules |work= The Guardian |last1= Travis |first1= Alan |last2= Taylor |first2= Matthew |last3= Wintour |first3= Patrick |location= London |date= 19 February 2014 |accessdate= 31 July 2014 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140731015603/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/feb/19/david-miranda-detention-lawful-court-glenn-greenwald |archivedate= 31 July 2014 |df= dmy-all }} May also championed legislation popularly dubbed the [[Investigatory Powers Bill|Snooper's Charter]], requiring internet and mobile service providers to keep records of internet usage, voice calls, messages and email for up to a year in case police requested access to the records while investigating a crime. The Liberal Democrats had blocked the [[Draft Communications Data Bill|first attempt]],{{cite news|last1=Gayle|first1=Damien|title=Theresa May to revive her 'snooper's charter' now Lib Dem brakes are 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160823043150/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/may/09/theresa-may-revive-snoopers-charter-lib-dem-brakes-off-privacy-election|archivedate=23 August 2016}} but after the Conservative Party obtained a majority in the 2015 general election May announced a new [[Draft Investigatory Powers Bill]] similar to the Draft Communications Data Bill, surveillance bill|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/11/01/uk-britain-security-surveillance-idUKKCN0SQ1PG20151101|accessdate=10 November 2015|agency=Reuters|date=1 November 2015}} ===Police and crime=== Speaking at the [[Association of Chief Police Officers]] (ACPO) conference in June 2010, May announced radical cuts to the Home Office budget, likely to lead to a reduction in police numbers.{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/10453370.stm |title= Police must do more |date=29 June 2010 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=29 June 2010}} In July 2010, May presented the House of Commons with proposals for a fundamental review of the previous Labour government's security and counter-terrorism legislation, including "stop and search" powers, and her intention to review the 28-day limit on detaining terrorist suspects without charge.{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/politics/10619419.stm |title=Counter-terrorism measures to face government review |date=13 July 2010 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=14 July 2010}}{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/democracylive/hi/house_of_commons/newsid_8815000/8815378.stm |title= May announces scope of anti-terror law review |date= 13 July 2010 |work= BBC Democracy Live |accessdate= 14 July 2010 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100717055653/http://news.bbc.co.uk/democracylive/hi/house_of_commons/newsid_8815000/8815378.stm |archivedate= 17 July 2010 |df= dmy-all }} In July 2010, May announced a package of reforms to policing in England and Wales in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-10757014 |title=Radical police shake-up announced |date=26 July 2010 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=26 July 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100726100849/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-10757014 |archivedate=26 July 2010}} The previous Labour Government's central crime agency, [[Serious Organised Crime Agency|Soca (Serious Organised Crime Agency)]], was to be replaced by a new [[National Crime Agency]]. In common with the Conservative Party 2010 general election manifesto's flagship proposal for a "[[Big Society]]" based on voluntary action, May also proposed increasing the role of civilian "reservists" for crime control. The reforms were rejected by the Opposition [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]]. Following the actions of some members of [[Black Bloc]] in vandalising allegedly [[UK Uncut|tax-avoiding]] shops and businesses on the day of the March 2011 TUC march, the Home Secretary unveiled reforms{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/mar/28/police-new-powers-cuts-protest-home-secretary?INTCMP=ILCNETTXT3487 |title=Police may be given new powers after cuts protest, says home secretary |date=28 March 2011 |work=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=1 April 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104093739/http://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/mar/28/police-new-powers-cuts-protest-home-secretary?INTCMP=ILCNETTXT3487 |archivedate=4 November 2013}} curbing the right to protest, including giving police extra powers to remove masked individuals and to police social networking sites to prevent [[Public Order Act 1986|illegal protest]] without police consent or notification.{{cite news|url=http://www.publicservice.co.uk/news_story.asp?id=15918 |title=Police may get social media crime powers |date=29 March 2011 |work=publicservice.co.uk Ltd |accessdate=1 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110407025057/http://www.publicservice.co.uk/news_story.asp?id=15918 |archivedate=7 April 2011}} In 2012, despite inquiries by both [[Scotland Yard]] and the [[Independent Police Complaints Commission]] ruling that there was no new evidence to warrant further investigation, after discussions with [[Doreen Lawrence|Dame Doreen Lawrence]], May commissioned [[Mark Ellison]] to review Scotland Yard's investigations into alleged police corruption.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/lawrence-murder-police-corruption-will-be-investigated-7811117.html|title=May defies Met to order inquiry after Independent campaign|author=Andrew Grice & Paul Peachey|publisher=[[The Independent]]|date=2 June 2012|accessdate=7 March 2014}} The report was presented to Parliament by May on 6 March 2014. [[Bernard Hogan-Howe|Sir Bernard Hogan-Howe]], [[Commissioner of the Metropolitan Police]] said the report, which has prompted an inquiry into undercover policing, was "devastating".{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-26485664|title=Hogan-Howe vows to restore trust in Met after new Lawrence row|publisher=BBC News|date=7 March 2014|accessdate=7 March 2014}} In July 2013, May welcomed the fact that crime had fallen by more than 10% under the coalition government, while still being able to make savings. She said that this was partly due to the government removing red tape and scrapping targets to allow the police to concentrate on crime fighting.{{cite press release |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/crime-is-down-by-more-than-10-under-this-government |title=Crime is down by more than 10% under this government |publisher=Home Office |date=18 July 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160917172845/https://www.gov.uk/government/news/crime-is-down-by-more-than-10-under-this-government |archivedate=17 September 2016}} In 2014, May delivered a speech to the [[Police Federation of England and Wales|Police Federation]], in which she criticised aspects of the culture of the police force.{{cite news |last1=Robinson |first1=Nick |title=May tells police – change or be changed |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-27511997 |publisher=BBC News |date=21 May 2014 |accessdate=10 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170214033013/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-27511997 |archivedate=14 February 2017}} In the speech, she said: {{blockquote|When you remember the list of recent revelations about police misconduct, it is not enough to mouth platitudes about "a few bad apples". The problem might lie with a minority of officers, but it is still a significant problem, and a problem that needs to be addressed ... according to one survey carried out recently, only 42% of black people from a Caribbean background trust the police. That is simply not sustainable ... I will soon publish proposals to strengthen the protections available to whistleblowers in the police. I am creating a new criminal offence of police corruption. And I am determined that the use of stop and search must come down, become more targeted and lead to more arrests.{{cite web|last1=May|first1=Theresa|title=The police must change and so must the Federation|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/speeches/home-secretarys-police-federation-2014-speech|website=Gov.uk|accessdate=10 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160818081359/https://www.gov.uk/government/speeches/home-secretarys-police-federation-2014-speech|archivedate=18 August 2016|df=dmy-all}}}} On 9 December 2010, in the wake of violent [[2010 United Kingdom student protests|student demonstrations]] in central London against increases to higher-education [[Tuition fees in the United handling of the protests.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/law-and-order/8193115/Royal-car-attack-How-did-the-police-get-it-so-wrong-again.html |title=Royal car attack: How did |title=Police could use water cannon to disperse rioters, Theresa May says |date=12 December 2010 |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/8197432/Police-could-use-water-cannon-to-disperse-rioters-Theresa-May-says.html |accessdate=9 August 2011 |deadurl=no 2012}} She rejected their use following the [[2011 England riots|widespread rioting in summer 2011]] and said: "the way we police in Britain is not through use of water cannon. The way we police in Britain is through consent of communities." May said: "I condemn utterly the violence in Tottenham... Such disregard for public safety and property will not be tolerated, and the Metropolitan Police have my full support in restoring order."{{cite news |title= London riots: Police patrol streets after violence |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-14435251 |publisher= BBC News |date= 7 August 2011 |accessdate= 9 August 2011 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110809203535/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-14435251 |archivedate= 9 August 2011 |df= dmy-all }} In the aftermath of the riots May urged the identification of as many as possible of the young criminals involved. She said: "when I was in Manchester last week, the issue was raised to me about the anonymity of juveniles who are found guilty of crimes of this sort. The Crown Prosecution Service is to order prosecutors to apply for anonymity to be lifted in any youth case they think is in the public interest. The law currently protects the identity of any suspect under the age of 18, even if they are convicted, but it also allows for an application to have such restrictions lifted, if deemed appropriate." May added that "what I've asked for is that CPS guidance should go to prosecutors to say that where possible, they should be asking for the anonymity of juveniles who are found guilty of criminal activity to be lifted".{{cite news |last=Whitehead |first=Tom |date=14 August 2011 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/8700761/UK-riots-juveniles-could-be-named-and-shamed-says-Theresa-May.html |title=UK riots: Juveniles could be named and shamed, says Theresa May |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |accessdate=28 November 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131114224855/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/8700761/UK-riots-juveniles-could-be-named-and-shamed-says-Theresa-May.html |archivedate=14 November 2013}} ====Anti-social behaviour==== In July 2010, May proposed to review the previous [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] Government's [[anti-social behaviour]] legislation signalling the abolition of the "[[Asbo|Anti-Social Behaviour Order]]" (ASBO). She identified the policy's high level of failure with almost half of ASBOs breached between 2000 and 2008, leading to "fast-track" criminal convictions. May proposed a less punitive, community-based approach to tackling social disorder. May suggested that anti-social behaviour policy "must be turned on its head", reversing the ASBO's role as the flagship crime control policy legislation under Labour.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-10784060 |title=Time to 'move beyond ASBOS' says Home Secretary May |date=28 July 2010 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=28 July 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728185910/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-10784060 |archivedate=28 July 2010}}{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/7914859/Home-Secretary-signals-the-end-of-Asbos.html |title=Home Secretary signals the end of Asbos |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=28 July 2010 |accessdate=31 July 2010 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100731090347/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/7914859/Home-Secretary-signals-the-end-of-Asbos.html |archivedate=31 July 2010}} Former Labour Home Secretaries [[David Blunkett]] (who introduced ASBOs) and [[Alan Johnson]] expressed their disapproval of the proposals.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/approach-to-antisocial-behaviour-must-be-turned-on-its-head-2037410.html |title=Approach to anti-social behaviour "must be turned on its head" |date=28 July 2010 |work=The Independent |location=London |accessdate=28 July 2010 |first=Wesley |last=Johnson |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100730123651/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/approach-to-antisocial-behaviour-must-be-turned-on-its-head-2037410.html |archivedate=30 July 2010}} ====Drug policy==== [[File:Deakhat.jpg|thumb|[[Khat]] bundles]] In July 2013, May decided to ban the stimulant [[khat]], against the advice of the [[Advisory Council on the Misuse of Drugs]] (ACMD). The council reached the conclusion that there was "insufficient evidence" it caused health problems.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-23163017 "Herbal stimulant khat to be banned"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130711045838/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-23163017 |date=11 July 2013 }}. BBC News. 3 July 2013. Explaining the change in the classification May said: "The decision to bring khat under control is finely balanced and takes into account the expert scientific advice and these broader concerns", and pointed out that the product had already been banned in the majority of other EU member states, as well as most of the G8 countries including Canada and the US.[https://www.standard.co.uk/panewsfeeds/may-under-fire-for-banning-khat-8685624.html "May under fire for banning khat".] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130707042248/http://www.standard.co.uk/panewsfeeds/may-under-fire-for-banning-khat-8685624.html |date=7 July 2013 }} ''London Evening Standard''. 3 July 2013. A report on khat use by the ACMD published in January 2013 had noted the product had been associated with "acute psychotic episodes", "chronic liver disease" and family breakdown. However, it concluded that there is no risk of harm for most users, and recommended that khat remain uncontrolled due to lack of evidence for these associations.[https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/144120/report-2013.pdf ACMD Report on Khat] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160205044630/https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/144120/report-2013.pdf |date=5 February 2016 }}. 2013. Liberal Democrat minister [[Norman Baker]] accused May of suppressing proposals to treat rather than prosecute minor drug offenders from a report into drug policy commissioned by the Home Office.{{Cite news |date=27 December 2014 |title=Norman Baker reveals drugs proposals Theresa May stripped from report |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/dec/26/norman-baker-reveals-drugs-proposals-theresa-may-stripped-from-report |work=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=27 December 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141227044503/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/dec/26/norman-baker-reveals-drugs-proposals-theresa-may-stripped-from-report |archivedate=27 December 2014}}{{Cite news|date=26 December 2014 |title=Ex-minister Norman Baker leaks details on Home Secretary's drug stance |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/exminister-norman-baker-leaks-details-on-home-secretarys-drug-stance-9945643.html |work=The Independent |location=London |accessdate=27 December 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141226183911/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/exminister-norman-baker-leaks-details-on-home-secretarys-drug-stance-9945643.html |archivedate=26 December 2014}} The Home Office denied that its officials had considered this as part of their strategy.
