===Immigration=== {{See also|Racism in the UK Conservative Party#Accusations against Theresa May{{!}}Accusations of anti-immigrant racism as Home Secretary}} In 2010, May promised to bring the level of net migration down to less than 100,000.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/oct/06/theresa-may-to-tell-tory-conference-that-mass-migration-threatens-uk-cohesion |title=Theresa May to tell Tory conference that mass migration threatens UK cohesion |work=The Guardian |location=London |date=6 October 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161027161451/https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/oct/06/theresa-may-to-tell-tory-conference-that-mass-migration-threatens-uk-cohesion |archivedate=27 October 2016}} ''The Independent'' reported in February 2015, "The [[Office for National Statistics]] (ONS) announced a net flow of 298,000 migrants to the UK in the 12 months to September 2014—up from 210,000 in the previous year." In total, 624,000 people [[Modern immigration to the United Kingdom|migrated to the UK]] in the year ending September 2014 and 327,000 left in the same period. Statistics showed "significant increases in migration among both non-EU citizens—up 49,000 to 292,000—and EU citizens, which rose by 43,000 to 251,000."{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/generalelection/tory-immigration-pledge-failed-spectacularly-as-figures-show-net-migration-nearly-three-times-as-high-as-david-cameron-promised-10071710.html |title=David Cameron immigration pledge 'failed spectacularly' as figures show net migration almost three times as high as Tories promised |date=26 February 2015 |work=The Independent |location=London |first=Andrew |last=Grice |accessdate=20 July 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150707150837/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/generalelection/tory-immigration-pledge-failed-spectacularly-as-figures-show-net-migration-nearly-three-times-as-high-as-david-cameron-promised-10071710.html |archivedate=7 July 2015}} In May 2012 she told the [[Daily Telegraph]] of her intention "to create here in Britain a [[Home Office hostile environment policy|really hostile environment]] for illegal migration,”Kirkup, James (25 May 2012). [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/immigration/9291483/Theresa-May-interview-Were-going-to-give-illegal-migrants-a-really-hostile-reception.html "Theresa May interview: 'We’re going to give illegal migrants a really hostile reception’"] – via www.telegraph.co.uk. May rejected the European Union's proposal of [[European migrant crisis#Relocation and resettlement of asylum seekers|compulsory refugee quotas]].Travis, Alan (11 May 2015). [https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/may/11/home-secretary-theresa-may-eu-emergency-resettlement-programme-theresa-may "Home secretary hardens refusal to accept EU resettlement programme"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170127211502/https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/may/11/home-secretary-theresa-may-eu-emergency-resettlement-programme-theresa-may |date=27 January 2017 }}. ''The Guardian'' (London). She said that it was important to help people living in war-zone regions and refugee camps but "not the ones who are strong and rich enough to come to Europe"."[http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/refugee-policy-of-chancellor-merkel-divides-europe-a-1053603.html Mother Angela: Merkel's Refugee Policy Divides Europe] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151002024728/http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/refugee-policy-of-chancellor-merkel-divides-europe-a-1053603.html |date=2 October 2015 }}". ''[[Der Spiegel]].'' 21 September 2015. In May 2016, ''The Daily Telegraph'' reported that she had tried to save £4m by rejecting an intelligence project to use aircraft surveillance to detect illegal immigrant boats.{{cite news |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/05/31/theresa-may-scrapped-aerial-border-surveillance-despite-warnings/ |title= Theresa May scrapped aerial border surveillance despite warnings from former security minister |work= The Daily Telegraph |location= London |last= Dominiczak |first= Peter |date= 31 May 2016 |accessdate= 31 May 2016 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160602103955/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/05/31/theresa-may-scrapped-aerial-border-surveillance-despite-warnings/ |archivedate= 2 June 2016 |df= dmy-all }} ====Family migration==== In June 2012, Theresa May announced that new restrictions would be introduced to reduce the number of non-[[European Economic Area]] family migrants. The changes were mostly intended to apply to new applicants after 9 July 2012.{{cite web |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201213/cmhansrd/cm120611/debtext/120611-0002.htm |title=House of Commons Hansard Debates for 11 Jun 2012 (pt 0002) |publisher=UK Parliament |accessdate=19 October 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020164414/http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201213/cmhansrd/cm120611/debtext/120611-0002.htm |archivedate=20 October 2013}} The newly introduced rules came into effect on 9 July 2012 allowing only those British citizens earning more than £18,600 to bring their spouses or their children to live with them in the UK. This figure would rise significantly in cases where visa applications are also made for children. They also increased the current two-year probationary period for partners to 5 years. The rules also prevent any adult and elderly dependents from settling in the UK unless they can demonstrate that, as a result of age, [[illness]] or [[disability]], they require a level of long-term personal care that can only be provided by a relative in the UK.{{cite web|last=Grower|first=Melanie|title=Changes to Immigration Rules for family members – Commons Library Standard Note SN-06353|url=http://www.parliament.uk/briefing-papers/SN06353|date=18 December 2012|accessdate=6 January 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130105063524/http://www.parliament.uk/briefing-papers/SN06353|archivedate=5 January 2013}} The [[House of Lords]] was concerned about the immigration issue and therefore addressed the PM in Parliament as to whether she had examined the impact on communities and families on modest incomes, but it received no direct response.{{cite news|last = Mair|first = Lucy|title = Supreme court strikes down Home Office's back-door changes to immigration rules|url = https://www.theguardian.com/law/2012/jul/18/supreme-court-immigration-rules|accessdate = 16 March 2013|newspaper = The Guardian|date = 18 July 2012|deadurl = no|archiveurl = (advocacy group)|Liberty]] concluded that the new rules showed scant regard to the impact they would have on genuine families.{{cite web |title = Liberty's briefing on the Statement of Changes in Immigration Rules |url = http://www.liberty-human-rights.org.uk/pdfs/policy12/liberty-s-briefing-on-the-statement-of-changes-in-immigration-rules-june-201.pdf |first = Yusef |last = Salehi |first2 = 2013}} ====Deportation decisions==== [[File:Memorandum of Understanding on transnational crime (5937407114).jpg|thumb|May, David Cameron and [[Najib Razak]], 14 July 2011]] At the Conservative Party I am not making this up—he had a pet cat". In response, the Royal Courts of Justice issued a statement, denying that this was the reason for the tribunal's decision in that case, and stating that the real reason was that he was in a genuine relationship with a British partner, and owning a pet cat was simply one of many pieces of evidence given to show that the relationship was "genuine". The Home Office had failed to apply its own rules for dealing with unmarried partners of people settled in the UK.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-15160326 |title= Theresa May under fire over deportation cat claim |date= 4 October 2011 |publisher= BBC News |accessdate= 5 October 2011 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111005020900/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-15160326 |archivedate= 5 October 2011 |df= dmy-all }} Amnesty International said May's comments only fuelled "myths and misconceptions" about the Human Rights Act and Justice Secretary [[Kenneth Clarke]] subsequently called May's comments "laughable and childlike."{{cite news|url=http://www.thisisnottingham.co.uk/Clarke-hits-childish-remarks/story-13490799-detail/story.html |title=Clarke hits out at 'childish remarks' |date=6 October 2011 |work=Nottingham Post |accessdate=14 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111008201216/http://www.thisisnottingham.co.uk/Clarke-hits-childish-remarks/story-13490799-detail/story.html |archivedate=8 October 2011}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-15160326|title=Theresa May under fire over deportation cat claim|publisher=BBC News|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005020900/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-15160326|archivedate=5 October 2011|date=4 October 2011}} In June 2012, May was found in [[contempt of court]] by Judge Barry Cotter, and stood accused of "totally unacceptable and regrettable behaviour", being said to have shown complete disregard for a legal agreement to free an Algerian from a UK Immigration Detention Centre. asylum seeker |work= The Guardian |location= London |date= 16 November 2013 |accessdate= 28 November 2013 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131130222427/http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/nov/16/end-of-life-plan-hunger-striker |archivedate= 30 November 2013 |df= dmy-all }} ====Abu Qatada deportation==== [[File:Abu Qatada boards plane.jpg|thumb|Abu Qatada's deportation to Jordan]] On 7 July 2013, [[Abu Qatada]], a radical cleric arrested in 2002, was deported to [[Jordan]] after a decade-long battle that had cost the nation £1.7 million in legal fees,{{cite news |last1=Ttavis |first1=Alan |title=Theresa May criticises human rights convention after Abu Qatada affair |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/08/theresa-may-human-rights-abu-qatada |work=The Guardian |location=London |date=8 July 2013 |accessdate=2 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160717201325/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/08/theresa-may-human-rights-abu-qatada |archivedate=17 July 2016}} and numerous prior Home Secretaries had been unable to resolve.{{cite news|title=Abu Qatada deported from UK to stand trial in Jordan|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-23213740|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=2 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160718082054/http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-23213740|archivedate=18 July 2016}} The deportation was the result of a treaty negotiated by May in April 2013, under which Jordan agreed to give Qatada a fair trial, by not using evidence that may have been obtained through torture against him.{{cite news |title=Abu Qatada timeline |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-17769990 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=2 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160718082058/http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-17769990 |archivedate=18 July 2016}} May has frequently pointed to Qatada's deportation as a triumph, guaranteeing in September 2013 that "he will not be returning to the UK", and declaring in her 2016 leadership campaign announcement that she was told that she "couldn't deport Abu Qatada" but that she "flew to Jordan and negotiated the treaty that got him out of Britain for good".{{cite news |last1=Halliday |first1=Josh |title=Abu Qatada will not be allowed back in UK, says Theresa May |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/sep/24/abu-qatada-not-allowed-back-uk-theresa-may-jordan-acquittal-terror |work=The Guardian |location=London |date=24 September 2014 |accessdate=2 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160717201355/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/sep/24/abu-qatada-not-allowed-back-uk-theresa-may-jordan-acquittal-terror |archivedate=17 July 2016}}{{cite news |last1=Rentoul |first1=John |title=Boring and competent Theresa May is what the nation needs after the shock of the Brexit vote |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/boring-and-competent-theresa-may-is-what-the-nation-needs-after-the-shock-of-the-brexit-vote-a7114531.html |work=The Independent |location=London |date=1 July 2016 |accessdate=2 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160701191546/http://www.independent.co.uk/voices/boring-and-competent-theresa-may-is-what-the-nation-needs-after-the-shock-of-the-brexit-vote-a7114531.html |archivedate=1 July 2016}} The Qatada deportation also shaped May's views on the [[European Convention on Human Rights]] and [[European Court of Human Rights]], saying that they had "moved the goalposts" and had a "crazy interpretation of our human rights laws", as a result, May has since campaigned against the institutions, saying that British withdrawal from them should be considered. ===="Go Home" advertisements==== {{main|"Go Home" vans}} {{External media |image1=[https://static.independent.co.uk/s3fs-public/styles/story_large/public/thumbnails/image/2013/07/31/11/immigration.jpg Image of the "Go Home" advert vans]. From ''[[The Independent]]'', Credit: Home Office/PA. |float=right |width=250px}} In August 2013, the Home Office engaged in an advertising campaign directed at illegal immigrants.{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/theresa-may-the-new-prime-ministers-5-most-controversial-moments-a7142321.html|title=Theresa May: The new Prime Minister's five most controversial moments|last=Agerholm|first=Harriet|date=18 July 2016|newspaper=The Independent|accessdate=31 January 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170131214148/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/theresa-may-the-new-prime-ministers-5-most-controversial-moments-a7142321.html|archivedate=31 January 2017}} The advertisements, in the form of mobile advertising hoardings on the back of lorries, told illegal immigrants to "go home or face arrest", with an image of a person in handcuffs, and were deployed in six London boroughs with substantial ethnic minority populations. They were widely criticized as creating a [[Home Office hostile environment policy|hostile atmosphere]] for members of ethnic minority groups.{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/immigration/10232988/Race-hate-inquiry-into-Home-Office-go-home-billboards.html|title=Race-hate inquiry into Home Office 'go home' September 2017}} The shadow Home Secretary, [[Yvette Cooper]], described their language as being reminiscent of that used by the [[National Front (UK)|National Front]] in the 1970s.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-24624383|title=Theresa May says 'go home' will not be rolled out across UK|date=22 October 2013|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=31 January 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170405220747/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-24624383|archivedate=5 April 2017}} An adjudication by the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) said that "the claim [that 106 arrests were made last week] was misleading and had not been substantiated" was followed by the advertisements being withdrawn after being banned by the ASA.{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/home-office-anti-immigration-go-home-vans-banned-by-advertising-watchdog-8868081.html|title=Home Office anti-immigration 'go home' vans banned February 2017}} ====Passport backlog==== In mid 2014, the Passport Office faced a backlog in developing processing passport applications, with around 30,000 applications hit by delays.{{Cite news |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/7a534864-f24e-11e3-9e59-00144feabdc0.html |work=[[Financial Times]] |location=London |accessdate=6 July 2014 |deadurl=no scandal==== {{main|Windrush scandal}} In April 2018, May's [[Home Office hostile environment policy|hostile environment policy]] became the focus of British politics in what came to be known as the |df= dmy-all }} ==Prime Minister== {{Main article|Premiership of Theresa May}} ===Leadership election=== {{Further information|Conservative Party (UK) leadership election, 2016}} On 30 June 2016, May announced her candidacy for the leadership of the Conservative Party to replace [[David Cameron]], who resigned following the outcome of the [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|European Union membership referendum]] in which 52% of voters voted in favour of leaving the EU. May emphasised the need for unity within the party regardless of positions on leaving the EU, saying she could bring "strong leadership" and a "positive vision" for the country's future. Despite having backed a vote to remain in the EU, she insisted that there would be no second referendum, saying: "The campaign was fought... and the public gave their verdict. There must be no attempts to remain inside the EU, no attempts to rejoin it through the back door... Brexit means Brexit". An opinion poll that day found 47% of people choosing May as their preferred candidate to be Prime Minister.{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/story/1719848/theresa-may-is-britons-favourite-for-pm-poll |title=Theresa May Is Britons' Favourite For PM – Poll |last=Carr |first=Harry |date=30 June 2016 |publisher=Sky News |accessdate=2 July 2016 |quote=The other candidates lagged far behind, with Michael Gove on 9% |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160702045052/http://news.sky.com/story/1719848/theresa-may-is-britons-favourite-for-pm-poll |archivedate=2 July 2016}} May's supporters included a number of Cabinet ministers, such as [[Amber Rudd]], [[Chris Grayling]], [[Justine Greening]], [[Jeremy Hunt]], [[Michael Fallon]] and [[Patrick McLoughlin]].{{cite news |last=Asthana |first=Anushka |date=1 July 2016 |title=Tory party leadership: support for Theresa May surges as Gove struggles |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/01/support-for-theresa-may-as-tory-party-leader-surges-as-gove-campaign-struggles |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=2 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160701234700/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/01/support-for-theresa-may-as-tory-party-leader-surges-as-gove-campaign-struggles |archivedate=1 July 2016}} She won the first round of voting on 5 July, receiving support from 165 MPs, with rivals [[Andrea Leadsom]] receiving 66 votes and [[Michael Gove]] 48. After the results were announced, May said she was "pleased" and "grateful" for the support of other MPs and confirmed that she wanted to unite the party and the UK, to negotiate the "best possible deal as we leave the EU", and to "make Britain work for everyone".{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-36718196 |title=Tory leadership: Theresa May tops first vote but Liam Fox out |publisher=BBC News |date=6 July 2016 |quote=She added: "I am the only candidate capable of delivering these three things as prime minister, and tonight it is clear that I am also the only one capable of drawing support from the whole of the Conservative Party." |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160705195213/http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-36718196 |archivedate=5 July 2016}} The two candidates with the fewest votes, [[Liam Fox]] and [[Stephen Crabb]], immediately announced their support for May.{{cite news |last=Asthana |first=Anushka |title=May takes big lead as Fox and Crabb drop out |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/05/theresa-may-conservative-leadership-contest-andrea-leadsom-michael-gove-first-round-vote |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=6 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160706161909/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/05/theresa-may-conservative-leadership-contest-andrea-leadsom-michael-gove-first-round-vote |archivedate=6 July 2016}} May came in first place in the second ballot on 7 July with an overwhelming majority of 199 MPs, compared with 84 for Leadsom and 46 for Gove, who was eliminated.{{cite news |title=Theresa May v Andrea Leadsom to be next prime minister |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-36737426 |accessdate=8 July 2016 |publisher=BBC News |date=8 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160708001014/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-36737426 |archivedate=8 July 2016}} Afterwards, May stated that she was delighted with her support among MPs, and she progressed to a vote of the Conservative Party membership against Leadsom.{{cite news |last=Cowburn |first=Ashley |date=7 July 2016 |title=Tory leadership election |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/tory-leadership-election-andrea-leadsom-theresa-may-michael-gove-conservative-next-prime-minister-a7125406.html |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |accessdate=7 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160708045902/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/tory-leadership-election-andrea-leadsom-theresa-may-michael-gove-conservative-next-prime-minister-a7125406.html |archivedate=8 July 2016}} On 11 July, Leadsom announced her withdrawal from the leadership contest hours after May had made her first official campaign speech, saying her lack of support amongst Conservative MPs compared to May would be too great a hindrance to becoming a credible Prime Minister.{{cite web |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/7939901e-4756-11e6-8d68-72e9211e86ab.html |title=May to take over as UK PM by Wednesday |date=11 July 2016 |work=Financial Times |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160712233009/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/7939901e-4756-11e6-8d68-72e9211e86ab.html |archivedate=12 July 2016}} As the sole remaining candidate, May was formally declared Leader of the Conservative Party that evening.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-36768148 |title=Theresa May to succeed Cameron as UK PM on Wednesday |date=13 July 2016 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=11 July 2016 |quote=The timing of the handover of power from David Cameron looks set to be after PM's questions on Wednesday. |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160711161227/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-36768148 |archivedate=11 July 2016}}{{cite news |date=11 July 2016 |title=Theresa May gives first speech as leader of the Conservative party |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/07/11/theresa-may-launches-conservative-leadership-bid-as-andrea-leads/ |newspaper=The Telegraph |location=London |accessdate=11 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160711104910/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/07/11/theresa-may-launches-conservative-leadership-bid-as-andrea-leads/ |archivedate=11 July 2016}} ===Appointment=== On 13 July 2016, two days after becoming Leader of the Conservative Party, May was appointed Prime Minister by [[Monarchy of the United Kingdom|Queen]] [[Elizabeth II]], becoming only the second female British Prime Minister after [[Margaret Thatcher]], and the first female British Prime Minister of the 21st century.{{cite web|url=https://www.royal.uk/queen-received-audience-right-honourable-theresa-may|title=The Queen received in audience The Right Honourable Theresa May|last=Adam.Vallance|date=12 July 2016|accessdate=17 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160818170601/https://www.royal.uk/queen-received-audience-right-honourable-theresa-may|archivedate=18 August 2016}}{{cite news |title= PM-in-waiting Theresa May promises 'a better Britain' |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-36768148 |accessdate= 18 April 2017 |publisher= BBC News |date= 11 July 2016 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170125064900/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-36768148 |archivedate= 25 January 2017 |df= dmy-all }}[[List of elected or appointed female heads of government]] Addressing the world's media outside [[10 Downing Street]], May said that she was "honoured and humbled" to become Prime Minister. On becoming Prime Minister, May became the first woman to have held two of the [[Great Offices of State]]. Responding to some calls for an early general election, "sources close to Mrs May" said there was no need for such an election.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-36769898 |title=Tributes for David Cameron at his final cabinet as UK PM |author= |date=12 July 2016 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=12 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160712112741/http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-36769898 |archivedate=12 July 2016}} In a speech after her appointment, May emphasised the term "Unionist" in the name of the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]], reminding all of "the precious, precious bond between England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland."{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-northern-ireland-36789572 |title=Theresa May: Word unionist 'very important to me' |date=13 July 2016 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=14 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160714214126/http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-northern-ireland-36789572 |archivedate=14 July 2016}} By 15 July, May had travelled to [[Edinburgh]] to meet with [[First Minister of Scotland|First Minister]] [[Nicola Sturgeon]] to reinforce the bond between Scotland and the rest of the United Kingdom. "I'm coming here to show my commitment to preserving this special union that has endured for centuries," she explained.{{cite news |last=Stewart |first=Heather |date=14 July 2016 |title=Theresa May's decisive reshuffle draws line under Cameron era |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/14/theresa-mays-decisive-reshuffle-draws-line-under-cameron-era |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=15 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160714203907/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/14/theresa-mays-decisive-reshuffle-draws-line-under-cameron-era |archivedate=14 July 2016}} ===Cabinet changes=== May's first Cabinet appointment was described by [[Reuters]] as "one of the most sweeping government reshuffles for decades", and called "a brutal cull" by ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-wrapup-idUSKCN0ZU1HE |title=May builds new-look Brexit cabinet to steer EU divorce |last1=Holton |first1=Kate |last2=Pitas |first2=Costas |date=14 July 2016 |agency=Reuters |accessdate=14 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160715155255/http://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-wrapup-idUSKCN0ZU1HE |archivedate=15 July 2016}}{{cite news |last=Hughes |first=Laura |date=14 July 2016 |title=Theresa May appoints Justine Greening and Liz Truss after mass cull of old government sees Michael Gove and Nicky Morgan axed |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/07/14/theresa-mays-cabinet-reshuffle-who-will-join-boris-johnson-and/ |newspaper=The Telegraph |location=London |accessdate=14 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160714072212/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/07/14/theresa-mays-cabinet-reshuffle-who-will-join-boris-johnson-and/ |archivedate=14 July 2016}} Nine of Cameron's ministers, including several prominent members, were sacked or resigned from their posts. The early appointments were interpreted both as an effort to reunite the Conservative Party in the wake of the UK's vote to leave the EU and as "a shift to the right," according to ''[[The Guardian]]''.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/13/theresa-may-becomes-britains-prime-minister |title=Theresa May appeals to centre ground but cabinet tilts to the right |first=Heather |last=Stewart |date=13 July 2016 |work=The Guardian |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160713235732/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/13/theresa-may-becomes-britains-prime-minister |archivedate=13 July 2016}} ITV's Political Editor [[Robert Peston]] commented: "Her rhetoric is more left-wing than Cameron's was, her cabinet is more right-wing than his was."{{cite web |url=http://www.itv.com/news/2016-07-14/may-appoints-right-wing-cabinet-for-left-wing-agenda/ |title=May appoints right wing cabinet for left wing agenda |last=Peston |first=Robert |date=14 July 2016 |publisher=ITV News |accessdate=16 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160715155006/http://www.itv.com/news/2016-07-14/may-appoints-right-wing-cabinet-for-left-wing-agenda/ |archivedate=15 July 2016}} Although May had supported remaining in the EU, she appointed several of the most prominent advocates of [[Brexit]] to key Cabinet positions responsible for negotiating the [[United Kingdom withdrawal from the European Union]], including [[Boris Johnson]] as [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|Foreign Secretary]], [[David Davis (British politician)|David Davis]] as [[Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union|Brexit Secretary]], and [[Liam Fox]] as [[Secretary of State for International Trade|International Trade Secretary]], the latter two being new positions.{{Cite newspaper |last1=James |first1=William |last2=MacLellan |first2=Kylie |title=May Builds New-Look Brexit Cabinet to Steer EU Divorce |journal=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-wrapup-idUSKCN0ZU1HE |date=15 July 2016 |agency=[[Reuters]] |accessdate=15 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160715155255/http://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-wrapup-idUSKCN0ZU1HE |archivedate=15 July 2016}} Other key appointees included [[Amber Rudd]] as [[Home Secretary]] and [[Philip Hammond]] as [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]].{{cite news |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/0/who-is-david-davis-a-profile-of-britains-new-minister-for-brexit/ |title= Who is David Davis? A profile of Britain's new 'Brexit Secretary' |work= The Daily Telegraph |date= 14 July 2016 |accessdate= 15 July 2016 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160715023920/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/0/who-is-david-davis-a-profile-of-britains-new-minister-for-brexit/ |archivedate= 15 July 2016 |df= dmy-all }} ===First term=== {{Main article|First May ministry}} [[File:Vladimir Putin and Theresa May (2016-09-04) 02.jpg|thumb|May and [[Vladimir Putin]] during the [[2016 G20 Hangzhou summit|G20 summit]] in [[Hangzhou]]]] [[File:Theresa May speech to UN General Assembly.jpg|thumb|May speaking to the [[United Nations General Assembly]] in September 2016]] The [[First May ministry]] delayed the final approval for the [[Hinkley Point C nuclear power station]] in July 2016, a project which May had objected to when she was Home Secretary.{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/jul/29/hinkley-point-c-why-has-government-delayed-final-approval |title= Why have ministers delayed final approval for Hinkley Point C? |work= The Guardian |location= London |date= 29 July 2016 |accessdate= 31 July 2016 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160730205353/https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/jul/29/hinkley-point-c-why-has-government-delayed-final-approval |archivedate= 30 July 2016 |df= dmy-all }}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/jul/30/theresa-may-delayed-hinkley-point-chinese-beijing-vince-cable |title=Theresa May 'raised objections to project as home secretary' |work=The Guardian |date=30 July 2016 |accessdate=31 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160731203845/https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/jul/30/theresa-may-delayed-hinkley-point-chinese-beijing-vince-cable |archivedate=31 July 2016}} Her [[Special advisers (UK government)|political adviser]] [[Nick Timothy]] wrote an article in 2015 to oppose [[China]]'s involvement in sensitive sectors. He said that the government was "selling our [[national security]] to China" without [[rational]] concerns and "the Government seems intent on ignoring the evidence and presumably the advice of the security and intelligence agencies".{{cite web|url=http://www.conservativehome.com/thecolumnists/2015/10/nick-timothy-the-government-is-selling-our-national-security-to-china.html|title=Nick Timothy: The Government is selling our national security to China|website=[[Conservative Home]]|date=20 October 2015|accessdate=31 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160731135519/http://www.conservativehome.com/thecolumnists/2015/10/nick-timothy-the-government-is-selling-our-national-security-to-china.html|archivedate=31 July 2016}} In July 2016, when [[George Kerevan]] asked her whether she would be prepared to authorise the killing of a hundred thousand innocent persons by a nuclear strike; during the "[[Trident nuclear programme|Trident]] debate" inside the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]], May said "Yes. And I have to say to the honourable gentleman: the whole point of a deterrent is that our enemies need to know that we would be prepared to use it. Unlike [[Political positions of Jeremy Corbyn#Nuclear defence|some suggestions]] that we could have a nuclear deterrent but not actually be willing to use it, which come from the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] frontbench."{{cite AV media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6ODnL6mawWk&t=1173&lc=z12idn3rokrgjnbnh23afzv5dtrafzqj504 |people=Members of the House of Commons |date=18 July 2016 |title= Trident Debate – Theresa May Vs Jeremy Corbyn – UK Parliament – Nuclear Weapons Vote |medium=Video recording |accessdate=18 July 2016 |time=19 minutes and 33 seconds in |location=House of Commons, London |publisher=EU Debate |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161119214822/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6ODnL6mawWk&t=1173&lc=z12idn3rokrgjnbnh23afzv5dtrafzqj504 |archivedate=19 November 2016}} On 20 July, May attended her first [[Prime Minister's Questions]] since taking office, then afterwards made her first [[List of international prime ministerial trips made by Theresa May|overseas trip as prime minister]], visiting Berlin for talks with German Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]]. During the visit, May said that she would not trigger [[UK Invocation of Article 50|Article 50 of the Treaty of Lisbon]]—the process for withdrawing from the European Union—before 2017, suggesting it would take time for the UK to negotiate a "sensible and orderly departure" from the EU. However, although Merkel said it was right for the UK to "take a moment" before beginning the process, she urged May to provide more clarity on a timetable for negotiations. Shortly before travelling to Berlin, May had also announced that in the wake of the referendum, Britain would relinquish the [[presidency of the Council of the European Union]], which passes between member states every six months on a rotation basis, and that the UK had been scheduled to hold in the second half of 2017.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-36841066 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/20/angela-merkel-backs-theresa-mays-plan-not-to-trigger-brexit-this-year |title=Angela Merkel backs Theresa May's plan not to trigger Brexit this ''[[New Statesman]]'' ===2017 general election=== {{main|United Kingdom general election, 2017}} {{See also|Second May ministry}} On 18 April, May announced that she would call a parliamentary vote to hold an [[Snap election|early general election]] on 8 June, saying that it was the "only way to guarantee certainty and security for years ahead".{{cite news|title=May to seek snap election for 8 June|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-39629603|accessdate=18 April 2017|publisher=BBC|date=18 April 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170418101352/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-39629603|archivedate=18 April 2017}} May had previously ruled out an early election on five occasions over nine months.{{cite web|url=https://blogs.spectator.co.uk/2017/04/five-times-theresa-may-no-10-ruled-snap-general-election/#|title=Five times Theresa May ruled out a snap general election – Coffee House|date=18 April 2017|website=spectator.co.uk|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170418111721/https://blogs.spectator.co.uk/2017/04/five-times-theresa-may-no-10-ruled-snap-general-election/|archivedate=18 April 2017}} The election was the first snap election held under the [[Fixed-term Parliaments Act 2011]] after MPs gave May the two-thirds [[super-majority]] required.{{cite news|title=General election campaigning begins as MPs back June poll|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-39643804|accessdate=19 April 2017|publisher=BBC News|issue=19 April 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170419143625/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-39643804|archivedate=19 April 2017}} Unveiling the Conservative manifesto in [[Halifax, West Yorkshire|Halifax]] on 18 May, May promised a "mainstream government that would deliver for mainstream Britain".{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-2017-39956541|title=Conservative manifesto: Theresa May targets mainstream Britain'|date=18 May 2017|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=18 May 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170517233142/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-2017-39956541|archivedate=17 May 2017}} It proposed to balance the budget by 2025, raise spending on the NHS by £8bn per annum and on schools by £4bn per annum by 2022, remove the ban on new [[grammar school]]s, [[Means-tested benefit|means-test]] the [[Winter Fuel Payment|winter fuel allowance]], replace the [[State Pension (United Kingdom)|state pension]] "triple lock" with a "double lock" and require executive pay to be approved by a vote of shareholders. It dropped the 2015 pledge to not raise income tax or national insurance contributions but maintained a commitment to freeze [[Value-added tax|VAT]]. New [[sovereign wealth fund]]s for infrastructure, rules to prevent foreign takeovers of "critical national infrastructure" and [[Institute of technology|institutes of technology]] were also proposed.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/may/18/theresa-may-launches-conservative-manifesto-for-community-and-country|title=May signals break with Thatcherism in manifesto for 'country and community'|last=Mason|first=Rowena|date=18 May 2017|work=The Guardian|accessdate=18 May 2017|last2=Stewart|first2=Heather|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170518133532/https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/may/18/theresa-may-launches-conservative-manifesto-for-community-and-country|archivedate=18 May 2017}} The manifesto was noted for its intervention in industry, lack of tax cuts and increased spending commitments on public services.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-2017-39965837|title=Conservative manifesto: Theresa May's 'mainstream' pitch|last=Kuenssberg|first=Laura|date=18 May 2017|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=18 May 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519222727/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-2017-39965837|archivedate=19 May 2017}} On Brexit it committed to leaving the single market and [[European Union Customs Union|customs union]] while seeking a "deep and special partnership" and promised a vote in parliament on the final agreement.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-2017-39960311|title=Conservative manifesto summary: Key points at-a-glance|date=18 May 2017|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=18 May 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170518122902/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-2017-39960311|archivedate=18 May 2017}} The manifesto also proposed reforms to [[social care in England]] that would raise the threshold for free care from £23,250 to £100,000 while including property in the means test and permitting deferred payment after death. After attracting substantial media attention, four days after the manifesto launch May stated that the proposed social care reforms would now include an "absolute limit" on costs in contrast to the rejection of a cap in the manifesto.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-2017-40001221|title=General election: Theresa May changes social care plans|date=22 May 2017|work=BBC News|accessdate=22 May 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170522113910/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-2017-40001221|archivedate=22 May 2017}} She criticised the "fake" portrayal of the policy in recent days by Labour and other critics who had termed it a "dementia tax". [[London Evening Standard|''Evening Standard'']] editor [[George Osborne]] called the policy change a "U-turn".{{Cite news|url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-election-care-osborne-idUKKBN18I160|title=May to change social care pledge, George Osborne says|date=22 May 2017|work=Reuters UK|accessdate=22 May For this she was widely praised as successive governments going back to the 1980s had refused such an inquiry, some though speculated that May had simply been forced to announce the inquiry after a group legal action and news of fresh evidence were brought by Jason Evans.{{cite web |title=Government 'knew risks of contaminated blood months before making it public', son of victim claims |url=http://www.itv.com/news/central/2017-06-22/fight-for-justice-after-dad-given-contaminated-blood/ |website=ITV News |language=en}}{{cite news |last1=Worley |first1=Will |title=New evidence in NHS tainted blood scandal |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/new-evidence-in-nhs-tainted-blood-donation-scandal-28d0qmggs |work=The Times |date=4 July 2017 |language=en}} Additionally, Andy Burnham had threatened to take evidence to the police if an inquiry were not announced{{cite news |title=Contaminated blood scandal: Labour's Burnham threatens to go to police |url=https://news.sky.com/story/contaminated-blood-scandal-labours-burnham-threatens-to-go-to-police-10942488 |work=Sky News}}. From the 2017 general election to December 2017, May suffered no defeats in whipped votes in the House of Commons.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/theresa-may-brexit-bill-key-amendment-7-dominic-grieve-whips-eu-exit-package-anna-soubry-chuka-a8101636.html|title=Theresa May 'could face first Commons' defeat on Brexit bill next week' on key amendment|date=9 December 2017|work=The Independent|accessdate=30 December 2017}} On 13 December 2017, May lost a vote on the [[EU Withdrawal Bill]] by 309 votes to 305, due to 11 Conservatives voting against the government, including [[Stephen Hammond]] who was then Vice-Chairman of the Conservative Party.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/dec/13/tory-brexit-rebels-inflict-major-defeat-on-theresa-may|title=Tory Brexit rebels inflict major defeat on Theresa May|last1=Stewart|first1=Heather|date=14 December 2017|work=The Guardian|accessdate=30 December 2017|publisher=|last2=Walker|first2=Peter|last3=Elgot|first3=Jessica}}{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/stephen-hammond-fired-sacked-brexit-rebellion-tory-mp-theresa-may-latest-a8108691.html|title=The Tories have sacked their own vice-chairman after he helped defeat the Government over Brexit|date=13 December 2017|publisher=|work=The Independent|accessdate=30 December 2017}} May accused [[Russia]] of "threatening the international order", "seeking to weaponise information" and "deploying its state-run media organisations to plant fake stories". She mentioned Russia's meddling in [[German federal election, 2017|German federal election]] in 2017,"[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/theresa-may-russia-election-meddling-warning-cyber-warfare-latest-uk-a8053161.html Theresa May warns Russia over election meddling and vows to protect UK]". ''The Independent.'' 13 November 2017. after German government officials and security experts said there was no Russian interference."[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-germany-election-cyber/germany-sees-no-sign-of-cyber-attack-before-sept-24-election-idUSKCN1BU2KE Germany sees no sign of cyber attack before Sept. 24 election]". Reuters. 19 September 2017. May promised to confront [[China]] on human rights but was praised in [[Communist Party of China|Communist Party]]-controlled [[Media of China|media]] for 'sidestepping' [[human rights in China]] during her first official visit to the country."[http://www.theweek.co.uk/91374/china-applauds-auntie-theresa-may-for-sidestepping-human-rights-issue China applauds ‘Auntie’ Theresa May for sidestepping human rights issue]". ''[[The Week]]''. 2 February 2018. The ''[[Global Times]]'' said: "For the Prime Minister, the losses outweigh the gains if she appeases the British media at the cost of the visit’s friendly atmosphere." In May 2018, during a three-day state visit to the UK by Turkish president [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]], May declared that Britain is a "true friend" of [[Turkey]], but she added that "It is important that in defense of democracy, which has been facing extraordinary pressures from the [[2016 Turkish coup d'état attempt|failed coup]], instability across the border from Syria and from [[Kurdish–Turkish conflict (1978–present)|Kurdish terrorism]], Turkey does not lose sight of the values it is seeking to defend."{{cite web|url=http://www.kurdistan24.net/en/news/42566c81-ed95-49fe-b8bd-ec0aae9f8cf3 |title=UK's May uses phrase 'Kurdish terrorism' during Erdogan visit as Kurds protest in London|work=[[Kurdistan 24]]|date= 15 May 2018|accessdate=13 July 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/president-erdogan-theresa-may-post-brexit-trade-turkey-a8351531.html |title=Post-Brexit, the UK will need Turkey for trade – and Erdogan is using that to his advantage|work=The Independent|date= 14 May 2018|accessdate=13 July 2018}} ===Public opinion=== {{Main|Opinion polling for the next United Kingdom general election#Preferred Prime Minister polling}} May had a high approval rating during her first week as Prime Minister. |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/06/16/theresa-mays-silence-speaks-volumes-about-her-leadership-ambitio/ |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=16 June 2016 |accessdate=10 July June 2016}} Some in David Cameron's ministry likened May to a "submarine" on the issue of Brexit due to her perceived indifference towards the referendum and the EU.{{Cite news |last=Dominiczak |first=Peter |title=Theresa May accused of leaving David Cameron to 'fight alone' during the EU Referendum, according to former No 10 director | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/09/24/theresa-may-accused-of-leaving-david-cameron-to-fight-alone-duri/ |work=The Telegraph |date=24 September 2016 }} In a leaked recording prior to the [[Brexit]] referendum, May said, {{quote|I think the economic arguments are clear. I think being part of a 500-million trading bloc is significant for us. I think, as I was saying to you a little earlier, that one of the issues is that a lot of people will invest here in the UK because it is the UK in Europe. If we were not in Europe, I think there would be firms and companies who would be looking to say, do they need to develop a mainland Europe presence rather than a UK presence? So I think there are definite benefits for us in economic terms.[https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/oct/25/exclusive-leaked-recording-shows-what-theresa-may-really-thinks-about-brexit Exclusive: what Theresa May really thinks about Brexit shown in leaked recording] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161026091230/https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/oct/25/exclusive-leaked-recording-shows-what-theresa-may-really-thinks-about-brexit |date=26 October 2016 }} ''[[The Guardian]]''}} May also said Britain was more secure as part of the [[European Union|EU]] due to the European arrest warrant and Europe-wide information sharing among other factors. She said, "There are definitely things we can do as members of the European Union that I think keep us more safe". [[File:Manchester Brexit protest for Conservative conference, October 1, 2017 17.jpg|thumb|left|Manchester protests ahead of [[Conservative Party (UK) Conference|Conservative Party Conference]] in October 2017]] May's public reticence during the referendum campaign resulted in tensions with David Cameron and his pro-EU team.[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/leaked-recordings-reveal-theresa-may-s-pro-eu-stance-ahead-of-brexit-vote-a7380286.html Leaked recordings reveal Theresa May's pro-EU stance ahead of Brexit vote] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171001211444/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/leaked-recordings-reveal-theresa-may-s-pro-eu-stance-ahead-of-brexit-vote-a7380286.html |date=1 October 2017 }} ''[[The Independent]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/en/uk-pm-may-outlined-brexit-fears-pre-referendum/a-36155785|title=UK PM May outlined Brexit fears pre-referendum |date=26 October 2016|first=Deutsche Welle|last=(http://www.dw.com)|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161026234527/http://www.dw.com/en/uk-pm-may-outlined-brexit-fears-pre-referendum/a-36155785|archivedate=26 October 2016}} Following the referendum and her election as party leader, May signalled that she would support full withdrawal from the EU and prioritise immigration controls over remaining within the single market, leading some to contrast this with her earlier remarks on the earlier economic arguments. She later went on to say before the [[2017 UK general election]] that she would be willing to leave the EU without a deal, saying that "no deal is better than a bad deal. We have to be prepared to walk out".{{cite news | title=Theresa May prête à un Brexit sans accord | website=Le Figaro |location= Paris |date=29 May 2017 |url= http://www.lefigaro.fr/flash-actu/2017/05/29/97001-20170529FILWWW00354-theresa-may-prete-a-un-brexit-sans-accord.php |trans-title=Theresa May ready for Brexit without a deal |language=fr |accessdate=29 May 2017 |quote=La Première ministre britannique Theresa May a répété lundi qu'elle était prête à quitter la table des négociations sur le Brexit sans avoir obtenu d'accord avec l'Union européenne si les conditions ne sont pas satisfaisantes pour la Grande-Bretagne. | deadurl=no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170529234210/http://www.lefigaro.fr/flash-actu/2017/05/29/97001-20170529FILWWW00354-theresa-may-prete-a-un-brexit-sans-accord.php |archivedate=29 May 2017 | df=dmy-all }}{{cite news | title=May says prepared to leave EU without a Brexit deal | website=Reuters UK | date=29 May 2017 |url= http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-eu-may-idUKKBN18P21R | accessdate=29 May 2017 | deadurl=no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170529214000/http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-eu-may-idUKKBN18P21R |archivedate=29 May 2017 | df=dmy-all }} The [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Lib Dem]] leader, [[Tim Farron]], said it was "disappointing that Theresa May lacked the political courage to warn the public as she did a bunch of bankers in private about the devastating economic effects of Brexit. More disappointing is that now she is supposedly in charge, she is blithely ignoring her own warnings and is prepared to inflict an act of monumental self-harm on the UK economy by pulling Britain out of the single market." [[Phil Wilson (British politician)|Phil Wilson]] for the [[Open Britain]] group said, "It's good to know that privately Theresa May thinks what many of us have been saying publicly for a long time, leaving the single market would be bad for businesses and for our economy. Now she is prime minister, Theresa May is in an unrivalled position to act on her previous concerns, starting by putting membership of the single market at the heart of her government's negotiating position." On 22 September 2017, May officially made public the details of her Brexit proposal during a speech in [[Florence]],{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lUFpahcEOX8 |title=Archived copy '''Youth in Iraq''' are individuals that are between 15–24 years old. Youth represent 19.6% of [[Iraq]]’s population of 32 million. The median age is 21 years.<ref name="CIA World Factbook">{{cite web|title=CIA Factboook|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/iz.html}}</ref> The population continues to rise, as mass migration known as the [[Iraq diaspora]] has occurred.<ref name=aljazeera>{{cite web|title=Aljazeera|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/insideiraq/2009/10/2009108132427530259.html}}</ref>
The youth population have experienced poor health from the effects of both [[malnutrition]] and [[poverty]]. Securing employment is difficult for youth in Iraq. The youth [[dependency ratio]] is 70.6%.<ref name="CIA World Factbook"/>
The minimum age one can be considered an adult after committing a crime is seven.<ref name="Iraq Youth Policy">{{cite web|title=Iraq Youth Policy|url=http://www.youthpolicy.org/factsheets/country/iraq/|website=Iraq Youth Policy|accessdate=9 December 2014}}</ref>
== Leisure == The [[National Youth Orchestra of Iraq]] was formed due to the interest of youth pianist, [[Zuhal Sultan]]. Since forming in 2008, they have performed in numerous countries and hold auditions via YouTube annually.<ref>{{cite web|title=National Youth Orchestra of Iraq|url=http://www.nyoiraq.org/|website=NYOIraq.org|accessdate=9 December 2014}}</ref>
Dambala is a game that resembles the popular Western-style game, [[Bingo (U.S.)|bingo]]. Players can earn cash and prizes in Dambala. The popularity of the game has resulted in many Iraqi youth's participation. Dambala is played in clubs and bars.<ref>{{cite web|last1=al-Jaffal|first1=Omar|title=Iraq youth turn to bingo-like game|url=http://www.iraq-businessnews.com/2014/03/09/iraqi-youth-turn-to-bingo-like-game/|website=Iraq business news|publisher=Al-Monitor|accessdate=2014-10-22}}</ref>
Western-style is being emulated by youth in Iraq. For both male and female youth, tattoos are gaining popularity as well as the clothing that is worn.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bassem|first1=Wassim|title=Iraq youth strike balance between conservatism, modernity|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2013/09/iraq-youth-modern-conservative.html#|website=Al-Monitor|accessdate=2014-10-22}}</ref>
== Employment == Iraqi youth unemployment rates have increased. There are over 1 million unemployed Iraqi youth.<ref>{{cite web|title=Unesco|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/iraq-office/education/technical-vocational-education/fighting-youth-unemployment-through-education/|website=UNESCO|accessdate=2014-10-22}}</ref> Those who graduate with a university education are finding it difficult to find employment. 80% of recent graduates are listed as unemployed.<ref name=Almonitor>{{cite web|title=Almonitor|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/politics/2012/12/violence-in-iraq-affects-family-life-too.html#}}</ref>
== Health == The Iraqi Diaspora has resulted in the decline of health [[infrastructures]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=The Lancet|last1=Levy|first1=Barry|authorlink2=Victor W. Sidel|authorlink1=Barry S. Levy|last2=Sidel|first2=Victor|journal=Lancet|date=2013-03-16|volume=381|page=2| doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(13)60254-8}}</ref> [[Malnutrition]] is an issue for Iraqi youth. There are over 1.5 million suffering from its effects. 3.5 million individuals are living in [[poverty]].<ref>{{cite web|title=About Iraq|url=http://www.iq.undp.org/content/iraq/en/home/countryinfo|website=UNDP in Iraq|accessdate=9 December 2014}}</ref> A decrease in the [[infant mortality]] rate has been seen over the past few decades. This rate dropped from over 40 infant deaths in 2010 per 1000 births, to under 35 per 1000 births in the 1980s. The mortality rates for Iraqi children under the age of 5 has also decreased. This rate dropped from 60 deaths per 1000 in the 1980s, to under 40 by 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=United Nations|url=http://www.escwa.un.org/popin/members/iraq.pdf|website=United Nations}}</ref>
In the [[Kurdistan]] region there is a high rate of [[suicide]] among female youth. Female youth in [[arranged marriages]] having higher rates of incidence. Many of them commit suicide as a sacrifice for their strong beliefs. This is called [[self-immolation]].<ref name="Suicide in Kurdistan">{{cite journal|title=Suicide in Kurdistan|last1=Vian Nissan|first1=Hanna|last2=Abdulbaghi|first2=Ahmad|journal=Nordic Journal of Psychiatry|date=2013|volume=67|pages=140–144| |doi=10.3109/08039488.2012.761401}}</ref> In the city of [[Sindar]], the rate of suicides have doubled in comparison with the rate of suicide in the US.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Arango|first1=Tim|title=Where arranged marriages are customary, suicides grow more common|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/07/world/middleeast/more-suicides-in-iraq-region-where-arranged-marriage-is-common.html?_r=0|website=The New York Times|publisher=Sindar Journal|accessdate=2014-10-22}}</ref>

{{Chinese name|[[Zheng (surname)|Zheng]]}}
'''Zheng Xiaoying''' (born 1929) is the first woman [[Conducting|conductor]] in [[China]]. Zheng was the chief conductor of the [[China National Opera|China National Opera House]] (CNOH) and she formed and conducted at the [[Xiamen Philharmonic Orchestra]].<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://english.cri.cn/4406/2010/04/22/1122s564861.htm|title = China's First Female Conductor Zheng Xiaoying|last = |first = |date = 22 April 2010|work = Cri English|access-date = 14 January 2016|via = }}</ref> She has also been a dean in the [[Central Conservatory of Music|Central Conservatory of Music in Beijing]] (CCOM).
== Biography == Zheng was born in [[Yongding District, Longyan|Yongding, Fujian]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|url = http://confuciusmag.com/zheng-xiaoying-cultural-symphony|title = Zheng Xiaoying: Cultural Symphony|last = Cheng|first = Ye|date = December 2013|journal = Confucius Institute Magazine|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 14 January 2016|volume = 6|issue = 29}}</ref> Zheng is of [[Hakka people|Hakka]] descent and felt that her family valued education.<ref name=":1" /> Zheng first studied at Jingling Women's University in [[Nanjing]] in 1947.<ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url = http://www.whatsonxiamen.com/news3735.html|title = Xiamen Philharmonic Orchestra founder - Zheng Xiaoying|last = |first = |date = 20 July 2008|work = What's On Xiamen|access-date = 14 January 2016|via = }}</ref> Zheng took part in the [[Chinese Communist Revolution]], where her job was to train a large song and dance troupe and conducting [[Chinese opera]]s.<ref name=":5">{{Cite book|title = A Dictionary for the Modern Conductor|last = Brown|first = Emily Freeman|publisher = Rowman & Littlefield Publishers|year = 2015|isbn = 9780810884014|location = |pages = 379–380|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=k9SOCgAAQBAJ&lpg=PA380&dq=%22zheng%20xiaoying%22&pg=PA379#v=onepage&q=%22zheng%20xiaoying%22&f=false}}</ref> She was working in [[Henan|Henan province]].<ref name=":6" />
Later, Zheng studied at the CCOM in 1952.<ref name=":0" /> Her first conducting teacher was Nicolai Tumascheve, who taught chorus-conducting.<ref name=":4">{{Cite book|title = Encyclopedia of Contemporary Chinese Culture|last = Ge|first = Congmin|publisher = Routledge|year = 2005|isbn = 9780415777162|location = |pages = 1015|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=2rLBvrlKI7QC&lpg=PA1015&dq=%22zheng%20xiaoying%22&pg=PA1015#v=onepage&q=%22zheng%20xiaoying%22&f=false|editor-last = Davis|editor-first = Edward L.}}</ref> In 1955, she was sent to a special course taught by [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] conductors where she was the only woman in the class.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url = http://www.womenofchina.cn/womenofchina/html1/people/artists/17/2096-1.htm|title = CNOH Confers Zheng Xiaoying 'Honorary Conductor for Life'|last = Liu|first = Sylvia|date = 10 April 2014|work = Women of China|access-date = 14 January 2016|via = }}</ref> She taught at the CCOM between 1956 and 1960.<ref name=":3" /> Zheng then studied opera conducting at the [[Moscow Conservatory]] between 1960 and 1963.<ref name=":0" /> In 1962, she was first Chinese conductor to conduct an opera in a foreign setting when she conducted "[[Tosca]]" at the Moscow National Theater.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url = http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2003-07/23/content_989036.htm|title = Chinaview People|date = |access-date = 14 January 2016|website = Xinhua Online|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> After Moscow, she returned to CCOM and taught until the [[Cultural Revolution]] interrupted her work.<ref name=":3" /> During the revolution, there "was no classical music in China".<ref name=":5" />
Zheng became the Principal Conductor at the CNOH in [[Beijing]] in 1977.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Dictionary of Women Worldwide: 25,000 Women Through the Ages|last = |first = |publisher = Gale|year = 2006|isbn = 978-0787675851|location = |pages = |via = HighBeam Research|chapter = Zeng Xiaoying (1929-)|chapter-url = https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G2-2588825582.html|subscription = yes}}</ref> She was involved in the "influential performances" of ''The God of Flowers, [[La traviata|La Traviata]], [[Carmen]], [[The Marriage of Figaro|Le Nozze di Figaro]]'' and ''[[Madama Butterfly|Madam Butterfly]]''.<ref name=":4" /> In the 1980s, she helped French conductor, Jean Perrison, make the first Chinese translation of ''Carmen'' when he visited Beijing.<ref name=":5" />
In 1993, she founded the first women' symphony orchestra in China, the Ai Yue Nu Philharmonic Orchestra, which has performed around the world.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.asiasource.org/arts/unbreaksprts/Daughter.cfm|title = Professor Zheng Xiaoying: China's First Woman Conductor|date = |access-date = 15 January 2016|website = Unbreakable Spirits: Women Breaking Down Barriers in China|publisher = Asia Source|last = |first = |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20060624085057/http://www.asiasource.org/arts/unbreaksprts/Daughter.cfm|archive-date = 24 June 2006}}</ref> The group plays both Western and Chinese music.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Cambridge Companion to Conducting|last = Edwards|first = J. Michele|publisher = Cambridge University Press|year = 2003|isbn = 9780521527910|location = |pages = 233|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=7zsis3X3XUMC&lpg=PA233&dq=%22Zheng%20xiaoying%22%20conductor&pg=PA233#v=onepage&q=%22Zheng%20xiaoying%22%20conductor&f=false|editor-last = Bowen|editor-first = Jose Antonio|chapter = Women on the Podium}}</ref> Zheng and the women's orchestra performed at the [[Fourth World Conference on Women]].<ref name=":2" />
When Zheng retired from the China National Opera in 1997,<ref name=":6" /> she moved to Xiamen.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.whatsonxiamen.com/news11250.html|title = Zheng Xiaoying, Conductor of Xiamen Philharmonic Orchestra 'Unstoppable'|last = |first = |date = 30 March 2010|work = What's On Xiamen|access-date = 14 January 2016|via = }}</ref> In 1998, she started the Xiamen Philharmonic Orchestra (XPO), a [[Private sector|non-State]] musical ensemble.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url = http://www.china.org.cn/english/culture/38463.htm|title = Zheng Xiaoying: Gifted Woman Who Gives Music to the Public|last = |first = |date = 1 August 2002|work = China.org|access-date = 14 January 2016|via = }}</ref> The XPO has grown steadily under her leadership, gaining worldwide recognition.<ref name=":6" /> Zheng was a torchbearer in Xiamen for the [[2008 Summer Olympics|2008 Olympic Games]].<ref name=":6" /><ref>{{Cite news|url = http://confuciusmag.com/zheng-xiaoying-cultural-symphony/29_zheng_xiaoying_03|title = Zheng Xiaoying|last = |first = |date = |work = Confucius Institute|access-date = 14 January 2016|via = }}</ref> In 2011, she was honored with the Golden Melody Prize from the [[Chinese Musicians' Association]].<ref name=":5" /> Zheng received the 2012 Chinese Cultural Figure title for her contribution to music education and conducting.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=89726452&site=ehost-live|title = Famed Female Conductor|last = |first = |date = 27 December 2012|journal = Beijing Review|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 15 January 2016|volume = 55|issue = 52|page = 7|subscription = yes|via = EBSCO}}</ref> She retired from the XPO in 2013.<ref name=":5" /> In 2014, she was honored by the CNOH with the title "Honorary Conductor for Life."<ref name=":3" />
Zheng is an educator who works to help the public understand and appreciate the [[orchestra]].<ref name=":3" /> She also teaches audiences about concert [[etiquette]].<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.scmp.com/news/china/society/article/1802690/notes-lessons-etiquette-chinas-classical-music-concertgoers|title = Off Notes: Lessons in Etiquette for China's Classical Music Concergoers|last = Zhou|first = Laura|date = 19 May 2015|work = South China Morning Post|access-date = 14 January 2016|via = }}</ref>
